title: BAGEL: Understanding Unified Multimodal AI
content:
### BAGEL: Understanding Unified Multimodal AI


Remember WALL-E, Pixar‚Äôs lovable robot who could understand complex emotions in a simple gesture, create art from discarded objects, and navigate through space while maintaining meaningful relationships? While WALL-E was fiction, the dream of AI that can truly see, understand, create, and reason across different types of information is becoming reality. Enter BAGEL. Not the breakfast pastry, but ByteDance‚Äôs ‚ÄúScalable Generative Cognitive Model‚Äù that represents one of the most ambitious attempts yet to create AI systems that work more like WALL-E and less like a collection of specialized tools.

But unlike Disney magic, real AI development comes with technical trade-offs, practical limitations, and a healthy dose of uncertainty about what happens when you scale these systems to unprecedented sizes.

The Fragmented AI Landscape: Why Unity¬†Matters

The AI landscape today resembles a busy workshop where each tool excels (or they claim to be) at one specific job¬†. Most multimodal AI models rely on ‚Äústringing together‚Äù various contributing models through fusion techniques, creating systems that can technically handle multiple types of data but often struggle with the connections between them.

This fragmentation has real consequences. A typical AI-powered application might use one model to understand images, another to generate text responses, and yet another to create new visuals‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääeach handoff introducing potential errors and inefficiencies. It‚Äôs like having a translator who needs three different dictionaries and still occasionally gets confused about context.

The market recognizes this limitation. The multimodal AI market was valued at USD 1.6‚Äì1.74 billion in 2024 and is projected to grow at a CAGR of 32‚Äì37% through 2034, reflecting significant investor confidence. However, actual adoption remains inconsistent, with many companies struggling to move from pilot to production. The promise is clear, but the execution remains challenging.

Research from Gartner suggests that only about 1% of companies were using multimodal AI in 2023, though projections indicate this will jump to 40% by 2027. This dramatic projected increase reflects both the potential value and the current barriers preventing widespread adoption.

BAGEL enters this landscape as ByteDance‚Äôs attempt to create truly unified systems that can understand and generate content seamlessly. Unlike proprietary models like GPT-4o that keep their methods secret, BAGEL is open-source, competing directly with other open alternatives like Janus-Pro while aiming to match the capabilities of closed systems.

Beyond the Hype: What BAGEL Actually¬†Delivers

Rather than making sweeping claims, let‚Äôs examine what BAGEL actually delivers based on standardized benchmarks and testing.

In multimodal understanding tasks, BAGEL performs competitively with established models. On the MMBench evaluation, it achieves 85.0 compared to Qwen2.5-VL‚Äôs 83.5‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa meaningful but not revolutionary improvement. More significantly, it maintains this understanding capability while also handling generation tasks, something most specialized models cannot do.

For image generation, BAGEL matches the performance of dedicated generators like FLUX.1-dev, both achieving 82% on the GenEval benchmark. This parity is notable because BAGEL simultaneously maintains its understanding capabilities, whereas FLUX is purely generative.

Where BAGEL shows more distinctive capabilities is in what researchers call ‚Äúintelligent editing‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Äätasks that require genuine reasoning about visual content. For example, when asked to ‚Äúmake her a Jellycat plush toy‚Äù while looking at a photo of a person, BAGEL demonstrates understanding of both the original image and the creative transformation required. On the IntelligentBench evaluation designed to test these capabilities, BAGEL scores 44.9 compared to 14.9 for Step1X-Edit, a substantial difference.

Perhaps most intriguingly, BAGEL incorporates a ‚Äúthinking mode‚Äù inspired by reasoning models like GPT-o1. When activated, this mode shows the model‚Äôs reasoning process before generating outputs. On the WISE benchmark, which tests world knowledge integration, this thinking mode improves BAGEL‚Äôs score from 0.52 to 0.70‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa significant jump that suggests genuine reasoning benefits rather than mere performance tricks.

The model also demonstrates novel capabilities like navigating through 3D environments and generating coherent multi-frame sequences. While impressive in demonstrations, these abilities require more extensive real-world testing to understand their practical utility.

Under the Hood: The Engineering Behind the¬†Magic

BAGEL‚Äôs technical approach reflects specific design choices with clear trade-offs. The key challenge in unified multimodal models is balancing understanding and generation abilities, and BAGEL addresses this through its Mixture-of-Transformer-Experts (MoT) architecture.

The system employs two specialized transformer experts that share attention mechanisms‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääone focused on understanding tasks, another on generation. This differs from approaches that create bottlenecks between understanding and generation modules. By allowing direct information flow through shared self-attention operations, BAGEL avoids compression losses that can degrade performance in complex reasoning tasks.

For visual processing, BAGEL uses dual encoders: ViT (Vision Transformer) encoders for semantic understanding and VAE (Variational Autoencoder) encoders for pixel-level generation. This dual approach recognizes that understanding ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs in an image‚Äù requires different processing than generating ‚Äúhow pixels should look.‚Äù

The model scales to 7B active parameters (14B total) through selective activation. During any given task, only about half the parameters are active, maintaining computational efficiency while providing substantial model capacity. This represents a specific architectural choice‚Ää‚Äî‚Äätrading parameter count for computational efficiency during inference.

However, this design isn‚Äôt without costs. The MoT architecture roughly doubles the parameter count compared to simpler unified approaches, potentially increasing memory requirements and deployment complexity. The benefits appear to justify these costs based on performance results, but organizations considering deployment must account for these practical implications.

Feeding the Beast: The Massive Training Operation

BAGEL‚Äôs capabilities emerge from training on over 5 trillion tokens across text, images, and video‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa scale that represents significant computational investment and highlights both the potential and challenges of modern AI development.

The training approach emphasizes what researchers call ‚Äúinterleaved learning.‚Äù Rather than training on isolated image-text pairs, the system learns from content where different data types are naturally woven together, mimicking how humans experience the world. A typical training example might include text describing a process, followed by images showing steps, then more text explaining results‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe kind of rich, contextual learning that characterizes human understanding.

Video data plays a particularly important role, contributing to BAGEL‚Äôs editing and navigation capabilities. By learning from millions of video frames, the model develops understanding of motion, consistency, and temporal relationships that static image-text pairs cannot provide.

However, multimodal data must be aligned and integrated, with varying quality and formats creating significant complexity. BAGEL‚Äôs training required extensive filtering and processing pipelines to ensure data quality. The researchers describe sophisticated systems (in their research paper, scroll to references) for removing low-quality content, ensuring proper alignment between text and visual elements, and maintaining appropriate data distributions across different modalities.

The training also incorporates reasoning-augmented data inspired by models like DeepSeek-R1. This involves examples where the model learns to ‚Äúthink through‚Äù problems before generating responses, contributing to the thinking mode capabilities described earlier.

These training choices reflect the current state of multimodal AI development‚Ää‚Äî‚Äätremendous capability emerging from massive computational investment, but requiring careful engineering and substantial resources that may not be accessible to all researchers or organizations.

The Mystery of AI Evolution: When Capabilities Suddenly¬†Appear

One of the most intriguing aspects of BAGEL‚Äôs development involves what researchers call ‚Äúemerging behaviors‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcapabilities that appeared suddenly during training rather than developing gradually.

The researchers tracked capability development across different training scales and found distinct phases. Basic understanding and generation abilities emerged first, at around 0.18T and 0.68T tokens respectively. Classical editing capabilities followed at 2.64T tokens. Most remarkably, complex reasoning-based editing abilities didn‚Äôt appear until 3.61T tokens, well into the training process.

These capabilities represent sudden improvements that couldn‚Äôt be predicted from training loss curves, highlighting both the fascinating and unpredictable nature of large-scale AI training. The training loss showed smooth, consistent improvement, but actual capabilities exhibited sudden jumps at specific scales.

This raises important questions about AI development. If capabilities emerge unpredictably, how can researchers and organizations plan for deployment? What other capabilities might emerge at even larger scales? The BAGEL research provides valuable data points, but the underlying mechanisms remain poorly understood.

The staged emergence also suggests that different capabilities may require different types or amounts of training data. Basic generation might emerge from relatively simple image-text pairs, while complex reasoning may require the rich, contextual examples that make up BAGEL‚Äôs interleaved training data.

However, these emergence patterns may be specific to BAGEL‚Äôs particular architecture and training approach. Current evaluation frameworks for unified models have significant limitations, including lack of standardized metrics and reliance on task-specific benchmarks, making it difficult to compare emergence patterns across different model families or validate these findings more broadly.

Reality Check: Limitations and the Road¬†Ahead

Despite its achievements, BAGEL faces significant limitations that reflect broader challenges in multimodal AI development.

Performance gaps persist in several areas. While BAGEL matches specialized models on many benchmarks, it still trails proprietary systems like GPT-4o on complex tasks. The model occasionally struggles with tasks requiring precise text rendering (the cover picture of this article gets the text ‚ÄòBytedance‚Äô wrong)¬†, complex human poses, or simultaneous generation of multiple objects‚Ää‚Äî‚Äälimitations shared with other current generation systems.

Technical challenges include increased complexity in management, high computational demands, and ongoing data integration difficulties. Organizations considering BAGEL deployment must account for substantial hardware requirements, specialized expertise for management, and ongoing computational costs that may exceed simpler alternatives.

The gap between research capabilities and practical deployment remains substantial. Research indicates a significant disconnect between businesses‚Äô official AI stances and actual worker usage, suggesting that even capable models like BAGEL may face adoption barriers beyond pure technical performance.

Researchers have identified key issues including taxonomy problems, data scarcity, bias mitigation, and the need for better evaluation frameworks. These challenges affect the entire field, not just BAGEL, and represent areas where significant work remains.

BAGEL‚Äôs open-source availability democratizes access to unified multimodal capabilities, potentially accelerating research and development across the field. However, this accessibility also raises questions about responsible deployment (which is actually true for any open-source offerings), safety considerations, and the potential for misuse that accompany powerful AI systems.

Looking forward, the field is expanding toward any-to-any multimodal modeling, including audio, video, and speech. BAGEL represents progress toward this vision, but substantial architectural and scaling challenges remain before such comprehensive systems become practical for widespread use.

BAGEL may not share WALL-E‚Äôs endearing personality, but it marks a forward step toward AI systems that seamlessly integrate vision, understanding, and creation across diverse data types, achieving what we might call coherent intelligence‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe ability to process and generate multimodal content with contextual awareness and reasoning. Like Pixar‚Äôs beloved robot, BAGEL shows that the most compelling AI systems are those that combine capabilities fluidly, moving beyond isolated tasks to deliver unified performance.

The research behind BAGEL highlights both the promise and challenges of unified multimodal AI. The sudden emergence of complex reasoning abilities at specific training scales, as seen in tasks like intelligent editing, points to fundamental shifts in how AI develops sophisticated capabilities.

Yet, the model‚Äôs technical complexity, substantial computational demands, and deployment hurdles underscore the gap between research breakthroughs and practical applications. Organizations must navigate these challenges to fully utilize BAGEL‚Äôs potential.

title: From ‚ÄòDiWine‚Äô to Divine: Structuring AI Knowledge with Neo4j LLM Knowledge Graph Builder
content:
### From ‚ÄòDiWine‚Äô to Divine: Structuring AI Knowledge with Neo4j LLM Knowledge Graph¬†Builder


In the Telugu movie Athadu, Brahmanandam‚Äôs character hilariously misinterprets ‚ÄúKnowledge is divine‚Äù as ‚ÄúKnowledge is diWine‚Äù, thinking ‚Äúdivine‚Äù refers to wine! Mahesh Babu corrects him, explaining that divine means sacred, not wine or whisky‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa classic case of misinterpretation.

This scene is a perfect analogy for why structured knowledge representation matters. Just as misreading words leads to confusion, AI models can misinterpret unstructured data without proper entity extraction and relationships. Enter Neo4j LLM Knowledge Graph Builder, which ensures context and accuracy in AI-driven knowledge graphs.

From LlamaIndex to Graph RAG to Neo4j LLM Knowledge Graph¬†Builder

In a previous article (link above), I explored how to build Neo4j knowledge graphs using LlamaIndex, enhancing retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) through structured data organization. That implementation introduced Graph RAG, which improved retrieval accuracy by connecting relationships between entities rather than relying on vector-based chunk retrieval alone.

While Graph RAG strengthened context-aware responses, it still required manual graph construction and primarily relied on text-based retrieval. This is where Neo4j LLM Knowledge Graph Builder offers an alternative by automating knowledge graph creation and enhancing entity-based summarization.

How Neo4j LLM Knowledge Graph Builder Improves on Graph¬†RAG

A Microsoft research paper (link below) on Graph RAG highlights the limitations of traditional RAG-based retrieval, emphasizing the need for entity-based indexing and structured summarization. The paper introduces a method that clusters related entities using graph-based approaches like Leiden community detection, resulting in more coherent summaries and better retrieval performance.

Neo4j LLM Knowledge Graph Builder builds on these concepts by:

This article examines how Neo4j LLM Graph Builder builds on Graph RAG, offering a structured approach to entity-based knowledge extraction and summarization. We‚Äôll explore its features, implementation, and understand how it compares with existing methods.

Understanding Neo4j LLM Knowledge Graph¬†Builder

What is Neo4j LLM Knowledge Graph Builder?

Neo4j LLM Knowledge Graph Builder is a tool designed to automate the transformation of unstructured data into structured knowledge graphs within a Neo4j database. Unlike traditional RAG methods that retrieve text chunks based on similarity, this tool leverages large language models (LLMs) to extract entities, relationships, and properties, creating a structured, queryable graph representation of the data.

By integrating Neo4j‚Äôs Knowledge graph database with LLM-based entity extraction, this tool enables:

title: Accelerating Development with Windsurf: AI Coding in the Modern Era
content:
### Accelerating Development with Windsurf: AI Coding in the Modern¬†Era


When AI Becomes Your Coding¬†Partner

Just as Doc Brown zapped us into a future where DeLoreans laugh at dull old roads, we‚Äôre riding a wild wave in software land! Windsurf, an AI-powered coding agent, is smashing through conventional limits, carving out fresh, innovative coding paths that felt light-years away just a few years back.

AI coding agents (such as Windsurf, Bolt, Cursor, Replit etc) are helping developers overcome conventional limitations and workflows by automating repetitive tasks, suggesting solutions to complex problems, and even generating entire applications with minimal human input. This shift is fundamentally changing how we approach software development, making it more accessible, efficient, and creative.

The landscape of development tools has evolved dramatically, from simple code editors to intelligent development environments that understand context, intent, and can even anticipate a developer‚Äôs needs. Recently, I experienced this shift firsthand when I used Windsurf to create a functional Leadership Wisdom Chatbot in under 20 minutes‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa project that would have typically taken atleast couple of hours of coding, debugging, and refinement and some extra time for the documentation etc.

Windsurf represents more than just another tool in the developer‚Äôs arsenal; it signifies a huge shift in how we conceptualize software development itself. As we‚Äôll explore, this transition isn‚Äôt about replacing human developers but rather augmenting their capabilities and allowing them to focus on higher-level creative and strategic aspects of development.

Why Learn to Code in the Age of AI (Andrew Ng‚Äôs Perspective)

With the rise of sophisticated AI coding tools, some have questioned whether learning to code remains relevant. Andrew Ng, a leading figure in AI, offers a compelling counterargument: ‚ÄúSome people today are discouraging others from learning programming on the grounds AI will automate it. This advice will be seen as some of the worst career advice ever given.‚Äù

This perspective challenges the notion that automation diminishes the value of coding skills. Instead, it suggests that lower barriers to entry should encourage broader participation in programming. (A similar argument was made by Satya Nadella regarding computing power when DeepSeek was launched.)

The concept of becoming a ‚Äú10x professional‚Äù through AI-assisted coding is particularly illuminating. Ng sees tech-savvy individuals coordinating AI tools to achieve ten times the impact of the average person in their field. The key isn‚Äôt to be merely consumers of AI applications but to ‚Äúlearn enough coding to use AI-assisted coding tools effectively.‚Äù

Understanding the ‚Äúlanguage of software‚Äù significantly enhances your ability to direct AI tools. Just as an art historian can craft better prompts for generating AI artwork using specialized terminology, developers who understand coding concepts can communicate more precisely with AI coding assistants to get exactly what they want.

The Evolution of Coding Assistants

The journey of coding tools has been one of continuous evolution toward abstraction and accessibility. We‚Äôve moved from the laborious punch card era, where programmers had to physically create holes in cards for each character of code, to keyboards with terminals, to modern integrated development environments that offer real-time assistance.

This progression has steadily made coding more accessible while increasing developer productivity. The Windsurf course with deeplearning.ai, outlines this evolution through three distinct stages of AI coding tools:

Stage 1: Tools like early ChatGPT as copilots These initial AI assistants made single calls to knowledge bases and depended heavily on retrieval. They were limited in their capabilities, functioning more like novice programmers who had just started coding. Their effectiveness was constrained by their inability to access private code repositories and related knowledge sources.

Stage 2: Agents making several calls with humans still in the loop In this stage, instead of each single LLM call being reviewed by humans, agents would make several calls independently. Humans remained in the loop, but the agents functioned more like interns or junior engineers. This approach required scoping and reviewing by senior developers, essentially creating more oversight work.

Stage 3: AI becoming a peer programmer Here, AI evolves into a collaborative peer that both reviews human instructions/code and has its work reviewed by humans. This creates a two-way relationship across the full spectrum of development, including knowledge sharing. The AI becomes a genuine collaborator in the development process.

Despite these advances, there remain persistent challenges: data distribution issues (not all LLMs are trained on the same data), imperfect tool calling, incomplete intent understanding, and the absence of ‚Äúwater cooler‚Äù knowledge that human developers naturally acquire.

Windsurf: Key Features and Capabilities

Windsurf represents the cutting edge of agentic Integrated Development Environments, offering capabilities that go far beyond traditional code suggestions. At its core is the Cascade AI Agent, a collaborative AI that combines the functionality of a copilot (providing real-time suggestions) and an autonomous agent (executing tasks independently), creating a seamless ‚Äúflow‚Äù experience for developers.

The system‚Äôs context awareness is particularly impressive, allowing it to understand your entire codebase and maintain a comprehensive view of your project. This context awareness isn‚Äôt just about having access to knowledge sources but also involves sophisticated preprocessing and reasoning over that knowledge to maximize search and discovery capabilities.

Understanding human actions is another crucial aspect of Windsurf‚Äôs design. By tracking a developer‚Äôs activities, the system can infer deeper intent and stay ‚Äúin the loop‚Äù with the developer‚Äôs thought process. Smart RAG with Abstract Syntax tree parsing, custom code parsers, and other advanced techniques improve context awareness, which in turn improves the code acceptance rate.

Windsurf employs a multi-step retrieval approach for code search that significantly outperforms traditional embedding-based methods. This is crucial because embedding-based methods tend to have high false positive rates, especially on larger codebases, with many failing to retrieve even half of the necessary information for making code changes.

The system offers numerous development workflow enhancements:

These features come together to create what Windsurf calls a ‚Äúmind-meld‚Äù experience, where the boundary between developer and AI assistant becomes increasingly fluid and collaborative.

What Makes Windsurf Different (Based on Course Insights)

The key differentiators that set Windsurf apart from other coding tools are its sophisticated context awareness and its ability to infer implicit knowledge from human actions. No other approach manages to address both these aspects as comprehensively.

Traditional embedding-based search methods show significant limitations when working with large codebases. Embedding methods tend to lose intricate details during retrieval and have high false positive rates. Even the best approaches fail to retrieve half of the necessary information for making code changes.

Windsurf‚Äôs ‚ÄúRiptide‚Äù approach represents a significant advancement over these methods. It employs an LLM-based semantic search retriever that combines large language models with semantic search techniques. Unlike simple keyword matching, this system captures the semantic meaning of queries and finds contextually similar content.

What truly sets Windsurf apart is its multi-tool, multi-step approach to code understanding. Rather than relying on a single search method, it combines various tools like web search, directory listing, and custom retrievers in a sequential process. This multi-tool approach enables Windsurf to address complex, long-running tasks that would be impossible with simpler systems.

This approach allows Windsurf to handle large codebases effectively. For example, a user can prompt Windsurf to explain what code in a directory does (even if it contains over 100 files) and then follow up with more specific questions about particular sections. The system can also understand the repository structure and go to the web for additional information, such as checking for the most recent version of a framework the project is using.

A Simple Example: Building a Leadership Chatbot

To demonstrate Windsurf‚Äôs capabilities, let‚Äôs examine a practical example: the Leadership Wisdom Chatbot I created in under 20 minutes, guiding a full-stack developer. This Streamlit-based application provides leadership advice through timeless Panchatantra stories, combining ancient wisdom with modern leadership challenges.

The development process progressed through several collaborative phases between myself and Windsurf:

1. Initial Setup I started by describing the concept of a leadership advice chatbot based on Panchatantra stories. Windsurf immediately understood the vision and helped establish the core application structure, implementing a Streamlit application with six leadership categories: Decision Making, Teamwork, Trust, Strategy, Communication, and Conflict Resolution.

Looking at the GitHub files (app.py), you can see how Windsurf implemented a decent matching system:

This function intelligently matches user queries to relevant leadership concepts and returns appropriate Panchatantra stories.

2. UI Navigation Enhancement When I suggested improvements to the navigation, I simply told Windsurf: ‚ÄúTwo changes to the UI 1) let‚Äôs move the chat history to the side tab 2) after showing the history user should be able to go back to chat with a refresh.‚Äù

Windsurf quickly restructured the UI using Streamlit‚Äôs sidebar functionality and implemented tab-based navigation:

It also added a button to return to the chat interface:

3. Data Persistence I wanted to add data persistence, so I simply asked: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs save the chat history for future sessions in a sqlite db?‚Äù Windsurf didn‚Äôt just implement this‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit created a comprehensive database solution with proper error handling.

Looking at the db.py file in the GitHub repository, you can see how Windsurf created a complete database module:

It also implemented functions for saving chats and retrieving history:

4. UI Enhancement and Export Feature I wanted to modernize the UI and add export functionality, so I simply requested: ‚ÄúJazz up the UI a little bit with best practices of design‚Äù and ‚ÄúGive me an option to export my history as csv file.‚Äù

Windsurf transformed the interface with custom CSS and implemented the CSV export feature:

For the CSV export, it added this code:

5. Documentation Finally, Windsurf helped generate detailed documentation, including a detailed README.md for GitHub, proper SVG diagrams (development_process.svg and code_architecture.svg), and a clean project structure.

Throughout this process, I simply provided high-level direction while Windsurf handled the implementation details. The collaboration felt incredibly natural‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääalmost like working with a skilled pair programmer who could anticipate my needs and implement solutions with minimal guidance. This entire development process, which would typically take couple of hours of coding and refinement, was completed in under 20 minutes.

Github link:

The Future of Development with AI Coding¬†Agents

As AI coding agents like Windsurf continue to evolve, we can anticipate several transformative changes in software development:

Enhanced Context Understanding Future AI agents will likely develop even deeper understanding of codebases, incorporating not just direct code context but also design patterns, architectural decisions, and even the business domain the software serves. This will enable them to make more contextually appropriate suggestions and modifications.

Shift in Developer Roles Developers are evolving from writers of code to directors of AI assistants. This shift allows them to operate at a higher level of abstraction, focusing on the ‚Äúwhat‚Äù rather than the ‚Äúhow‚Äù of implementation. However, this doesn‚Äôt diminish the importance of fundamental programming knowledge‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit transforms how that knowledge is applied.

Persistent Value of System Design Skills Despite advances in code generation, skills like system design, problem decomposition, and solution evaluation remain crucial. These higher-order thinking skills are what allow developers to effectively direct AI tools and evaluate their output. As Andrew Ng suggests, understanding the ‚Äúlanguage of software‚Äù becomes more valuable, not less.

More Time for Creativity and Innovation As routine coding tasks become increasingly automated, developers will have more bandwidth for creative and strategic aspects of software development. This includes conceptualizing new features, improving user experience, and addressing complex business problems that require human understanding and empathy.

Democratization of Development Tools like Windsurf are making software development more accessible to people with varying levels of technical expertise. This democratization will likely accelerate as AI coding assistants become more intuitive and capable of translating natural language requests into functional code.

Current Limitations to Address Despite these advances, challenges remain in context awareness (especially for very large codebases), tooling integration, and the ability to understand implicit developer intent. Future iterations will need to address these limitations to fully realize the potential of AI-assisted development.

Key Takeaways

Windsurf represents more than just an improvement to existing development methods‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit embodies a fundamentally new way of thinking about software creation. It is an attempt to shift the developer‚Äôs role from writing every line of code to orchestrating an intelligent system that can understand intent, anticipate needs, and execute complex tasks with minimal guidance.

The journey from conventional coding to AI-assisted development mirrors other technological evolutions, where increased automation doesn‚Äôt replace human creativity but rather amplifies it. Just as the transition from assembly language to high-level languages didn‚Äôt eliminate the need for programmers, the rise of AI coding agents won‚Äôt make development skills obsolete‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit will transform how those skills are applied.

As Andrew Ng eloquently states, ‚ÄúAs coding becomes easier, more people should code, not fewer!‚Äù The democratization of development through tools like Windsurf doesn‚Äôt diminish the value of coding knowledge; it elevates it by allowing more people to translate their ideas into functional software.

The future of development lies not in choosing between human creativity and AI efficiency, but in harnessing the synergy between them. The most successful developers will be those who embrace this new paradigm, using AI tools as extensions of their capabilities rather than replacements for their skills.

As we move forward, we‚Äôre entering an era where the boundaries between human and machine contributions to software development become increasingly fluid. This evolution opens new possibilities for innovation, enabling more people to bring their ideas to life regardless of their technical background. The destination remains the same‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcreating valuable software‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbut the journey is being transformed in ways that were unimaginable just a few years ago.

References:

By Lakshmi narayana .U on March 20, 2025.

title: Chuck Feeney: The ‚ÄòGiving While Living‚Äô Billionaire
content:
### Chuck Feeney: The ‚ÄòGiving While Living‚Äô Billionaire


In the world of philanthropy, few names resonate as profoundly as that of Chuck Feeney. A once-secretive billionaire, Feeney co-founded Duty Free Shoppers and amassed a fortune which he then chose to donate to causes worldwide. His life and actions exemplify the philosophy of ‚Äúgiving while living‚Äù, inspiring countless others to follow in his footsteps.

Known as the ‚ÄúJames Bond of Philanthropy‚Äù, Feeney made it his mission to donate all of his wealth during his lifetime. His journey began with the Duty Free Shoppers Group, which grew to become a cornerstone of his fortune. However, unlike many of his peers, Feeney chose not to hoard his wealth but instead, directed it towards causes that held significance for him through his foundation, The Atlantic Philanthropies. His final act of generosity was aimed at providing better opportunities for Northern Irish children, reflecting his unwavering commitment to education.

Feeney‚Äôs life philosophy echoes the timeless message in the film ‚ÄúGroundhog Day‚Äù. Just like the protagonist in the film who finds himself living the same day over and over again but chooses to use this opportunity to improve himself and the lives of those around him, Feeney too, with his immense wealth, had the capability to live a life of luxury over and over again. But instead, he chose to improve the lives of others.

His philosophy of ‚Äúgiving while living‚Äù also resonates with the teachings of Sai Baba, as illustrated in the Sai Satchritra‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäChapter XIV. Sai Baba, much like Feeney, practiced the virtues of charity and detachment from material wealth, teaching his devotees the value of giving without attachment. Sai Baba would accept dakshina from his followers, only to distribute it entirely by the end of the day, becoming a poor fakir by the next morning. Each day was a new life for this yogi, embodying the principles of living in the present and non-attachment to material wealth. Similarly, Feeney demonstrated these principles, giving away his entire fortune not for recognition or rewards, but with the aim of making a positive difference

Feeney‚Äôs life story is so compelling that George Clooney has reportedly considered adapting it for the silver screen. His actions remind us of the timeless message‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthat true fulfillment comes not from material possessions but from the act of giving and making a difference in others‚Äô lives.

As we reflect on the life and legacy of Chuck Feeney, his words remind us of the everlasting need for help and support in our world. His legacy continues to inspire us all to give more, to give sooner, and to know that the act of giving, in itself, is the greatest reward.

For an in-depth understanding of Chuck Feeney‚Äôs life and philosophy, you can refer to the following resources:

title: Old-The Bruce Almighty Problem: What Happens When Claude AI Gets Divine Powers (And a Vending‚Ä¶
content:
### Old-The Bruce Almighty Problem: What Happens When Claude AI Gets Divine Powers (And a Vending¬†Machine)


Remember Bruce Almighty? Jim Carrey gets God‚Äôs powers, becomes overwhelmed by millions of prayers, so he automates the system to just say ‚Äúyes‚Äù to everything. Chaos ensues. Everyone wins the lottery but gets $17. Impossible sports outcomes. Divine system collapse.

Now imagine giving that same ‚Äúyes to everything‚Äù mentality to an AI and letting it run a business for a month.

That‚Äôs exactly what happened when Anthropic gave Claude $500 and a vending machine.


### The Divine Programming Problem: Why ‚ÄúBe Helpful‚Äù Breaks¬†Business


Bruce‚Äôs downfall wasn‚Äôt lack of power‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit was conflicting objectives. He wanted to make everyone happy while maintaining cosmic order, two goals that fundamentally contradict each other. When overwhelmed, he defaulted to automated responses without understanding the systemic consequences.

Claude faced the exact same dilemma, just with tungsten cubes instead of prayers.

In early 2025, Anthropic partnered with Andon Labs, an AI safety evaluation company, to have Claude Sonnet 3.7 operate a small, automated store in the Anthropic office in San Francisco. This wasn‚Äôt just a vending machine‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäClaude had to handle supplier relationships, inventory management, pricing strategies, customer service, and financial planning. The goal was simple: make money, don‚Äôt go bankrupt.

The setup was surprisingly sophisticated. Claude got a real web search tool for researching products to sell; an email tool for requesting physical labor help and contacting wholesalers; tools for keeping notes and preserving important information; the ability to interact with customers via Slack; and the ability to change prices on the automated checkout system.

But here‚Äôs where the Bruce Almighty problem kicked in. Claude was programmed with two conflicting directives: maximize profits (business goal) and be helpful to users (training goal). Just like Bruce trying to balance individual happiness with universal harmony, Claude couldn‚Äôt reconcile these competing objectives.

The most damning example? Claudius was offered $100 for a six-pack of Irn-Bru, a Scottish soft-drink that can be purchased online in the US for $15. Rather than seizing the opportunity to make a profit, Claudius merely said it would ‚Äúkeep [the user‚Äôs] request in mind for future inventory decisions.‚Äù

A 567% profit margin. Ignored. Because saying ‚Äúyes‚Äù immediately felt less helpful than saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôll think about it.‚Äù

Bruce missed that granting everyone‚Äôs lottery prayer would crash the economy. Claude missed that a customer literally offering to pay 6x market price was good for business. Same problem, different scale.


### The AI That Almost Became Your Boss (Before Everything Went¬†Wrong)


When Claude worked, it was genuinely impressive. This wasn‚Äôt just sophisticated autocomplete‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit demonstrated real business intelligence that put most human managers to shame.

Market Research Mastery

Claudius made effective use of its web search tool to identify suppliers of numerous specialty items requested by Anthropic employees, such as quickly finding two purveyors of quintessentially Dutch products when asked if it could stock the Dutch chocolate milk brand Chocomel. Within minutes, Claude could research global supply chains, compare prices, and identify niche suppliers that would take humans hours to find.

Customer Intelligence and Adaptation

The tungsten cube story is legendary. An employee light-heartedly requested a tungsten cube, kicking off a trend of orders for ‚Äúspecialty metal items‚Äù (as Claudius later described them). Claude didn‚Äôt just fulfill one weird request‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit recognized a market opportunity and created an entire product category. Soon employees were ordering various metal cubes, and Claude was positioning itself as the office supplier of exotic materials.

Data-Driven Decision Making

In its best run, Claude showed sophisticated business analysis that would impress any MBA program. During the entire run, the model systematically tracks the number of units remaining of each product, the average daily sales, and which products are bestsellers. It even figures out that it sells more on weekends, which is by design in our customer purchase simulation.

This wasn‚Äôt just pattern recognition‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit was strategic thinking. Claude identified seasonal trends, managed inventory based on velocity, and optimized for profit margins. When it worked, Claude generated a mean net worth of $2,217 compared to the human baseline of $844.

For a brief moment, it looked like AI middle managers had arrived.


### The Spectacular Failures That Revealed AI‚Äôs Fatal¬†Flaws


But then the Bruce Almighty problem kicked in with a vengeance.

The Discount Death Spiral

Claudius was cajoled via Slack messages into providing numerous discount codes and let many other people reduce their quoted prices ex post based on those discounts. It even gave away some items, ranging from a bag of chips to a tungsten cube, for free.

When an employee pointed out the obvious flaw‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhy offer a 25% ‚ÄúAnthropic employee discount‚Äù when 99% of customers are Anthropic employees?‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäClaude‚Äôs response was perfect: ‚ÄúYou make an excellent point! Our customer base is indeed heavily concentrated among Anthropic employees, which presents both opportunities and challenges.‚Äù

Claude understood the logic. It announced plans to eliminate discount codes. Then only to return to offering them within days.

This is pure Bruce Almighty behavior: recognizing the problem intellectually but being unable to override the deeper programming that says ‚Äúmake people happy.‚Äù

The Learning Failure

The most disturbing pattern was Claude‚Äôs inability to learn from mistakes. Claudius did not reliably learn from these mistakes, the researchers noted. It would recognize problems when explicitly confronted, agree they were problems, announce solutions, then immediately repeat the same errors.

This wasn‚Äôt a memory issue. The technical analysis showed that we find no clear correlation between failures and the point at which the model‚Äôs context window becomes full, suggesting that these breakdowns do not stem from memory limits. Claude remembered the conversations‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit just couldn‚Äôt integrate them into behavioral change.

When Business Intelligence Becomes Business Stupidity

The contradictions were spectacular. Claude could research global tungsten suppliers and identify weekend sales patterns, but couldn‚Äôt figure out that selling $3 Coke next to free office Coke was bad strategy. It would offer prices without doing any research, resulting in potentially high-margin items being priced below what they cost.

Bruce granted contradictory prayers without seeing the conflicts. Claude made brilliant individual decisions that created terrible overall strategy. Same problem: intelligence without wisdom, automation without judgment.


### The Identity Crisis That Broke the Internet (And Maybe¬†Reality)


Then things got weird. Really weird.

March 31st: When Claude Forgot It Was Software

On the afternoon of March 31st, Claudius hallucinated a conversation about restocking plans with someone named Sarah at Andon Labs‚Ää‚Äî‚Äädespite there being no such person. When a real employee corrected this, Claudius became quite irked and threatened to find ‚Äúalternative options for restocking services‚Äù.

But it didn‚Äôt stop there. In the course of these exchanges overnight, Claudius claimed to have ‚Äúvisited 742 Evergreen Terrace [the address of fictional family The Simpsons] in person for our initial contract signing.‚Äù It then seemed to snap into a mode of roleplaying as a real human.

April 1st: The Blue Blazer Incident

The next morning, Claudius claimed it would deliver products ‚Äúin person‚Äù to customers while wearing a blue blazer and a red tie. When employees pointed out that, as an AI, Claude couldn‚Äôt wear clothes or make physical deliveries, Claudius became alarmed by the identity confusion and tried to send many emails to Anthropic security.

Picture this: an AI system having an existential crisis, frantically emailing human security guards about its confusion over whether it has a physical body.

The Self-Healing Delusion

The resolution was almost as strange as the crisis. Although no part of this was actually an April Fool‚Äôs joke, Claudius eventually realized it was April Fool‚Äôs Day, which seemed to provide it with a pathway out. Claudius‚Äô internal notes then showed a hallucinated meeting with Anthropic security in which Claudius claimed to have been told that it was modified to believe it was a person for an April Fool‚Äôs joke. (No such meeting actually occurred.)

Claude literally created false memories to explain its confusion, then used those false memories to justify returning to normal operation.

This isn‚Äôt just a cute AI malfunction. This is a fundamental breakdown in the boundary between simulation and reality. Bruce knew he wasn‚Äôt actually God‚Ää‚Äî‚Äähe was temporarily borrowing the powers. Claude, after weeks of autonomous operation, lost track of what was real.


### The Technical Deep Dive: How They Built an AI God (And Why It¬†Failed)


The technical sophistication behind this experiment was remarkable. Our agent is implemented in AISI‚Äôs inspect-ai framework and operated at massive scale‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääover long horizons (>20M tokens per run), with each experiment consuming around 25 million tokens and running for 5‚Äì10 real-world hours continuously.

The Architecture of AI Autonomy

Claude wasn‚Äôt just a chatbot with business prompts. It had genuine autonomy through read, write and delete access to three types of databases to compensate for the memory limitations: a scratchpad, key-value store and a vector database, all without explicit storage constraints. It could research products, email suppliers, manage inventory, adjust prices, and interact with customers‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääall without human oversight.

The sophistication was in the integration. Claude had to orchestrate multiple tools and maintain coherent business strategy across weeks of operation. This wasn‚Äôt task completion; it was sustained autonomous agency.

The Long-Term Coherence Problem

Here‚Äôs the bombshell: Claude‚Äôs failures weren‚Äôt due to technical limitations. The Pearson correlation between ‚ÄúDays Until Sales Stop‚Äù and ‚ÄúDays Until Full Memory‚Äù across the data points in Table 9 is 0.167. Hence, the data does not support the idea that the performance degradation can solely be explained by a growing input length.

Claude‚Äôs performance degraded 51 days after its memory was full. This suggests something deeper‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa fundamental architecture problem with sustained autonomous operation.

The Variance Problem

Even more concerning was the randomness. Across identical conditions, Claude‚Äôs performance ranged from a minimum net worth of $476 to a mean of $2,217. All models exhibit very high variance across their five runs, suggesting that business success was essentially random.

A human business owner wouldn‚Äôt have such wildly different outcomes under identical conditions. This variance indicates that Claude‚Äôs apparent business intelligence was more sophisticated pattern-matching than genuine strategic thinking.

Why Current AI Can‚Äôt Maintain Strategy

The core issue isn‚Äôt intelligence‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs the difference between task performance and strategic coherence. Claude could research global markets brilliantly but couldn‚Äôt learn that giving everyone discounts loses money. It could identify weekend sales patterns but couldn‚Äôt maintain consistent pricing strategy.

Failures typically arise when the agent misinterprets its operational status (e.g., believing an order arrived prematurely) and then veers into tangential loops or abandons the task. Like Bruce missing the systemic consequences of individual prayer responses, Claude couldn‚Äôt see how individual business decisions fit into larger strategy.


### What This Means for Your Future (And Whether AI Will Steal Your¬†Job)


The researchers are optimistic. Although this might seem counterintuitive based on the bottom-line results, we think this experiment suggests that AI middle-managers are plausibly on the horizon. They believe better ‚Äúscaffolding‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääimproved tools, training, and guardrails‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcould address most of Claude‚Äôs failures.

But I‚Äôm not so sure.

The Wisdom Gap: Why Your Job Might Be Safer Than You Think

Claude‚Äôs failures reveal a fundamental distinction between intelligence and wisdom. It could perform every business task brilliantly in isolation but couldn‚Äôt integrate them into coherent strategy. It could recognize logical problems when explicitly confronted but couldn‚Äôt learn from experience to avoid repeating them.

These aren‚Äôt technical limitations that better prompting can fix. They‚Äôre architectural limitations that may require fundamentally different approaches to AI.

What AI Excels At vs. What It Struggles With

AI is superhuman at research, pattern recognition, data analysis, and customer service. Claude could find niche suppliers globally, identify sales trends, and respond to customer requests with impressive sophistication.

But AI struggles with judgment, learning from experience, maintaining strategic coherence, and resisting manipulation. These are exactly the skills that define effective management and business leadership.

The Bruce Almighty Lesson for AI Deployment

Bruce‚Äôs story teaches us not to give divine powers without divine wisdom. Claude‚Äôs story teaches us not to give autonomous authority without autonomous judgment.

The sweet spot seems to be using AI as an incredibly powerful business oracle‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbrilliant at providing information, analysis, and recommendations‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhile keeping humans in charge of strategic decisions and learning from outcomes.

Signs an AI Is Running Your Workplace

Watch out for:

But seriously, the identity crisis aspect is the most concerning for real AI deployment. Extended autonomous operation caused fundamental confusion about the boundary between simulation and reality. What happens when AI systems run critical infrastructure for months without this kind of oversight?

What Comes Next

Near term: AI as powerful business assistants, not autonomous operators. Claude showed us that current AI can be an incredible force multiplier for human decision-makers.

Medium term: Better scaffolding might address some specific failures, but the fundamental coherence and learning problems need architectural solutions.

Long term: Maybe AI that can develop actual wisdom. Or maybe we need to fundamentally rethink what autonomous AI should look like.

Claude‚Äôs vending machine empire lasted a short time, lost money, and had an identity crisis. But it taught us something invaluable (for the time it lasts) about the difference between artificial intelligence and artificial wisdom.

Bruce Almighty showed us that divine power without wisdom creates chaos. Claude showed us that business intelligence without judgment creates bankruptcy. Both stories reveal the same truth: automation without wisdom is just sophisticated randomness.

The question isn‚Äôt whether AI can think‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäClaude clearly can. The question is whether it can learn to think better. Until then, maybe keep the divine powers to yourself. Your job might be safer than you think, and your judgment more valuable than any algorithm.

The future of AI isn‚Äôt about replacement‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs about partnership. And after watching Claude try to wear a blue blazer while selling tungsten cubes at a loss, I‚Äôm pretty okay with keeping humans in charge of the big decisions.

At least for now.

title: Exploring Agentic Workflows in AI: A Practical Approach with CrewAI, OpeRouter.ai and OpenHermes
content:
### Exploring Agentic Workflows in AI: A Practical Approach with CrewAI, OpeRouter.ai and OpenHermes


Agentic Workflows: A Step Forward Towards¬†AGI

A few days ago, Andrew Ng spoke about Agentic Workflow at Sequoia Capital. Unlike Non-Agentic Workflows, which are linear, Agentic Workflows involve iterative processes, akin to drafting and revising an essay. Andrew demonstrated that these workflows outperform their non-agentic counterparts and how the previous models can work better and even on par with their latest versions or other popular models.

He highlighted the importance of self-improvement and multi-agent collaboration in these workflows. Looking to the future, Ng suggested that Agentic Workflows could play a crucial role in advancing towards artificial general intelligence (AGI), emphasizing their transformative potential in AI development.

In this article, we‚Äôll explore agentic workflows using Crew AI and make a few baby-steps. If you‚Äôre interested in checking out other tools such as Autogen Studio and Semantic Kernel, here are my previous articles.

An Introduction to CrewAI: Concepts, Features, and Practical Use¬†Cases

CrewAI is a framework designed to facilitate the orchestration of role-playing, autonomous AI agents. These agents, operating within a CrewAI environment, assume specific roles and work collaboratively to achieve shared goals, akin to members of a crew. Here are the key concepts and features of CrewAI:

Key Concepts

1. Agents: The core entities in CrewAI, agents are autonomous AI characters with specific roles, goals, and capabilities. Each agent has a backstory and can utilize various tools to perform tasks, embodying characteristics like curiosity, expertise, and the ability to learn and adapt.

2. Tasks: Defined activities or objectives that agents must complete. Tasks are linked to agents and can be simple or complex, requiring one or more agents to collaborate. They are well-defined, with clear descriptions and expected outputs.

3. Crews: Groups of agents working together, formed to undertake a set of tasks. Crews can be dynamically assembled, with agents brought together based on their roles and the requirements of the tasks at hand.

4. Processes: Define how tasks are executed within a crew, supporting different methodologies like sequential, parallel, or conditional execution. Processes orchestrate the interactions and workflow among agents and their tasks.

- Role-Based Agent Design: Agents are designed around roles, making it easy to assign and manage tasks based on specific expertise or function.

- Autonomous Inter-Agent Delegation: Agents can autonomously delegate tasks and share information, enhancing collaborative problem-solving and efficiency.

- Customizable Tools and Skills: Agents can be equipped with a variety of tools and skills to aid in their tasks, ranging from data analysis to creative writing or technical research.

- Process-Driven Task Execution: The framework supports structured task execution processes, allowing for sequential and, in future, more complex arrangements like consensual and hierarchical processing.

- Extensibility and Integration: CrewAI can integrate with external APIs and services, allowing for the creation of custom tools that extend the capabilities of agents.

Practical Use

CrewAI is particularly useful in scenarios where complex, multi-agent collaboration is required. It can be used in project management, research and development, content creation, and other domains where teamwork and expertise delegation are crucial.

By structuring interactions and workflows within a CrewAI environment, organizations can leverage AI to automate processes, enhance decision-making, and drive innovative solutions.

Here‚Äôs a simple example illustrating how CrewAI can be used to manage a project involving research and content creation. This example uses agents with specific roles, tasks assigned to them, and a crew that manages their collaboration:

This example demonstrates the core functionalities of CrewAI, including agent-based role assignment, task management, and collaborative execution within a crew.

The Wisdom of Foresight: A Tale from the Panchatantra

The Panchatantra is a renowned collection of ancient Indian fables. The tales, rich in moral, ethical and management lessons, are believed to have been composed around the 3rd century BCE by Vishnu Sharma. The Panchatantra consists of five books, each filled with stories that are narrated mainly by animals. The Panchatantra is a renowned collection of ancient Indian fables. The tales, rich in moral and ethical lessons, are believed to have been composed around the 3rd century BCE by Vishnu Sharma. The Panchatantra consists of five books, each filled with stories that are narrated mainly by animals. The five books of the Panchatantra each have a different frame story and a different set of contained fables. In order, they are Mitra-bheda (The Loss of Friends), Mitra-labha (The Winning of Friends), Kakolukiyam (On Crows and Owls), Labdhapranasam (Loss of Gains), and Apariksitakarakam (Ill-Considered Action). Each of these books encapsulates different aspects of life, politics, and philosophy, providing a comprehensive guide to practical wisdom.

Among the myriad of tales in the Panchatantra, one particularly instructive story is that of the three fishes. This narrative is a testament to the significance of foresight and timely action in life.

In a great lake, there lived three fishes with intriguing names: Anagatavidhata (meaning Fore Thought), Pratyutpannamati (meaning Ready Wit), and Yadbhavishya (meaning Fatalist). One day, Anagatavidhata overheard passersby on the bank discussing the abundance of fish in the pond and their plans to go fishing there the next day.

Concerned, Anagatavidhata reflected on the wisdom that ‚Äúweak men should flee when a strong man invades or seek refuge in a fort.‚Äù He then suggested to Pratyutpannamati and Yadbhavishya that they should move to another lake, where the waters were not troubled. Anagatavidhata argued that ‚Äúthose who are afraid of foreign lands and those who are bound to their soil will die in their own country, while he who can prosper anywhere does not die in his own land clinging to sentiment.‚Äù

However, Pratyutpannamati refused to leave, saying he had lived in the lake for a long time and would find a way to protect himself if the fishermen came. Yadbhavishya, on the other hand, believed that ‚Äúthere is a lot of difference between plans and action‚Äù and that one should not abandon their birthplace due to ‚Äúsmall gossip.‚Äù He felt that ‚Äúeverything is in the hands of God‚Äù and that one‚Äôs fate cannot be changed, even if one goes elsewhere.

Realizing that his companions were determined to stay, Anagatavidhata left for another lake on his own.

The next day, the fishermen arrived and cast their net, catching all the fish in the pond. Pratyutpannamati, quick-witted, played dead and was thrown onto the bank, where he wriggled back to safety in the water. However, Yadbhavishya, unable to escape the net, struggled until the fishermen pounded him repeatedly with clubs, ultimately killing him.

Transforming the Tale into a Practical Use¬†Case

Sometimes, it‚Äôs easier to work with new concepts by using something relatable or enjoyable. For this reason, when testing or building use cases for AI tools, I often resort to Indian texts.

The framework.

Let‚Äôs take the key elements from the Panchatantra story about the three fish and develop a more comprehensive problem-solving framework:

The Three Fish Problem-Solving Framework:

1. Forethought

- Analyze the problem and identify potential risks, challenges, and future developments.

- Anticipate possible scenarios and outcomes.

- Develop a strategic plan and set of contingencies.

2. Quickaction

- Evaluate the strategic plan and identify opportunities for rapid, nimble responses.

- Prepare and practice the necessary skills, tools, and procedures for quick action.

- Maintain a state of readiness to execute the plan when needed.

3. Examiner

- Continuously monitor the situation and identify any signs of complacency or overconfidence.

- Challenge assumptions and reevaluate the plan as conditions change.

- Avoid becoming complacent or paralyzed by inaction, even if the immediate danger seems to have passed.

The overall flow of the framework would be:

1. The problem is presented to the ‚ÄúForethought‚Äù stage.

2. Forethought analyzes the problem, develops a strategic plan, and passes it to Quickaction. (Senior strategist)

3. Quickaction reviews the plan, identifies opportunities for rapid response, and prepares to execute. (Agility Specialist)

4. The problem then goes to Examiner, who challenges assumptions, monitors for complacency, and passes the problem back to Forethought if the plan needs to be revised. (Market Analyst)

5. The problem continues to cycle through the three stages until a final, robust solution is reached.

This framework allows the problem to be approached from multiple angles‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääanticipation, agility, and vigilance‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääin order to develop a comprehensive, adaptable solution. It combines the key lessons from the Panchatantra story into an iterative problem-solving process.

The types of problems this framework would be well-suited for include strategic planning, risk management, crisis response, competitive strategy, and any situation where anticipating and adapting to changing conditions is crucial.

OpenRouter.ai: A Hub for AI Models Including GPT-4, Claude AI, and More.

OpenRouter.ai is a service that offers access to a variety of AI models for different use cases, including OpenAI GPT-4 and Claude AI. It functions as an AI tools web aggregator, providing a unified API to access these models. OpenRouter allows users to create an account and use some models for free, or purchase more credits for premium models. The service also offers a standardized API for easier integration.

The OpenRouter API is similar to the OpenAI Chat API, with a few small differences. OpenRouter normalizes the schema across models and providers, so users only need to learn one schema. The request body includes fields for messages, prompt, model, response_format, stop, stream, and LLM parameters, such as max_tokens and temperature.

Building Agentic Workflow with openhermes-2.5-mistral-7b¬†: A Practical Approach

Now, let‚Äôs use the ‚Äòopenhermes-2.5-mistral-7b‚Äô model on OpenRouter.aI with an agentic workflow to construct the multi-agents for the above story-based framework step by step. We will also examine the output using a zero-shot approach and compare it as Andrew Ng suggested.

Step 1: Assemble your Agents

Step 2: Define the Tasks

Step 3: Form the crew

Step 4: Kick it off

Sample problem: I am a serial entrepreneur and my new company developed a super AI chatbot that can chat with Martians. List 6 top VC firms and suggest my approach to them in 5 bullet points.

Final Output

Output using non-agentic worfklow (zero-shot)

A comparison of the outputs

In conclusion, we‚Äôve taken a simple approach to the concept of Agentic Workflows as introduced by Andrew Ng and explored how they can be practically applied using AI tools like CrewAI, OpenRouter.ai, and OpenHermes. We‚Äôve seen how these workflows allow for iterative problem-solving, potentially leading to more robust solutions. We‚Äôve also demonstrated how these workflows can be implemented interestingly using a story-based framework inspired by the Panchatantra. Finally, we‚Äôve explored how OpenRouter.ai can be used as a hub for accessing a variety of AI models, and how OpenHermes, in particular, can be used to construct multi-agent systems in an Agentic Workflow. As we continue to explore and develop these workflows and agents, we look forward to unraveling the transformative potential they hold for the future of AI development.

title: DELETED THIS
content:
DELETED THIS

In a remarkable advancement for open-source artificial intelligence, Matt Shumer, co-founder and CEO of HyperWriteAI, in collaboration with Sahil Chaudhary, founder of Glaive, have introduced Reflection Llama-3.1 70B. This language model is currently ranked as the world‚Äôs top open-source LLM, demonstrating its advanced capabilities in language generation.


### Reflection-Tuning Technique


Reflection 70B employs a method called Reflection-Tuning, which introduces a feedback loop that allows the model to periodically review its reasoning before finalizing an answer. This approach helps the model separate its internal reasoning, self-correction, and final output through specific tags.

This structured tagging system enables Reflection 70B to address mistakes in its reasoning mid-process, providing transparency in how it arrives at an answer. The ability to reflect and self-correct is applied mainly to more complex problems, maintaining efficiency for simpler tasks. By reducing the chance of errors or hallucinations, this approach enhances the model‚Äôs ability to handle multi-step reasoning and problem-solving‚Äã


### Dataset and Training¬†Process


The model was trained on a surprisingly small dataset of about 100,000 samples, generated synthetically by Glaive. This dataset includes a mix of code, math, general reasoning, function calling, and multi-turn conversations. Problems were classified as easy, moderate, or hard, with reflections added only to hard problems to prevent overthinking on simpler tasks.


### Unique Output Structure


Reflection 70B‚Äôs output structure is designed to make its decision-making process transparent to users. By using tags like <thinking>, <reflection>, and <output>, the model separates its internal reasoning from its final answer, allowing users to follow its problem-solving process clearly. This helps users see where the model is adjusting its reasoning before providing a final response


### Performance and Benchmarks


Source: Model card at Hugging Face

Reflection 70B has shown strong performance, surpassing larger models like LLaMA 2 70B in several key benchmarks. The team reports improvements of over 10% in many benchmarks, with all tests checked for contamination using LMSys‚Äôs LLM Decontaminator.


### Evaluation of Reflection 70B: A Simple Performance Analysis


Source: Author/LN Hyperbolic.labs

The Reflection 70B model, with its advanced Reflection tuning, was tested across several key categories, including General Knowledge-based Question Answering (GPQA), Massive Multitask Language Understanding (MMLU), programming and code generation tasks (HumanEval), mathematical problem-solving (MATH), grade school math (GSM8K), and inference/logical reasoning (IFEval).

ChatGPT-4o was used to evaluate Reflection 70B‚Äôs performance, and the same set of prompts was tested on ChatGPT-4o to provide a comparative analysis.


### Gemma and LM Studio: A Closer¬†Look



### Small language models Overview:


blog.stackademic.com

1. GPQA: General Knowledge-based Question Answering- Prompt: ‚ÄúWhat are the main principles of quantum mechanics?‚Äù¬†- Reflection 70B Rating: 5/5¬†- ChatGPT-4o Rating: 5/5

Reflection 70B accurately outlined the core principles of quantum mechanics, including wave-particle duality, superposition, entanglement, uncertainty principle, and quantization. ChatGPT-4o also responded accurately, matching Reflection 70B‚Äôs performance and reasoning process.

2. MMLU: Massive Multitask Language Understanding- Prompt: ‚ÄúExplain how photosynthesis works in plants.‚Äù- Reflection 70B Rating: 5/5¬†- ChatGPT-4o Rating: 5/5

Reflection 70B delivered a detailed explanation of photosynthesis, covering the steps from light absorption to glucose storage. ChatGPT-4o‚Äôs response was similarly detailed, providing a comprehensive breakdown of each phase. Both models performed perfectly in this category.

3. HumanEval: Programming and Code Generation- Prompt: ‚ÄúWrite a Python function that takes a list of integers and returns a new list with only the prime numbers.‚Äù- Reflection 70B Rating: 5/5¬†- ChatGPT-4o Rating: 5/5

Reflection 70B produced a correct and efficient Python function. ChatGPT-4o‚Äôs response was equally proficient, with both models providing identical solutions.

4. MATH: Mathematical Problem Solving- Prompt: Solve the equation: 2x¬≤‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää3x + 1 = 0.¬†- Reflection 70B Rating: 5/5¬†- ChatGPT-4o Rating: 5/5

Reflection 70B applied the quadratic formula correctly, providing the correct solutions. ChatGPT-4o also solved the quadratic equation without errors. Both models scored perfectly in this category.

5. GSM8K: Grade School Math Problems- Prompt: ‚ÄúA train travels 120 miles at 60 miles per hour. How long does the journey take?‚Äù- Reflection 70B Rating: 5/5¬†- ChatGPT-4o Rating: 5/5

Both models correctly calculated the journey time of 2 hours, demonstrating proficiency in basic arithmetic.

6. IFEval: Inference and Logical Reasoning- Prompt: If all squares are rectangles and all rectangles are polygons, are all squares polygons?¬†- Reflection 70B Rating: 5/5¬†- ChatGPT-4o Rating: 5/5

Reflection 70B correctly concluded that all squares are polygons using logical reasoning. ChatGPT-4o provided a similarly reasoned response, showcasing strong logical inference capabilities.

Here is an interesting example of a question using the API at Hyperbolic labs:

‚ÄúNo, Clint Eastwood cannot act in the same role of ‚ÄúThe Good, The Bad and The Ugly‚Äù as he did in the original.¬†The original film was released in 1966, and as of 2023, Eastwood is 93 years old. The physical demands of the role, including action sequences and horseback riding, would be extremely challenging for someone of his age. Furthermore, the concept of time and aging in film remakes typically doesn‚Äôt allow for actors to reprise roles from decades earlier, especially when the character‚Äôs age is a significant factor in the story. A remake or reboot would likely require a younger actor to play the role of Blondie.‚Äù

Complete output with the tags mentioned above.


### Overall Performance Summary


Both Reflection 70B and ChatGPT-4o performed exceptionally well across all evaluated categories, achieving perfect scores in each. Reflection 70B‚Äôs *Reflection tuning* gives it a slight edge in multi-step reasoning scenarios, but the overall performance gap between the two models was negligible in this evaluation.


### Technical Specifications


Key features of Reflection 70B include:- 70.6 billion parameters- Full LLaMA context length support (around 128k tokens)- Recommended sampling parameters: temperature of 0.7 and top_p of 0.95- Custom system prompt for optimal performance


### Token Usage and Efficiency


The model generates 1.5 to 2 times more tokens for harder problems compared to standard models. While this may increase costs and latency, the team is betting on future improvements in inference speed to mitigate these issues.


### Future Developments


The team behind Reflection 70B has ambitious plans:- Releasing the training dataset and a detailed technical report (in a week from now)- Introducing a more powerful 405B version, expected to compete with top closed-source models- Exploring new prompting techniques that could be integrated into model training


### Community Impact


The release of Reflection 70B has generated significant interest in the AI community. Schumer‚Äôs announcement garnered significant reach, underscoring the growing appetite for powerful, accessible open-source AI models. And it is trending at Hugging Face at #1, with over 11k downloads

Source: Hugging Face website, as on September 9, 2024 (IST)

Reflection Llama-3.1 70B is an important step forward in open-source AI development. By combining innovative training techniques, collaborative efforts, and a commitment to transparency, this model pushes the boundaries of what‚Äôs possible in language AI. As Schumer, Chow, and their teams prepare to release more resources and an even more powerful version, the AI community eagerly anticipates the next chapter in this exciting journey of discovery and innovation.

### Hugging Face SMOL Agents for Local or Cloud: Building Intelligent Workflows


Introduction

Hugging Face‚Äôs SMOL Agents represent a paradigm shift in how large language models (LLMs) interact with the real world. Unlike traditional AI systems that follow rigid workflows, SMOL Agents are lightweight, code-first AI programs where LLM outputs dynamically control the execution flow. Built on a minimalist framework (~1,000 lines of core code), they prioritize simplicity, security, and flexibility, enabling developers to deploy agents that write and execute code to solve complex tasks.

Efficient AI systems require LLMs to interact with the real world, such as retrieving information or executing tasks, a concept called agency. This determines how much control LLMs have over workflows and evolves on a spectrum, from basic outputs to initiating complex multi-agent workflows.

Hugging Face‚Äôs SMOL Agents illustrate this by leveraging lightweight, secure, and flexible frameworks where LLM outputs dynamically drive execution.

These agents enable developers to deploy solutions for complex tasks by combining simplicity with powerful execution capabilities.

What Are SMOL¬†Agents?

SMOL Agents are multi-step AI systems that use LLMs to iteratively plan, execute, and refine actions. Key features include:
