title: (New) From Prompt Engineering to Context Engineering: Building Smarter AI Systems
content:
### (New) From Prompt Engineering to Context Engineering: Building Smarter AI¬†Systems


How the evolution from crafting prompts to architecting information ecosystems is reshaping AI development (once again)


### üéØ The Great Awakening


‚ÄúJust when you thought you had prompt engineering figured out‚Ä¶‚Äù

Remember in Inception when Dom Cobb thought he was just stealing secrets from dreams, only to discover he could actually architect entire dream worlds with multiple layers of reality? That‚Äôs exactly what happened to the AI community in 2024. While developers everywhere were perfecting their prompt-fu‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcrafting increasingly elaborate instructions like digital Shakespeare‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe real architects were quietly building something that made even the cleverest prompts look like sticky notes.

Enter Context Engineering: the art of architecting entire information ecosystems that make AI systems truly intelligent.

The Reel Revelation:

What‚Äôs Really Happening: Why industry leaders are calling it ‚Äúthe delicate art and science of filling the context window with just the right information.‚Äù How enterprises are moving beyond clever prompts to intelligent context orchestration. The fundamental shift from ‚Äúasking better questions‚Äù to ‚Äúcreating smarter and scalable environments.‚Äù

The Stakes: This isn‚Äôt just another buzzword evolution. Companies implementing context engineering are seeing significant improvements in AI performance, while those stuck in prompt-land are wondering why their systems still struggle with complex, real-world tasks.


### üìä The Great Shift‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäWhy Context Engineering Matters


The Limitations of Prompt Engineering

Traditional prompt engineering focuses on crafting the perfect instruction‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe right words, examples, and structure to guide an LLM‚Äôs behavior. It‚Äôs about optimizing that single text string you send to the model. And for simple tasks, it works brilliantly.

But here‚Äôs where it breaks down: Real-world AI applications aren‚Äôt simple tasks.

When you‚Äôre building a customer support system that needs to remember conversation history, access current product information, check user account status, and coordinate with external tools‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääsuddenly, your carefully crafted prompt is just one small piece of a much larger puzzle.

The context window challenge becomes apparent (even with increasing context windows across all Large Language models): you have limited space (tokens) to work with, and you need to fill it with the right information, not just more information.

Enter Context Engineering

Context engineering shifts the focus from prompt optimization to information ecosystem design. Instead of asking ‚ÄúHow do I phrase this request better?‚Äù we ask ‚ÄúWhat information, tools, and context does the AI need to succeed?‚Äù

The Core Components:

Real-World Impact

Consider KPMG‚Äôs implementation of AI agents across their enterprise. Rather than relying on prompt engineering alone, they built context-rich systems that integrate diverse data sources, maintain conversation history, and coordinate multiple specialized agents. The result? Standardized, scalable AI assistants that actually understand business context.

Or look at Caidera.ai‚Äôs life sciences marketing automation, where context engineering enables 70% faster campaign creation by intelligently orchestrating scientific documents, regulatory requirements, and market data into coherent marketing strategies.


### üèóÔ∏è The Architecture of Intelligence


Why Framework Choice¬†Matters

While context engineering principles can be implemented with any framework, some are better suited to this new paradigm than others. The key is finding tools that support:

Modern Context Engineering Features

Today‚Äôs leading frameworks provide sophisticated context management through:

Advanced Memory Systems:

Dynamic Workflows:

External Integration:

The goal isn‚Äôt to promote any specific tool, but to understand what capabilities enable effective context engineering in practice.


### üí° Context Engineering Techniques in¬†Practice


Core Techniques Breakdown

1. Intelligent Source Selection

Not all information is created equal. The first step in context engineering is analyzing the user‚Äôs query to determine which types of sources will be most valuable:

2. Context Ordering and Compression

Once you have relevant information, you need to rank and potentially compress it to fit within the context window:

3. Context Window Management

The context window is finite, so you need intelligent strategies for fitting information:

4. Multi-Source Data Coordination

Different data sources require different handling strategies:


### üõ†Ô∏è Building Blocks in Action‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäA Research Assistant Case¬†Study


What We‚Äôre¬†Building

Let‚Äôs examine a practical implementation that demonstrates context engineering principles: a multi-source research assistant that intelligently gathers, ranks, and synthesizes information from diverse sources.

The Challenge: Traditional approaches either rely on single sources (like Wikipedia) or dump everything into the context window hoping for the best. Neither approach works well for complex research queries.

The Context Engineering Solution: Build a system that:

Implementation Deep¬†Dive

Smart Document Handling:

Specialized Retrievers:

### The Road¬†Ahead


This field will continue evolving as we discover what works in different contexts and scales. The principles are solid, but the implementations will vary widely based on specific needs and constraints.

The transition from prompt engineering to context engineering represents more than just a new technique‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs a new way of thinking about AI system design. Instead of trying to pack everything into perfect instructions, we build intelligent environments that provide AI systems with what they need, when they need it.

Context engineering is still in its early days, but the foundational patterns are becoming clear. The next chapter will be written by practitioners who take these concepts and apply them to real-world challenges.

title: Experiencing the RASA: Building Powerful Conversational AI
content:
### Experiencing the RASA: Building Powerful Conversational AI


Designing Conversational Agents with Purpose, Presence, and Precision


### The Essence of ‚ÄòRasa‚Äô in AI and¬†Life


In Indian aesthetics, ‚Äúrasa‚Äù (‡§∞‡§∏) represents the emotional essence that creates connection between art and audience. This concept beautifully parallels what we aim to achieve with conversational AI‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcreating interactions that resonate beyond mere functionality.

Consider the 2001 Indian film ‚ÄúLagaan,‚Äù where diverse characters unite to overcome seemingly impossible odds. The cricket match becomes more than a game; it embodies determination, unity, and ultimately joy. Similarly, our conversational AI should blend technical components into an experience greater than the sum of its parts.

When we build AI assistants, we‚Äôre not just coding functionalities but crafting experiences. Each interaction should feel meaningful rather than mechanical. The user becomes the ‚Äúsah·πõdaya‚Äù (the sensitive spectator) who connects emotionally with the experience we‚Äôve designed.

This guide will take you through creating a spirituality assistant that demonstrates these principles, showing how technical implementation can deliver both function and feeling‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääfrom basic setup to sophisticated deployments that serve real human needs.


### The Rasa Ecosystem: Understanding Your¬†Tools


Rasa Open Source Foundation

Rasa Open Source forms the foundation of the ecosystem with widespread adoption across industries. This framework provides complete control over machine learning models and supports nearly 100 languages, making it accessible for global applications Rasa Open Source forms the foundation of the Rasa ecosystem. It is an open-source conversational AI platform that allows developers to understand user messages, hold contextual conversations, and connect to messaging channels and third-party systems. With over 25 million downloads, it‚Äôs the most popular open-source framework for building chat and voice-based AI assistants.

The architecture separates natural language understanding from dialogue management, allowing for customization at every level. You can connect your assistant to popular platforms including Facebook Messenger, Slack, and Telegram, extending reach across multiple channels Integration capabilities with popular messaging platforms including Facebook Messenger, Slack, Telegram, and others.

Rasa Pro Enhancements

Building on the open-source foundation, Rasa Pro introduces capabilities particularly relevant for enterprise applications:

The CALM architecture (Conversational AI with Language Models) enables integration with large language models for more contextual interactions CALM (Conversational AI with Language Models) which enables the use of large language models for more contextually aware and agentic interactions. This combines the creative potential of LLMs with the reliability of structured conversation flows.

Flow-based conversation management represents a shift from traditional approaches. Rather than scripting all possible conversation paths, you define business logic flows that handle tasks predictably while allowing natural conversation Flows for Business Logic that provide a simple and scalable way to implement the tasks your AI assistant can handle.

Security features prevent common issues like hallucination and prompt injection, maintaining consistency in business-critical applications Built-in security features that make it resistant to hallucination, prompt injection, and jailbreaking.

For developers and smaller teams, Rasa Pro Developer Edition offers free usage for up to 1000 conversations per month, providing enterprise features with an accessible entry point Rasa Pro is available in a Developer Edition that is free and allows you to run Rasa Pro locally and in production for up to 1000 conversations per month (or 100/month for internal assistants).

Development Environments

The ecosystem provides different interfaces for development and management:

Rasa X offers a low-code interface for reviewing conversations and improving your assistant through a graphical interface Rasa X/Enterprise is a low-code user interface that supports conversational AI teams reviewing and improving AI assistants at scale. It must be used with Rasa Pro.

Rasa Studio (invite only) provides a more comprehensive environment with web client interface, backend server, database management, user authentication, and event processing capabilities Rasa Studio is a newer component in the ecosystem that provides a more comprehensive development environment. It includes: a web client interface for user interaction, backend server for processing requests and managing data, database migration capabilities, user management through Keycloak, ingestion service for processing conversation events.

The Flow Builder in Rasa Studio presents an intuitive visual interface for creating business logic flows, accelerating development for teams Rasa Studio‚Äôs Flow Builder provides a visual, node-based interface with steps designed to help you quickly iterate on the logic in your assistant.


### Setting Up Your Conversational AI Environment


Installation Approaches

Starting your Rasa project begins with choosing the right installation method for your needs:

Quick installation with pip provides the simplest approach for individual developers:

This creates an isolated environment for your project and installs the core framework.

For Rasa Pro without local installation, GitHub Codespaces offers a cloud-based alternative:

This approach eliminates local setup and can facilitate team collaboration.

For macOS and Windows users, Multipass provides another option by creating Ubuntu instances:

This creates a consistent Linux environment regardless of host OS.

Project Structure Overview

After installation, initializing a new project with rasa init creates a directory structure with several key files:

Each file serves a specific purpose in your assistant‚Äôs architecture:

LLM Integration Configuration

For Rasa Pro projects using CALM, configuring LLM integration enhances natural language capabilities:

In config.yml, set up the LLM pipeline components:

Then configure your model groups in endpoints.yml:

This connects your assistant to external LLM capabilities while maintaining Rasa‚Äôs structured approach.


### Designing Conversation Flows and Business¬†Logic


Flow-Based Conversation Design

The flow paradigm represents a fundamental shift in how we design conversational interactions:

Flows define the business logic your assistant follows, organizing conversations around specific user goals rather than scripting every possible path.

A basic flow structure includes:

This example from our spirituality assistant demonstrates a meditation guidance flow:

This structured approach prevents hallucination while allowing natural conversation..

Custom Action Development

Custom actions extend your assistant‚Äôs capabilities beyond conversation:

Actions are Python functions that execute when triggered by a flow step:

This action retrieves personalized meditation suggestions based on user-provided information.

Custom actions can connect to databases, call external APIs, perform calculations, and integrate with other systems‚Ää‚Äî‚Äämaking your assistant truly useful in real-world contexts.

Conversation Pattern Management

Beyond the main flows, conversational patterns handle common interaction types:

Pattern flows handle chitchat, clarification requests, topic changes, and other everyday conversational elements:

These patterns ensure your assistant maintains natural conversation while staying on track with primary goals.

For clarification handling, responses should guide users back to the main conversational purpose without feeling abrupt or mechanical:

Testing Strategy

Effective testing ensures your assistant performs consistently:

End-to-end tests act as conversation blueprints that verify the assistant handles interactions correctly:

These tests confirm that new changes don‚Äôt break existing functionality.

Beyond technical testing, evaluate conversation quality from a user perspective:

Regular testing throughout development catches issues early and ensures a quality experience.


### Hands-On Project: A Simple Indian Spirituality Guide (A Taste of What Rasa Can¬†Do)


Project Conceptualization

Our basic spirituality assistant will serve as a guide to Indian spiritual concepts and practices:

The assistant‚Äôs capabilities include:

The personality should balance knowledgeability with approachability‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääauthoritative but not intimidating, approachable without being casual. Responses should convey respect for the traditions while making them accessible.

The knowledge domains span theoretical concepts, practical techniques, textual knowledge, and cultural context‚Ää‚Äî‚Äägiving users a comprehensive resource for their spiritual journey.

Technical Implementation

Let‚Äôs implement our assistant step by step:

First, we initialize with the CALM template to leverage LLM capabilities:

This creates a project structure optimized for LLM integration.

Next, set up OpenAI integration in your endpoints.yml:

This configures the external language models that enhance your assistant‚Äôs capabilities.

Now create the conversation flows in data/flows.yml:

Each flow corresponds to a specific user goal, with steps to collect necessary information and actions to fulfill the request.

Knowledge Base Development

The foundation of our assistant is a robust knowledge base:

Create a spirituality_data.py file with structured information:

This structured data powers the assistant‚Äôs responses, ensuring accurate and consistent information.

Helper functions retrieve appropriate information based on user queries:

These functions make the data accessible to custom actions during conversations.

Custom Action Implementation

Now implement the actions that will use your knowledge base:

This action retrieves concept information and formats it for the user, including related concepts they might explore next.

Similar actions would be implemented for meditation guidance, sacred text exploration, and spiritual practice instruction.


### Training and¬†Testing


With implementation complete, train and run your assistant:

Set up environment variables:

Train the model:

Run the action server and Rasa server:

Now test with example conversations:

Concept exploration:

Meditation guidance:

These conversations demonstrate the assistant‚Äôs ability to provide personalized, contextual responses based on user needs.

Code Repository (Sample Project)

This simple project is designed to offer a taste of Rasa‚Äôs capabilities‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääenough to illustrate the framework‚Äôs power and flexibility, without venturing into full-scale production complexity.


### Real-World Applications and Deployment


Industry Applications

The techniques demonstrated in our spirituality guide apply across diverse sectors:

Financial services can implement assistants that handle complex workflows like account management and money transfers. For example, a transaction assistant might handle a conversation like:

This requires proper validation, security, and integration with banking systems.

Customer service applications benefit from personalized support that recognizes user context. A product return assistant might say:

This contextual awareness improves the customer experience by reducing friction.

Enterprise knowledge management leverages Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) to access company information. This allows assistants to answer questions like ‚ÄúHow do I reset my password?‚Äù by finding relevant documents and generating answers without coding every possible Q&A flow.

Multilingual applications detect user language preferences and respond appropriately:

This personalization extends beyond translation to include cultural adaptation.

Voice-based implementations handle spoken conversations including pauses, turn-taking, and phone-specific capabilities like DTMF processing, integrating with contact center systems to automate call operations.


### Deployment Strategies


For production deployment, several options ensure reliability and scalability:

Development to production pipeline progresses through environments:

Kubernetes orchestration provides scalable infrastructure:

This configuration enables automatic scaling as user load increases.

Monitoring and analytics track conversation metrics:

These insights drive continuous improvement of your assistant.

Security implementation ensures data protection:

Channel integration extends reach across platforms:

By combining these deployment practices with the development techniques we‚Äôve explored, you can create conversational AI that delivers both technical function and emotional resonance‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe true ‚Äúrasa‚Äù of AI interaction.

Like the villagers in ‚ÄúLagaan‚Äù who transformed from disparate individuals into a unified team capable of victory against overwhelming odds, the components of your Rasa assistant should work together to create something greater than the sum of its parts. And just as the film‚Äôs conclusion brought satisfaction to both characters and audience, a well-crafted conversational AI creates that same sense of resolution and delight for its users‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe essence of ‚Äúrasa‚Äù in both Indian aesthetics and modern technology.

title: AI Interactions Explored: Insights and ChatGPT Analysis Guide
content:
### AI Interactions Explored: Insights and ChatGPT Analysis¬†Guide


Part 1: Gleaning Personal Insights from ChatGPT Conversations

Personal Dialogues with AI as a Mirror

The advent of AI conversation platforms like ChatGPT has not only revolutionized interaction dynamics but also opened new avenues for introspection and personal development. When one‚Äôs dialogues with an AI like ChatGPT are exported, typically as JSON files, they serve as more than just a log of exchanges. These conversations reflect one‚Äôs approach to interacting with AI, revealing patterns, preferences, and areas of focus.

Personal Interactions as a Source of Analysis

1. Rich, Personalized Data: Each conversation in a ChatGPT export encapsulates a user‚Äôs specific inquiries, responses received, and contextual details. This personalized dataset is ripe for introspection and understanding one‚Äôs interaction style.

2. Reflecting User‚Äôs Interests and Inquiries: The variety of topics addressed in these conversations mirrors the user‚Äôs intellectual curiosities, problem-solving approaches, and even creative endeavors.

3. Real-Time, Authentic Interactions: Unlike hypothetical scenarios, these real-time exchanges offer genuine insights into how one engages with AI, from query formulation to response interpretation.

Types of Analysis for Self-Reflection

1. Conversation Pattern Analysis: Identifying recurring themes or subjects, which can reveal a user‚Äôs dominant areas of interest or concern.

2. Sentiment Analysis: Understanding the emotional undertones of one‚Äôs queries and AI‚Äôs responses, offering a window into the user‚Äôs emotional engagement with the technology.

3. Temporal Analysis: Observing how the frequency and nature of interactions evolve over time, which might reflect changing interests or learning patterns.

4. Topic Modeling: Using NLP to unearth latent topics in conversations, providing insights into the breadth and depth of the user‚Äôs interactions.

5. Query Classification: Categorizing the nature of queries (informational, transactional, instructional) to understand the user‚Äôs predominant modes of AI engagement.

6. Response Time Analysis: Evaluating the promptness of AI responses in various contexts, which can inform the user‚Äôs expectations and satisfaction with AI interactions.

The export of one‚Äôs ChatGPT conversations is a unique and personal dataset that offers a multifaceted view of one‚Äôs engagement with AI. By analyzing these conversations, we can gain valuable insights into our own patterns of thinking, questioning, and learning.

Part 2: Analyzing ‚Äòmodel_comparisons.json‚Äô‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäInsights from My Personal ChatGPT Interactions

Dissecting Personal AI Dialogues

In this analysis, we delve into ‚Äòmodel_comparisons.json‚Äô, a file documenting my own conversations with ChatGPT. This exploration aims to objectively understand and infer patterns and tendencies in my interactions with AI.

Key Inferences from AI Interaction Data

1. Diverse Subject Matters: The file reveals a range of topics in my queries, from AI and technology to storytelling. This suggests a wide-ranging curiosity and an exploratory approach in my conversations with AI.

2. Overall Positive Engagement: Sentiment analysis points to a predominantly positive tone in these dialogues. This could indicate effective communication or an alignment of AI responses with my inquiries.

3. Variety in Query Types: The data shows a mix of informational, transactional, and instructional queries. This diversity might reflect a multi-dimensional use of AI for different purposes, from seeking information to requesting specific tasks.

4. Complex Queries and Deeper Insights: Further analysis of the ‚ÄòOther‚Äô category in my queries uncovers a tendency towards complex, advisory, and opinion-seeking interactions. This indicates a propensity to engage AI in more nuanced and detailed discussions.

5. Contextual Variability in AI Responses: A comparative look at AI responses to similar queries shows variability, suggesting that the AI‚Äôs replies are tailored to the perceived context and nuances of each query.

Visual Insights into AI Engagement

This visualization would highlight frequent themes in my queries, offering a visual summary of the topics I commonly explore.

. Engagement Trends Over Time:

Graphs illustrating the frequency of my queries over time, which might reveal patterns or shifts in my engagement with ChatGPT.

. Topic Distribution Overview:

Charts showing the range of topics in my conversations, visually quantifying the breadth of my interactions.

. Response Time Dynamics:

A histogram highlighting the variation in AI‚Äôs response times, which could provide insights into the interaction flow and response efficiency.

Consolidated overiew of insights and User Query Types Analysis based on the clustering and classification.

Part 3: Integrating General Analysis and Personal Case Study‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäUnderstanding the Benefits of AI Interaction Analysis

Bringing Together Broad Insights and Specific Examples

The journey through the analytical landscape of AI conversations, as detailed in Parts 1 and 2, provides a decent understanding of how one can benefit from examining their interactions with AI. Part 1 established a general framework for analyzing ChatGPT data, while Part 2 delved into a specific example, my own interactions documented in ‚Äòmodel_comparisons.json‚Äô. Together, these parts illustrate the broader benefits of such analysis.

Conclusions from Generic Analysis and Personal Example

1. Insights into Interaction Patterns: The general analysis in Part 1, combined with the specific insights from Part 2, demonstrate how diverse and varied one‚Äôs engagement with AI can be, spanning multiple topics and inquiry types.

2. Understanding Personal Engagement Style: The deep dive into ‚Äòmodel_comparisons.json‚Äô provided a personal example of how such analysis can reveal individual communication styles, preferences, and areas of interest in AI interactions.

3. Reflecting on AI‚Äôs Versatility and Adaptability: The varied responses from AI to similar queries, as seen in the case study, underscore the AI‚Äôs ability to tailor responses, adapting to the nuances of each user‚Äôs queries.

4. Visualizing Data for Enhanced Understanding: The visualizations presented offer a clear and accessible way to comprehend complex interaction data, reinforcing the importance of visual tools in data analysis.

5. Synthesizing Insights:

Broad Implications and Personal Growth

The combination of a generic analytical approach and a specific case study demonstrates the value of scrutinizing AI interactions. For individuals, such analysis can lead to a deeper understanding of their engagement patterns, revealing preferences and tendencies in their queries and responses.

For AI developers and researchers, this approach provides valuable feedback for improving AI models, ensuring they better meet user needs and preferences. It highlights the importance of contextual understanding and adaptability in AI responses.

Step-by-Step Guide to Analyzing Your ChatGPT Plus Conversations Using ChatGPT Plus with Example¬†Prompts

Step 1: Uploading Your ChatGPT Plus Data- Upload ‚Äòmodel_comparisons.json‚Äô into ChatGPT Plus.- Example Prompt: ‚ÄúPlease read and analyze the structure of this uploaded JSON file containing my conversation data.‚Äù

Step 2: Extracting Key Information- Ask ChatGPT Plus to organize essential data like queries, responses, and timestamps.- Example Prompt: ‚ÄúCan you extract and organize my queries, your responses, and the timestamps from this JSON file?‚Äù

Step 3: Conversation Pattern Recognition- Instruct ChatGPT Plus to identify recurring themes.- Example Prompt: ‚ÄúIdentify the common themes or topics in my conversations from this data.‚Äù

Step 4: Sentiment Analysis- Request sentiment analysis of the conversations.- Example Prompt: ‚ÄúPerform a sentiment analysis on these conversations and categorize them as positive, negative, or neutral.‚Äù

Step 5: Analyzing Interaction Over Time- Use ChatGPT Plus to analyze interaction patterns based on timestamps.- Example Prompt: ‚ÄúAnalyze the timestamps to determine my interaction patterns and peak engagement times.‚Äù

Step 6: Topic Modeling- Ask ChatGPT Plus to apply NLP for topic discovery.- Example Prompt: ‚ÄúApply NLP techniques to uncover the latent topics discussed in my interactions.‚Äù

Step 7: Query Categorization- Have ChatGPT Plus categorize your queries.- Example Prompt: ‚ÄúClassify my queries into informational, transactional, or instructional types.‚Äù

Step 8: Comparative Response Analysis- Prompt ChatGPT Plus to compare its responses to similar queries.- Example Prompt: ‚ÄúCompare your responses to similar queries in this data to observe how they vary.‚Äù

Step 9: Generating Visualizations- Discuss data format for external visualization.- Example Prompt: ‚ÄúOrganize the data for sentiment analysis and interaction trends in a format suitable for external visualization.‚Äù

Step 10: Synthesizing Insights- Ask ChatGPT Plus for a comprehensive overview.- Example Prompt: ‚ÄúCan you synthesize the findings from this analysis to provide an overview of my interaction patterns and insights?‚Äù

Future Directions and Continuous Learning

This detailed analysis suggests a future where personal AI interaction data is regularly examined for insights into learning styles, communication strategies, and intellectual interests. It opens avenues for continuous personal growth and informed engagement with AI technologies.

The exploration of AI interaction data, both in a broad sense and through personal examples, offers a window into the multifaceted relationship between humans and AI. It stands as a testament to the power of data analysis in enhancing our understanding of technology and ourselves.

title: The Prompt Engineering Plot Twist: Why AI Agents Actually Made Us More Important
content:
### The Prompt Engineering Plot Twist: Why AI Agents Actually Made Us More Important


From spellcasting to system design in 2025: prompt engineering has leveled¬†up


### The Great AI Agent¬†Paradox


When ‚ÄúAutonomous‚Äù Still Needs a GPS

So here‚Äôs the thing nobody saw coming. The year everyone thought AI agents would kill off prompt engineering, turned out to be the year prompt engineering became more crucial than ever.

Picture this: You‚Äôve got this brilliant intern who just walked into your office. But you tell them ‚Äúhandle the Johnson project‚Äù without bothering to mention whether you‚Äôre talking about a corporate merger or next quarter‚Äôs marketing campaign. What happens? They‚Äôll optimize brilliantly‚Ä¶ for completely the wrong thing.

That‚Äôs basically what happened with AI agents in 2024‚Äì2025.

Here‚Äôs what actually went down:

The companies building the most advanced AI agents are hiring prompt engineers faster than you can say ‚Äúchain-of-thought.‚Äù Even weirder? Every single major AI company is pushing agent capabilities while simultaneously doubling down on prompt engineering tools and education.

What started as simple Q&A with ChatGPT has morphed into something that looks a lot like the early days of programming. Complete with frameworks, best practices, and people arguing about methodology on X.

This analysis is based on developments through mid-2025, combining verified industry data with emerging market signals and early-stage trends.


### The Technical Shift Nobody Talks¬†About


From ‚ÄúPlease Write Code‚Äù to ‚ÄúOrchestrate My Digital Workforce‚Äù

Tthe prompt engineering scene in 2025 is basically unrecognizable from those early ‚Äúwrite me a poem about cats‚Äù days. We‚Äôve gone from throwing spaghetti at the wall to actual engineering discipline. (The term prompt engineering was in the vogue though, but it meant so many things)

The trends we‚Äôre witnessing through 2024‚Äì2025 (and they‚Äôre remarkable):

The result? Prompt engineers are graduating from writing one-off instructions to building prompt architectures‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcomprehensive systems that orchestrate roles, guardrails, structured outputs, reasoning pipelines, and validations.

Further, it‚Äôs not enough to write a good prompt‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääyou have to know if it works. That‚Äôs why prompt evaluation platforms like Arize, Langfuse, and PromptLayer have become essential infrastructure for AI teams. These tools log every interaction, evaluate prompt outputs based on performance metrics (e.g. helpfulness, factual accuracy, tone), and identify failure patterns for systematic refinement.

Here‚Äôs the evolution in a nutshell:

The difference? We stopped asking AI to do things and started training AI teammates.


### Meta-Prompting: When AI Learns to Talk to¬†Itself


The Self-Improving Revolution That‚Äôs Actually Working

Meta-prompting is basically prompts writing prompts. Sounds recursive and confusing? It is. But it also works incredibly well.

Think of it as ‚Äúprompt folding‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääone prompt can dynamically create better versions of itself. Instead of you sitting there rewriting prompts every time they fail (and we‚Äôve all been there), you feed the failures back into the LLM and ask it to fix the original prompt.

It‚Äôs like having an AI that can complain about your unclear instructions and then fix them for you.


### How This Actually Works in¬†Practice


The basic template that everyone‚Äôs using now:

Real example from customer support optimization: You start with something useless like ‚ÄúHelp customers with their problems.‚Äù The meta-prompt transforms this into a comprehensive system covering acknowledgment protocols, problem diagnosis steps, solution frameworks, escalation criteria, response tone guidelines, and specific formatting requirements.

This isn‚Äôt theoretical anymore. Companies are building production systems that literally rewrite themselves to handle edge cases better.


### What Y Combinator Startups Are Actually¬†Building


How This Plays Out in the Real World

The Y Combinator ecosystem gives us a perfect window into how this stuff actually works when money‚Äôs on the line. These aren‚Äôt academic experiments‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthey‚Äôre real companies solving real problems.

Some of the patterns emerging:

The framework that‚Äôs becoming standard: Everyone‚Äôs converging on something called RTCE (Role, Task, Context, Expectation). Here‚Äôs what a real one looks like:

This isn‚Äôt just ‚Äúbe more specific.‚Äù It‚Äôs systematic instruction design.


### Where the Enterprise Money Is Actually¬†Going


Because Nobody Gets Promoted for Cute Haikus

While everyone was debating whether prompt engineering had a future, enterprise teams were quietly building it into their core infrastructure. And the numbers don‚Äôt lie.

The money trail tells the story:


### Industry-Specific Reality¬†Checks


Healthcare compliance isn‚Äôt messing around:

These aren‚Äôt simple chatbots. These are mission-critical systems handling billions of dollars.


### Building Systems That Know When They Don‚Äôt¬†Know


The Escape Hatch Revolution

Here‚Äôs something that took way too long to figure out: AI systems need structured ways to admit they‚Äôre confused.

The basic version everyone should be using:

But the advanced systems go further:

This last part is ingenious. The AI can basically complain to developers about confusing instructions and create a to-do list for system improvements. It‚Äôs like having a really patient employee who documents every time your instructions don‚Äôt make sense.


### Why Agents Made Everything Harder (And Way More Valuable)


The Orchestration Challenge Nobody Saw Coming

Autonomous agents don‚Äôt eliminate the need for human guidance‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthey turn it into strategic orchestration.

There are actually four different levels of this game:

Multi-agent coordination needs sophisticated prompting at every single level. You‚Äôre dealing with role definition, reasoning methods, constraint handling, escalation protocols, and edge case management across integrated systems.

It‚Äôs like conducting a symphony where every musician is incredibly talented but needs very specific sheet music.


### The Secret Sauce: Evaluation-Driven Development


How Production AI Actually Gets Built

The real competitive advantage for AI companies isn‚Äôt their prompts‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs their evaluation frameworks. The systems that measure and improve AI performance systematically.

What a real evaluation framework looks like: You‚Äôre typically measuring accuracy (factual correctness), helpfulness (relevance to user needs), tone (professional and appropriate), and completeness (addressing all aspects of the inquiry). With scoring systems that automatically flag responses below quality thresholds for human review.

The improvement cycle that actually works: Generate responses, evaluate performance against established criteria, identify failure patterns, use meta-prompts to address weaknesses while maintaining strengths, rinse and repeat until you hit target performance metrics.

This is why some companies‚Äô AI systems keep getting better while others plateau. It‚Äôs not the initial prompt‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs the improvement machinery.


### The ‚ÄúLazy Prompting‚Äù vs. Detailed Engineering Debate


When Context Actually Matters

Andrew Ng‚Äôs ‚Äúlazy prompting‚Äù philosophy has been making the rounds, and it‚Äôs sparked some interesting debates. The research shows prompt engineering sessions average 43.3 minutes with highly iterative refinement‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhich suggests even ‚Äúlazy‚Äù prompts evolve into detailed ones through iteration.

About context:

The choice isn‚Äôt really about lazy vs. detailed. It‚Äôs about matching your approach to your constraints and consequences.


### Your Roadmap for Actually Succeeding in¬†2025


Skills That Matter When Money‚Äôs on the Line

The evidence is pretty clear at this point: prompt engineering isn‚Äôt disappearing‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs professionalizing. With the market in heading toward $25.63 billion by 2034 (that‚Äôs a 27.86% compound annual growth rate), the opportunity is real.

If you‚Äôre building individual skills, here‚Äôs what experts suggest:

If you‚Äôre building team capabilities: Modern prompt engineering workflows treat prompts like code‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwith version control, automated testing, performance monitoring, and optimization engines that systematically improve performance over time.

If you‚Äôre running an organization:

The skills that‚Äôll matter most in 2025‚Äì2027:


### Conclusion: We‚Äôre Building the Language of the¬†Future


The transformation of prompt engineering from craft to engineering discipline represents something bigger than just another tech trend. We‚Äôre fundamentally changing how humans and machines work together.

The parallels to early software development are pretty striking‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe tools are evolving fast, the possibilities seem endless, and nobody‚Äôs entirely sure where the boundaries are yet.

Prompt engineering isn‚Äôt just a technical skill anymore‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs becoming the fundamental language of human-AI collaboration (as it‚Äôs always been).

The bottom line: We‚Äôre not just prompt engineers anymore. We‚Äôre the architects of human-AI collaboration. And in 2025, with agents becoming integral to business operations, that‚Äôs exactly where the biggest opportunities are.


### Thank you for being a part of the community

title: From Model Specs to Project Specs: The Complete Guide to Specification-Driven AI Development
content:
### From Model Specs to Project Specs: The Complete Guide to Specification-Driven AI Development



### The Missing Blueprint


Picture this: Your AI project started with enthusiasm, had a capable team, adequate funding, and executive support. Six months later, it‚Äôs struggling to meet basic requirements, stakeholders are confused about what‚Äôs being built, and the team is frantically rewriting prompts hoping something will click. Sound familiar?

Here‚Äôs the shocking truth: According to Gartner‚Äôs 2023 AI Hype Cycle report, 60‚Äì70% of AI projects fail to deliver business value, with MIT Sloan Management Review (2022) finding that 67% of AI initiatives fail to scale beyond pilot stage. But here‚Äôs what‚Äôs remarkable‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthese failures aren‚Äôt due to technical limitations. They‚Äôre missing the one thing that made OpenAI‚Äôs o1 actually work.

It‚Äôs not the model architecture, the training data, or even the compute power. It‚Äôs the specification methodology.

When OpenAI released their Model Spec research, they revealed something profound: the secret wasn‚Äôt just teaching models to reason‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit was teaching them to reason over explicit specifications. But here‚Äôs what most people missed: this isn‚Äôt just about language models. It‚Äôs about a fundamental approach to building any AI system that actually works.

The revelation is simple yet revolutionary: It‚Äôs not about the model‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs about the specification methodology. And this methodology can transform how we build any AI project, from simple automation scripts to complex enterprise systems.


### I. The Great Shift: From Model-Centric to Project-Centric Specifications



### Beyond the Model¬†Boundary


When most people read about OpenAI‚Äôs Model Spec, they see it as documentation for how AI models should behave. But look deeper, and you‚Äôll realize something extraordinary: OpenAI‚Äôs Model Spec is actually a Project Specification in disguise.

Consider what the Model Spec really contains:

Sound familiar? These are the exact elements every successful AI project needs, regardless of whether you‚Äôre building a chatbot, a recommendation system, or an automated decision-making platform.

The anatomy of AI project failure always follows the same pattern:

OpenAI solved this by creating a specification that serves as the single source of truth for all stakeholders‚Ää‚Äî‚Äätechnical and non-technical alike. The Model Spec isn‚Äôt just instructions for an AI; it‚Äôs a contract between all parties about what success looks like.


### The Universal Project Spec Framework


Here‚Äôs where it gets exciting: we can adapt deliberative alignment principles to any AI initiative. The key insight from the research paper is that teaching systems to ‚Äúreason over learned specifications‚Äù works because specifications become the authoritative context for all decision-making.

For AI projects, this translates into three fundamental pillars:

1. Intent Definition: Just as the Model Spec captures OpenAI‚Äôs intentions for model behavior, your project spec must capture stakeholder intentions for project outcomes. This isn‚Äôt just writing requirements‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs creating a living document that stakeholders can reference, debate, and evolve together.

2. Context Architecture: The research shows that models perform better when they have the right context at the right time. Similarly, AI projects succeed when all team members have access to the right information, constraints, and decision-making frameworks when they need them.

3. Evaluation Criteria: OpenAI includes challenging prompt sets with their Model Spec to test adherence. Your project spec must include specific, measurable criteria that can validate whether your AI system is meeting its intended goals.

But here‚Äôs the crucial difference: we‚Äôre not just doing context engineering for prompts anymore. We‚Äôre doing System Context Engineering‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääarchitecting information flow across your entire AI project to ensure every decision, from data collection to user interface design, aligns with your core specifications.


### II. The Project Specification Architecture



### The Complete Specification Stack


Drawing from both the Model Spec structure and successful project implementations, every AI project needs a four-layer specification architecture:

Project Overview Layer This is your project‚Äôs equivalent to the Model Spec‚Äôs principles section. It includes:

Imagine this scenario: A team is tasked with building an email summarization tool. Instead of ‚Äúsummarize emails better,‚Äù the specification would read:

Technical Specification Layer This translates business intent into technical requirements:

Evaluation Specification Layer Just as the Model Spec includes challenging test cases, your project spec must define:

Maintenance Specification Layer The living document approach requires:


### Making Specifications Executable


The breakthrough insight from deliberative alignment research is that specifications aren‚Äôt just documentation‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthey‚Äôre executable knowledge that guides every decision in your project.

Consider this challenge scenario: Building an AI system to extract management lessons from films. Stakeholders initially agree on scope, but what happens when edge cases emerge during development?

Traditional approach: Discover these issues during testing:

This leads to scope creep, delayed timelines, and frustrated stakeholders.

Specification-driven approach: Define edge cases upfront in the specification:

This isn‚Äôt just documentation‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs executable logic that developers can implement directly. Every edge case, every decision point, every evaluation criterion is spelled out clearly enough that any team member can make consistent decisions.

Version Control for Intentions

One of the most powerful aspects of the Model Spec approach is treating specifications as living code. Just as OpenAI versions their Model Spec and tracks changes, your project specifications must evolve without losing alignment.

This means:

The result? Requirements that evolve intelligently instead of drifting chaotically.


### III. Implementation Playbook: Specification-Driven Development



### The Three-Phase Implementation


Phase 1: Stakeholder Alignment through Living Documentation

This phase adapts the Model Spec‚Äôs collaborative creation process to your project context. Instead of technical teams guessing what business stakeholders want, you create specifications together.

Week 1‚Äì2: Collaborative Specification Creation

Scenario example: In our email summarizer project, the initial stakeholder meeting reveals conflicting requirements:

Without specifications: Teams would build separate solutions, leading to integration nightmares. With specification-driven approach: The specification process reveals these aren‚Äôt contradictory requirements but different success criteria requiring layered solutions defined upfront.

Week 3‚Äì4: Specification Validation

Phase 2: Development with Specification Guardrails

Here‚Äôs where the deliberative alignment methodology really shines. Instead of building first and hoping it matches requirements, every development decision references the specification.

Sprint Planning with Specifications

Continuous Specification Validation

Phase 3: Continuous Alignment and Specification Evolution

The Model Spec‚Äôs ‚Äúliving document‚Äù approach becomes your project‚Äôs secret weapon for handling changing requirements without losing coherence.

Specification Evolution Process

Performance Monitoring Against Specifications


### Industry-Specific Adaptations


Enterprise AI Projects: Compliance and Governance

Enterprise AI projects need specifications that address regulatory compliance, data governance, and organizational policies. The Model Spec‚Äôs approach to ‚Äústaying in bounds‚Äù becomes critical here.

Key adaptations:

Consumer Applications: User Experience and Privacy

Consumer-facing AI systems require specifications that prioritize user experience and privacy protection, similar to how the Model Spec emphasizes being ‚Äúapproachable‚Äù and protecting user interests.

Key adaptations:

Research Systems: Reproducibility and Validation

Research AI systems need specifications that ensure reproducibility and scientific validity, echoing the Model Spec‚Äôs commitment to truth-seeking and accuracy.

Key adaptations:


### IV. Advanced Patterns: Scaling Specification Engineering



### Multi-Project Specification Ecosystems


As organizations mature in specification-driven development, they discover something powerful: specifications can inherit from and build upon each other, just like code libraries.

Specification Inheritance

Consider a company building multiple AI-powered customer service tools. Instead of recreating specifications from scratch, they can establish:

Base Customer Service AI Specification

Project-Specific Specifications

Cross-Project Dependencies

Advanced organizations create specification ecosystems where projects reference and depend on each other‚Äôs specifications:

Building Organizational Specification Standards

The most mature implementations create company-wide specification frameworks that capture organizational values, compliance requirements, and technical standards. This becomes the organization‚Äôs equivalent to OpenAI‚Äôs Model Spec‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa document that defines how all AI systems should behave within that context.


### Tools and Automation


Specification Management Platforms

Just as software development has evolved sophisticated tools for code management, specification-driven development needs dedicated platforms for specification management:

Automated Compliance Checking

Drawing inspiration from how the Model Spec includes automated evaluation prompts, advanced implementations include:

AI-Assisted Specification Creation

The future of specification engineering includes AI tools that help create better specifications:


### V. Measuring Success: The New KPIs for AI¬†Projects



### Specification-Centric Metrics


Traditional AI project metrics focus on technical performance: accuracy, response time, throughput. But specification-driven development requires new metrics that measure alignment between implementation and intent.

Alignment Scores: How Well Implementation Matches Specification Intent

This is your project‚Äôs equivalent to the Model Spec‚Äôs evaluation against challenging prompt sets. Key metrics include:

Project Velocity Improvements Through Specification Clarity

Well-written specifications dramatically improve development speed by reducing ambiguity and rework:

Quality Indicators: Defect Rates, Rework Frequency, Scope Creep

Specification-driven development should significantly improve project quality metrics:


### ROI of Specification-Driven Development


Cost Reduction Through Fewer Failed Projects and Less Rework

Based on industry case studies and organizational reports, specification-driven development delivers:

Time to Market Acceleration Through Specification Clarity

When everyone understands what‚Äôs being built, development accelerates:

Competitive Advantage Through Superior AI Project Execution

Organizations mastering specification-driven development gain sustainable competitive advantages:


### VI. Framework Comparison and Future¬†Horizons



### How Specification-Driven Development Relates to Existing Methodologies


Understanding where this approach fits within existing frameworks helps organizations implement it effectively:

vs. Agile Development

vs. DevOps Practices

vs. Traditional Waterfall

vs. Design Thinking


### Specification-Native Organizations


The most successful AI organizations of the future will be ‚Äúspecification-native‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbuilt from the ground up around specification-driven development principles.

Cultural Transformation: Moving from Ad-Hoc to Specification-Driven Development

This transformation touches every aspect of how organizations approach AI:

Leadership Changes

Team Structure Changes

Process Changes

Skill Development and Team Structuring Around Specification Excellence

Organizations need new skills and roles to excel at specification-driven development:

New Role: Specification Engineer

Enhanced Existing Roles

Training Programs

The Paradigm Shift: ‚ÄúSpecify First, Build Right‚Äù

The future belongs to organizations that embrace ‚Äúspecify first, build right‚Äù as their core development philosophy. This means:


### Emerging Horizons


AI-Assisted Specification Creation and Real-Time Validation

The next frontier involves using AI to create better AI project specifications:

Intelligent Specification Generation

Real-Time Specification Validation

Specification Marketplaces for Sharing Proven Patterns

As specification-driven development matures, we‚Äôll see the emergence of specification marketplaces where organizations can share and reuse proven specification patterns:

Regulatory Compliance Through Specifications

Government and industry regulators are beginning to recognize that specification-driven development offers a path to AI governance and compliance:


### Conclusion: The Specification Revolution


We stand at an inflection point in AI development. The traditional approach‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbuild first, figure out requirements later‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääsimply doesn‚Äôt scale to the complexity and importance of modern AI systems. OpenAI‚Äôs Model Spec research shows us a better way, but its implications extend far beyond language models.

The paradigm shift from ‚Äúbuild first, figure out later‚Äù to ‚Äúspecify first, build right‚Äù represents the maturation of AI development from craft to engineering discipline. Just as civil engineers don‚Äôt build bridges without detailed specifications, AI engineers shouldn‚Äôt build intelligent systems without clear, executable specifications that capture stakeholder intent.

The evidence is compelling: organizations that embrace specification-driven development deliver more successful AI projects, reduce costs, accelerate time to market, and build sustainable competitive advantages. They create AI systems that actually solve the problems they‚Äôre intended to solve.

Your next AI project is an opportunity. You can continue with traditional approaches and accept the industry‚Äôs high failure rate, or you can implement specification-driven development and join the growing community of organizations building AI systems that actually work.

The choice is clear. The methodology is proven. The framework is available.

The only question is: Will you specify first, or will you be left behind?

Ready to explore specification-driven development for your organization? I‚Äôm actively working with teams to develop practical specification templates and implementation guides. Contact me to discuss creating specification frameworks tailored to your specific AI initiatives and to join the growing community of practitioners pioneering this approach.

title: Gemini 2.0 Flash Native Image Generation‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäA Beginner‚Äôs Guide
content:
### Gemini 2.0 Flash Native Image Generation‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäA Beginner‚Äôs Guide


Creating New Ties Between Text and Visual¬†AI

Google has recently expanded access to one of its most anticipated AI capabilities: native image generation in Gemini 2.0 Flash. Previously limited to trusted testers, this feature is now available for developer experimentation across all regions supported by Google AI Studio. Developers can access this experimental version (gemini-2.0-flash-exp) through both Google AI Studio and via the Gemini API.

What sets Gemini 2.0 Flash apart is its unique combination of multimodal input processing, enhanced reasoning capabilities, and natural language understanding. Unlike traditional text-to-image generators, Gemini 2.0 Flash can comprehend complex instructions, maintain contextual awareness across multiple interactions (branching included), and generate images that demonstrate understanding of both visual elements and world knowledge.

For developers seeking to create more engaging applications with visual elements, this release represents a good opportunity to explore new possibilities without requiring multiple specialized models or complex integrations.

The ability to generate both text and images from a single model streamlines development workflows and opens doors to more intuitive user experiences.

Key Features & Capabilities

Text and Image Integration

Gemini 2.0 Flash excels at creating illustrated narratives where text and images work together seamlessly. When asked to tell a story, the model can generate accompanying illustrations that maintain consistent characters and settings throughout the narrative. This makes it particularly valuable for creating children‚Äôs stories, educational content, or marketing materials.

While it will not deliver the final result, it sure can help in creating an outline or sort of a pre-viz. In my experiments with the Google AI Studio, I created a storybook based on Panchatantra tales, with the model successfully generating translating the overall story idea into consistent animal characters across multiple scenes while maintaining the moral themes central to these traditional stories. The characters‚Äô appearances remained recognizable from one image to the next, demonstrating the model‚Äôs ability to maintain visual continuity.

Conversational Image Editing

One of the most powerful aspects of Gemini 2.0 Flash is its ability to engage in multi-turn conversations about image creation and modification (including branching). Unlike systems that require precise, technical prompts for each generation, Gemini allows for natural language feedback and progressive refinement.

In one test, I uploaded a personal photo and engaged in a conversation to change the color of my shirt (and then the tie). The model understood which element of the image to modify, preserved the original details and lighting, and allowed me to try different colors through simple conversational requests. This iterative approach feels more natural and accessible than traditional image editing tools, especially for users without technical expertise.

World Knowledge and Enhanced Reasoning

Gemini 2.0 Flash leverages its extensive training to create images that demonstrate an understanding of how the world works. This makes it particularly effective at generating realistic imagery for practical applications like recipe illustrations, where ingredients, cooking techniques, and cultural contexts all need to be accurately represented.

While the model‚Äôs knowledge is broad and generally accurate, it isn‚Äôt absolute or complete. Like all language models, it has limitations and may occasionally produce inaccuracies. Nevertheless, its reasoning capabilities allow it to connect concepts and create imagery that reflects logical relationships between elements. Once again, it does serve as a good starting point.

Text Rendering Capabilities

One area where Gemini 2.0 Flash particularly shines is in accurate text rendering within images (Example, the cover image for this article). Many image generation models struggle with this task, often producing illegible characters, poor formatting, or misspellings. According to Google‚Äôs internal benchmarks, Gemini 2.0 Flash outperforms leading competitive models in this area.

This capability makes the model especially valuable for creating advertisements, social media graphics, invitations, or any other content where text must be clearly legible and properly formatted within an image. The ability to generate both visual elements and accurately rendered text in a single operation streamlines workflows that would otherwise require multiple tools.

Technical Implementation

Getting started with Gemini 2.0 Flash requires a Google AI Studio account and an API key. The API follows RESTful principles and uses standard HTTP methods for requests and responses. Authentication is handled via the API key, which should be included in the request header or as specified in the Google AI documentation.

The experimental version is accessed using the model name ‚Äúgemini-2.0-flash-exp‚Äù for general text generation or ‚Äúgemini-2.0-flash-exp-image-generation‚Äù when you specifically need image output. It‚Äôs important to understand that as an experimental version, there may be changes to the API before the final production release.

Basic Implementation Code

Implementing image generation with Gemini 2.0 Flash is remarkably straightforward. Here‚Äôs a basic Python implementation using the official Google GenAI client library:

This simple code can generate a complete illustrated story. In my implementation of an elephant storybook, I expanded this to handle streaming responses and save the generated images, but the core request structure remains similar. (Full code in the Github link below)

Configuration Options

To control the output of Gemini 2.0 Flash, several configuration parameters are available:

Streaming Responses

For a better user experience, especially with longer generations that include multiple images, implementing streaming responses is recommended:

This approach allows you to process and display parts of the response as they become available, rather than waiting for the entire generation to complete.

Practical Use¬†Cases

Creative Content Generation

Gemini 2.0 Flash excels at creating narrative content with illustrations. In my experiments creating a storybook based on an elephant character and adapting Panchatantra stories, the model consistently produced engaging narratives with visually appealing illustrations that maintained character consistency throughout.

These capabilities make it ideal for pre-viz and prototyping:

The ability to generate both text and images in a coordinated fashion significantly reduces the effort required to create these kinds of materials.

Design and Visualization

The model‚Äôs ability to modify existing images opens up numerous possibilities for design visualization. In my simple experiments, I found the model could understand which element to modify while preserving the overall composition and realistic lighting effects.

Other design applications include:

The conversational nature of the interaction makes these design explorations more intuitive than traditional editing tools, especially for quick ideation.

Specialized Applications

Beyond creative and design use cases, Gemini 2.0 Flash has potential for more specialized applications:

Use case: Accessibility Design¬†Testing

One particularly promising application is accessibility design testing. Traditional approaches often rely on specialized software or manual inspection, but Gemini 2.0 Flash can visualize accessibility modifications directly on images of existing spaces.

In a simple implementation using a subway station image, I was able to have the model add wheelchair ramps and highlight obstacles that might impede accessibility. The complete code for this implementation shows how straightforward this process can be:

What makes this application particularly valuable is how it can help architects, urban planners, facility managers and most importantly users/ citizens visualize accessibility improvements without requiring specialized design skills. The model can identify potential issues and show how modifications might look when implemented, making accessibility planning more intuitive and collaborative.

Once again, while not a replacement for professional accessibility assessment, this approach offers a quick visualization tool that can help stakeholders better understand and communicate about accessibility needs. The model can identify stairs, narrow passages, high counters, and other common barriers, then show how modifications like ramps, wider doorways, or lower counters would appear in the space.

The following GitHub link provides the code mentioned above, a few image generations, and additional code samples referenced in this article.

Conclusion: Best Practices & Looking¬†Forward

Gemini 2.0 Flash represents more than just another AI tool‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs a glimpse into a future where the barriers between imagination and visualization continue to dissolve. As we‚Äôve explored throughout this guide, the technology offers developers unprecedented capabilities to create, modify, and communicate through images with natural language interactions.

The optimization strategies we‚Äôve discussed‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbeing specific yet flexible in prompts, using descriptive style terms, building context progressively, and iterating through conversation‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääprovide a foundation for working effectively with this emerging technology. In my own experiments with Panchatantra stories and personal photo modifications, these approaches consistently led to satisfying results.

While limitations exist (Richard‚Äôs and author‚Äôs ties included)‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääparticularly around maintaining perfect consistency across multiple generations, handling very complex compositions, and addressing highly specialized domain knowledge‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe model‚Äôs capabilities already exceed what was possible just months ago. Each limitation represents not a barrier but a frontier for future development.

As one of the mainstream players in AI, Google continues to refine this technology, giving users and developers more choices than ever before. The gap between idea and visualization has never been smaller, and the potential applications across industries‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääfrom education to healthcare to design‚Ää‚Äî‚Äähave never been broader.

By Lakshmi narayana .U on March 16, 2025.

title: Developing Business Thinking AI Plugins using Semantic Kernel
content:
### Developing Business Thinking AI Plugins using Semantic¬†Kernel


The short courses available on Andrew Ng‚Äôs deeplearning.ai website provide comprehensive overviews of the latest AI technologies. They offer practical experience and cover a wide range of leading tech providers in the field, enabling learners to choose the tools and technologies that best suit their needs. While most of these courses are designed with developers in mind, the ‚ÄúHow Business Thinkers Can Start Building AI Plugins With Semantic Kernel‚Äù course is a notable exception, standing out for its business slant.

A quick word about Orchestration Frameworks:

The key components of an LLM orchestration framework include:

1. API: A simple API that makes it easy to interact with LLMs, manage resources, and monitor performance.

2. Distributed Architecture: The ability to scale the orchestration framework to handle large numbers of LLMs, ensuring efficient resource utilization.

3. Load Balancing: A feature that helps distribute the workload evenly among available LLMs, improving performance and reducing latency.

4. Fault Tolerance: Mechanisms to handle errors and failures in the orchestration process, ensuring the reliability of the LLM-based applications.

5. Security: Features to ensure the security of the LLM-based applications, such as authentication, authorization, and encryption.

6. Model Management: Version control, model lineage tracking, and model deployment pipelines are essential for managing LLMs.

7. Traces and Spans: LLM orchestration frameworks need to support tracing and spans to provide visibility into the orchestration process and help with troubleshooting and monitoring.

8. Resource Management: The ability to allocate and manage resources, such as memory and CPU, for the LLMs, ensuring efficient utilization and avoiding resource contention.

Some popular LLM orchestration frameworks include LangChain, Llama Index, Semantic Kernel and Arize AI. These frameworks offer various features and capabilities, so it is essential to choose the one that best meets the needs of your application.

About Microsoft‚Äôs Semantic¬†kernel.

Semantic Kernel is an open-source SDK developed by Microsoft that allows developers to easily integrate AI services like OpenAI, Azure OpenAI, and Hugging Face with conventional programming languages like C# and Python. It is designed to help developers create AI apps that combine the best of both worlds.

Semantic Kernel is at the center of the copilot stack, an AI orchestration layer that allows the combination of AI models and plugins to create new experiences for users. It has been engineered to allow developers to flexibly integrate AI services into their existing apps.

Semantic Kernel provides a set of connectors that make it easy to add memories and models, effectively adding a simulated ‚Äúbrain‚Äù to your app. It also makes it easy to add skills to your applications with AI plugins that allow you to interact with the real world.

These plugins are composed of prompts and native functions that can respond to triggers and perform actions. Because of the extensibility Semantic Kernel provides with connectors and plugins, you can use it to orchestrate AI plugins from both OpenAI and Microsoft on top of nearly any model.

For more detailed information, you can check out the official documentation or the GitHub repository for Semantic Kernel.

The course: ‚ÄúHow Business Thinkers Can Start Building AI Plugins With Semantic¬†Kernel‚Äù

It has the following sections.

This course is designed to provide a comprehensive understanding of how AI can be used in businesses, with practical examples and activities throughout. It is ideal for business thinkers who want to leverage AI in their operations.

Coding Examples

The course comes with 5 easy-to-follow Jupyter notebooks, each corresponding to a chapter above. These notebooks contain Python code and work seamlessly on Google Colab.

Practical Extensions Developed Based on the Course¬†Content.

Drawing from the course content, I developed practical extensions that utilized the concept of creating business thinking plugins using Semantic Kernel. This was a significant learning experience for two reasons: 1) It facilitated a deeper understanding of the underlying code structure, enhancing my technical proficiency. 2) It enabled me to leverage my business expertise to construct relevant and impactful AI tools.

I decided to apply the principles from ‚ÄòBlue Ocean Strategy‚Äô, a methodology developed by W. Chan Kim and Ren√©e Mauborgne. Although I anticipated that the initial implementation may not yield optimal results, I recognized this as an essential stepping stone in understanding and effectively utilizing business plugins.

Here is a report of my chat summary with ChatGPT, to generate the basic framework.

Developing a Blue Ocean Strategy for a Movie Production House.

title: Navigating Custom Video Agents: A Journey Using the VideoDB Director Framework
content:
### Navigating Custom Video Agents: A Journey Using the VideoDB Director Framework


Multimodal AI and the Role of Video in Shaping the¬†Future

In multimodal AI, which combines data types like text, images, audio, and video, managing video content often feels like anything but fun. Videos stand out for their ability to convey rich, contextual information, making them central to applications in education, entertainment, and beyond. Yet, their potential comes with challenges‚Ää‚Äî‚Äästorage demands, processing complexities, and intricate workflows often make video integration a daunting task.

This is where Director, an AI video agent framework, steps in. It transforms video interactions into intuitive experiences by enabling natural language-driven workflows for tasks like search, editing, and generation. By simplifying the complexities of video management, Director not only addresses the infrastructure challenges but also aligns with Mary Poppins‚Äô wisdom, turning a once tedious job into an engaging and efficient game.

Here is an overview of other features of VideoDB that power Director.

In this article, we will review this framework, examine how easy it is to deploy locally, explore its existing agents, and then add an agent ourselves.

But first, here is an overview of the Director framework.

Video-db Director: An AI Video Agent Framework

Video-db Director is a framework designed to build AI video agents that can perform complex video tasks, such as searching, editing, compiling, and generating content, with the ability to stream results instantly. It is built upon the ‚Äòvideo-as-data‚Äô infrastructure of VideoDB. The framework is designed to simplify media workflows using AI.

Key Features

Functionality and Examples Director functions as a ‚ÄúChatGPT for videos‚Äù. It enables users to input natural language commands that trigger the system‚Äôs reasoning engine to orchestrate different agents to complete tasks.

- A simple command like ‚ÄúCreate a hook template for this video‚Äù can initiate the process.- Examples of agents include a Prompt clip (to create clips from the video, Summarise, Highlight Creator, Text to Movie agent, and a Video Search agent.

Architecture

The framework is composed of several key components:

At the core of Director is its Reasoning Engine, the central hub enabling intelligent workflows. It processes user inputs, maintains context, and orchestrates agents to handle tasks like video summarization, editing, and sharing. By breaking tasks into smaller steps, it ensures real-time, accurate results while providing live feedback. Extensible and efficient, the engine makes advanced video interactions seamless‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhether it‚Äôs clipping a scene or automating a workflow.

By default, Director uses SQLite as the database, which can be customized based on user requirements. The local database stores metadata and relationships, while a remote service, videodb.io, manages video storage, stream delivery, and media processing, ensuring seamless handling of video assets.

Steps to install and deploy Director locally (that uses VideoDB infrastructure in the¬†cloud)

2. Run the setup script:

This script installs Node.js, Python, and pip and sets up virtual environments.

3. Configure environment variables:

Add API keys and other configuration options to the¬†.env files.

Director supports Mac, Linux, and Windows (WSL).

4. Run the application

It launches the application on `http://127.0.0.1:8080`

Existing Customizable Video Agents of¬†Director

Director comes equipped with over 20 pre-built video agents that can handle a variety of video tasks, making it a comprehensive tool for anyone working with video content. These agents are customizable and designed to simplify even the most complex workflows. Some of the features include:

- Video Summarization (summarize_video): Create concise summaries of long videos in seconds.¬†- Video Generation (video_generation): Generate small videos from a script.¬†- Content Clipping (prompt_clip): Extract clips seamlessly from larger video files.¬†- Creative Tools (meme_maker, thumbnail): Generate memes and thumbnails effortlessly.

These agents demonstrate the flexibility and utility of Director, making it a good tool for video creators and managers alike.

Let‚Äôs now look at building a custom agent in Director.

To create a new agent in Director,

The HookTemplateAgent in demonstrates how to build an agent for analyzing video content and creating structured outputs like video hooks or scene recommendations.

Building a Custom Agent in Director (HookTemplateAgent)

The idea behind Hook Template agent is to streamline the creation of engaging video openings by analyzing video content and generating compelling hook templates. Potentially, this can come in handy, whether you‚Äôre working with interviews, storytelling narratives, educational content, or marketing videos, where this agent examines transcripts and scenes to identify the most captivating moments, quotes, and insights from your content. It then structures these elements into a professional template that includes script suggestions, visual recommendations, and pacing guidance‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääall designed to grab viewer attention in the crucial first 15‚Äì30 seconds. This agent further customized could provide good guidance for content creators, educators, and marketing teams looking to consistently create strong video openings while saving time in the creative process, especially when the agent is deployed over a set of videos.

Let‚Äôs break down how it works.

1. InitializationThe HookTemplateAgent is defined as a subclass of BaseAgent, inheriting its core functionality while adding specific attributes such as agent_name, description, and required parameters.

Key components include:

2. Define Parameters

The agent accepts three parameters:

3. Processing Video Transcripts

The _get_transcript method retrieves the video transcript. If the transcript isn‚Äôt readily available, it indexes the video‚Äôs spoken words and fetches the transcript.

4. Analyzing Video Scenes

The _get_scenes method retrieves a scene index for the video. If no index exists, it creates one.

5. Workflow Summary

The HookTemplateAgent:

For example, it updates users with progress using self.output_message and handles exceptions gracefully.

6. Sample Output

Check it out here

For the complete implementation, please click below for the github link.

Next Steps and Conclusion

During my local deployment and development, I was unable to view the backend as mentioned in Director‚Äôs GitHub documentation. This needs further exploration, along with the multi-agent functionality. Additionally, experimenting with databases other than SQLite and integrating other LLMs would be valuable next steps.

Just as Mary Poppins reminds us to find the fun and turn work into a game, Director simplifies complex video workflows into manageable, intuitive tasks. Whether leveraging pre-built agents or building custom ones like the HookTemplateAgent, the framework empowers users to analyze and transform video content with ease. By integrating scalable tools, a flexible design, and support for reusable functionality, Director shifts the focus from tedious processes to meaningful creativity. It enables creators to craft engaging narratives and innovative workflows while seamlessly managing complexities in the background.

With infrastructure and features like the billing dashboard offering detailed insights into usage and storage, video management becomes more transparent and efficient.
