title: Agent Communication Protocol: How ACP Enables Multi-Framework AI Agent Communication
content:
### Agent Communication Protocol: How ACP Enables Multi-Framework AI Agent Communication


An Open Standard for Multi-Framework AI Agent Communication

Think of the climactic mission in Top Gun: Maverick‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäF/A-18 Super Hornets, F-35 Lightning IIs, and support aircraft from different manufacturers, all coordinating through standardized communication protocols to execute a complex mission. Each aircraft has unique capabilities, but they succeed because they speak the same language to mission control and each other.

Now imagine if every aircraft manufacturer had invented its own communication system. The mission would be impossible. This is exactly where AI agents find themselves today‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbrilliant individually, but find it difficult to coordinate because there‚Äôs no universal ‚Äúmission control protocol‚Äù for AI agents.

Quick guidance before we dive into the tech: who this is for and a fast TL;DR.

Reader Note


### The Interoperability Challenge


The AI agent ecosystem has exploded with specialized frameworks. CrewAI enables collaborative intelligence, AutoGen facilitates multi-agent discussions, LangGraph/LlamaIndex orchestrates workflows, and open Smolagents/Agno/Mastra etc provides seamless tool integration. Each framework excels at specific tasks, but they can‚Äôt work together.

This creates the N√óN integration problem: connecting four frameworks requires six custom integrations. Add one more framework, and you need ten integrations. Teams rebuild similar functionality across frameworks instead of leveraging existing capabilities. Organizations face vendor lock-in that prevents optimal tool selection.

Consider an enterprise building an intelligent research system. They might need CrewAI‚Äôs collaborative analysis, Smolagents‚Äô web search integration, AutoGen‚Äôs multi-perspective discussions, and LangGraph‚Äôs workflow orchestration. Currently, this would require custom integration code between each framework pair‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa maintenance nightmare that grows exponentially with each new framework.


### Understanding ACP


Agent Communication Protocol (ACP) solves this interoperability challenge through standardized communication. Originally developed by IBM Research and now managed by the Linux Foundation, ACP provides a REST-based protocol using standard HTTP for agent coordination.

The architecture is simple: agents are hosted inside ACP servers and accessed through ACP clients. You can test ACP agents with curl, Postman, or a web browser‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääno special SDK required, though Python and TypeScript SDKs are available.

Key features¬†include:

Framework Agnostic Design: Existing agents become ACP-compliant with minimal modifications while retaining their internal logic

Comprehensive Content Support: Uses MimeTypes for content identification, making it extensible to handle any data format‚Ää‚Äî‚Äätext, images, audio, video, or custom binary formats work out of the box

Streaming and Real-Time Communication: Supports streaming responses, enabling agents to provide incremental updates during task execution via Server-Sent Events and WebSockets

MCP Integration: Agents can use MCP internally to access tools and ACP to communicate with other agents‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe protocols are complementary rather than competitive

Agent Lifecycle Management: Complete lifecycle support from configuration and discovery through deployment, operation, and retirement with built-in state management

Observability and Monitoring: Built-in diagnostic hooks for logging communications, exposing performance metrics, and tracing errors across distributed tasks

Offline Discovery: Agents can embed metadata directly into their distribution packages, enabling discovery even when inactive in scale-to-zero environments

Security and Access Control: Support for capability tokens, authentication systems, and access delegation while maintaining user control

Open Governance: Linux Foundation oversight ensures broad industry participation rather than vendor lock-in


### Protocol Landscape Comparison


Understanding where ACP fits requires examining it alongside other emerging standards:

Protocol Comparison

Technical Feature Comparison

Architectural Philosophy Comparison

When to Use Which Protocol

Protocol Integration Patterns

The protocols are designed to be complementary rather than competitive:

MCP + ACP Integration: Agents can use MCP internally to access tools and ACP to communicate with other agents. The DeepLearning.AI course demonstrates building ‚Äúan agent that uses MCP to access tools and ACP to communicate with other agents.‚Äù

Layered Adoption Strategy: Organizations can adopt capabilities incrementally‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äúbeginning with MCP for tool access, followed by ACP for multimodal messaging, A2A for collaborative task execution, and extending to ANP for decentralized agent marketplaces.‚Äù

Protocol Bridge Solutions: Bridge servers exist that ‚Äúconnect Agent Communication Protocol (ACP) agents with Model Context Protocol (MCP) clients, enabling seamless integration between ACP-based AI agents and MCP-compatible tools like Claude Desktop.‚Äù


### Production Implementation: Railway Platform Integration


To demonstrate ACP‚Äôs practical capabilities, let‚Äôs examine a complete production newsroom intelligence system deployed on Railway, which is a functional system with real web integration, live fact-checking, and multi-agent coordination. (Github link provided at the end of the article.)

Project Architecture and Structure

The implementation follows a production-ready structure optimized for cloud deployment:

Complete Environment Configuration

The system demonstrates production environment management with comprehensive configuration options:

Docker Containerization Approach

The production deployment uses a multi-stage Docker approach optimized for Railway:

Agent Implementations

The system includes eight specialized agents that perform actual web operations:

Web Research Agent with Live Integration

Protocol-Native Agent Orchestration

The orchestrator agent demonstrates ACP‚Äôs most powerful feature‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääagents calling other agents through the same protocol:

Railway Deployment Configuration

Railway‚Äôs configuration demonstrates production-ready ACP deployment:

Production Client Implementation

The system includes a comprehensive client that demonstrates real-world ACP usage:

Automated Testing and Verification

The system includes comprehensive testing to verify deployment success:

Protocol-Native Health Monitoring

The system replaces traditional HTTP health checks with ACP-native monitoring:

Real-World Usage¬†Examples

The implementation demonstrates several practical ACP usage patterns:

This production implementation demonstrates ACP as a practical solution for real-world multi-agent coordination, complete with web integration, fact-checking, health monitoring, and cloud deployment capabilities.


### Key Takeaways for Business¬†Leaders


The Agent Communication Protocol (ACP) addresses critical challenges in AI agent coordination, offering practical benefits for organizations building AI-driven workflows. Here‚Äôs what it means for your business:


### Technical Architecture and Business¬†Value


ACP‚Äôs design enables concrete business benefits through practical patterns that address real operational challenges.

Framework Interoperability Benefits

Streaming and Progressive Responses

ACP‚Äôs streaming capability enables user experience improvements:

This streaming capability proves essential for long-running analyses and research tasks, providing immediate feedback and enabling decisions based on preliminary results.


### Getting Started with¬†ACP


ACP is designed to be approachable, using familiar HTTP patterns and standard web tools for testing.

Basic Implementation

Client Integration

Migration Strategies


### Future Outlook and Mission¬†Control


The industry trajectory toward agent-based systems is clear, and ACP provides the communication infrastructure that makes this transformation practical rather than chaotic. The merger with Google‚Äôs A2A protocol signals consolidation around open standards, benefiting developers with a single standard and preventing vendor lock-in.

Several trends position ACP for broader adoption:

Enterprise Deployment: Linux Foundation governance provides the stability enterprises require for long-term investment in agent communication standards

Cross-Organizational Workflows: Protocol standardization enables secure agent collaboration between organizations‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääsupply chains, financial services, and healthcare are early adopters

Agent Marketplaces: Standardized communication enables marketplace models where organizations discover and integrate third-party agents through capability discovery features

Hybrid Human-AI Workflows: Async design accommodates human-in-the-loop processes naturally, blending human judgment with agent automation

Like the Top Gun: Maverick mission where different aircraft coordinate through standardized protocols to achieve complex objectives, ACP enables AI agents from different frameworks to coordinate seamlessly. Bret Taylor‚Äôs vision of outcomes-based software becomes practical when agents can communicate efficiently rather than struggling with integration complexity.

The protocol‚Äôs early adoption provides strategic advantages: selecting optimal agents regardless of framework, integrating with partners‚Äô agents easily, and evolving agent strategies without vendor lock-in. Organizations that implement ACP-based agent coordination today are building the communication infrastructure for Taylor‚Äôs outcomes-focused future‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhere AI agents coordinate like precision aircraft in controlled airspace, safely and efficiently delivering the results that businesses need.

The complete ACP implementation discussed in this article, including Railway deployment configurations and all agent examples, is available on GitHub. The production deployment demonstrates real-world ACP usage with live web integration, multi-agent coordination, and cloud-native deployment patterns.


### A message from our¬†Founder


Hey, Sunil here. I wanted to take a moment to thank you for reading until the end and for being a part of this community.

Did you know that our team run these publications as a volunteer effort to over 3.5m monthly readers? We don‚Äôt receive any funding, we do this to support the community. ‚ù§Ô∏è

If you want to show some love, please take a moment to follow me on LinkedIn, TikTok, Instagram. You can also subscribe to our weekly newsletter.

And before you go, don‚Äôt forget to clap and follow the writerÔ∏è!

title: Advanced RAG Techniques in AI Retrieval: A Deep Dive into the Chroma Course
content:
### Advanced RAG Techniques in AI Retrieval: A Deep Dive into the Chroma¬†Course



### Overview of Advanced retrieval for AI with Chroma course by Anton Troynikov and Andrew¬†NG


The course on ‚ÄúAdvanced retrieval for AI with Chroma‚Äù is taught by Anton Trovnikov, a co-founder of Chroma, which is an open-source vector database. The course focuses on various techniques to enhance the accuracy of Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG).

These techniques include Query expansion, which utilizes a Large Language Model (LLM) to rewrite or generate queries that accurately reflect the user‚Äôs intent. Another technique highlighted in the course is Document selection, where an LLM is used to select the most relevant sections from the retrieved documents for the RAG context.

The course also explores the process of fine-tuning embeddings. This involves adapting query embeddings based on user feedback. The benefits of these techniques are substantial, leading to a significant improvement in RAG accuracy and reducing common retrieval pitfalls associated with semantic similarity but lacking answer information.

The course content is comprehensive, covering common RAG retrieval failure modes, LLM-based query expansion for improved retrieval, text model scoring and ranking of retrieved results, and fine-tuning query embeddings with user feedback.

Contrasting with the course that utilizes Langchain, an insightful and comprehensive article on the implementation of RAG is provided by Ivan Ilin.

The aforementioned article provides an in-depth analysis of the following topics, primarily focusing on the implementation using Llamaindex.

Naive RAG Approach:

Advanced RAG Techniques:

Fusion Retrieval:

Query Transformations and Routing:

Use of Agents in RAG:

After completing the course, it‚Äôs a good idea to read the mentioned article. This will help you see a broader view beyond what you learned about the Chroma vector store and consider other options.


### Tips for running the course notebooks on your computer.


One of the challenges I encountered while running the notebooks on my computer was conflicts during Python installation.

Even after installing the modules, I would get ‚ÄòModuleNotFoundError‚Äô. I fixed this by using python-m install instead of pip install. This makes sure the installation happens in the current environment.

python -m pip install ‚Äúyour library‚Äù

Additionally, it is better to configuring Chroma to save and load from your local machine. This way, data will be persisted automatically and loaded on start (if it exists).

client= chromed.PersistentClient (path="/path/to/save/to"

The path is where Chroma will store its database files on disk, and load them on start.

Running the Advanced Retrieval for AI with Chroma course notebooks highlighted the importance of effective troubleshooting, cache management, and hardware considerations in AI. Careful dependency management and adjusting the setup process to specific hardware characteristics improved performance and stability.


### A Quick and Simple Recap on¬†RAG


Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) is a cool new way to make artificial intelligence (AI) smarter. It improves Large Language Models (LLMs), which are AI systems that can understand and generate text. RAG does this by adding a search function that pulls in the most relevant and up-to-date information from big databases. This means the AI can use the latest information to answer questions or make decisions.

RAG was first introduced in a research paper by Facebook in 2020. The researchers imagined RAG as a mix of two types of memory: one is like the AI‚Äôs existing knowledge, and the other is like a search engine. This combination allows the AI to access and use information more effectively, especially when answering complex questions. This idea has since been developed further and is now used in many AI applications.

In the field of Natural Language Processing (NLP), which is all about helping computers understand and generate human language, RAG has been a game-changer. Traditional language models could generate text, but they often couldn‚Äôt bring in extra, specific information while they were generating text. RAG solves this problem by combining the search capabilities of retrieval models with the text-generating skills of generative models. This has opened up new possibilities in NLP, making RAG a crucial tool for tasks that require detailed, informed responses.

RAG works by using two main parts: the retrieval model and the generative model. The retrieval model is like a librarian, pulling out relevant information from databases or collections of documents. This information is then given to the generative model, which is like a writer. The generative model uses the retrieved data to write coherent and informative text, ensuring that the responses are accurate and full of context.

While RAG significantly boosts the capabilities of LLMs, it‚Äôs crucial to recognize its dual nature. On one hand, RAG mitigates issues like false information generation and data leakage, enhancing the trustworthiness of AI interactions. However, the quality of RAG‚Äôs responses heavily depends on the quality of the retrieved data, highlighting the need for robust and reliable data sources‚Äã‚Äã.


### Course contents of Advanced Retrieval for AI with¬†Chroma



### Putting Course Knowledge into Practice with My Book as a Reference

Exercise Workbook 2: Implementing Query Expansion Technique

Objective: Explore the two techniques in Query Expansion‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäExpansion with Generated Answers and Multiple Queries‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääto choose the best for a non-fiction book like ‚ÄòDirecting Business‚Äô.

Original Query: Give a movie example to explain how to drive one‚Äôs time?

Joint Query: (with hypothetical answer from gpt-turbo-3.5) Give a movie example to explain how to drive one‚Äôs time? One movie example that can be used to explain how to drive one‚Äôs time is ‚ÄúThe Pursuit of Happyness‚Äù (2006) starring Will Smith. Based on a true story, the film showcases a struggling salesman named Chris Gardner who is determined to provide a better life for his son. Despite facing numerous setbacks and hardships, Gardner demonstrates exceptional time management skills throughout the movie. He meticulously plans his day, making the most of each minute by prioritizing tasks and maximizing productivity. His dedication to driving his time is evident as he juggles multiple jobs, studies for exams, and searches for a new job opportunity. Gardner‚Äôs unwavering focus on utilizing his time efficiently ultimately leads to his success, highlighting the importance of effective time management in achieving one‚Äôs goals.

He meticulously plans his day, prioritizing tasks and maximizing productivity. For the Joint query:

A movie example that demonstrates how to drive one‚Äôs time is ‚ÄúGroundhog Day.‚Äù In the movie, the main character Phil Connors, played by Bill Murray, relives the same day over and over again. At first, he squanders his time, but after witnessing death, he decides to make the most of each day. He develops a schedule and is motivated to help others, which gives him a sense of purpose. By structuring his time and focusing on meaningful tasks, Phil is able to execute his day with efficiency. This example highlights the importance of prioritizing tasks and using time wisely.

This scene showcases the importance of not wasting time and taking action when necessary. It emphasizes that when you have to shoot, you should just shoot and not waste time talking. This scene conveys the message that time is a valuable commodity and it is in our hands to use it wisely. The book also mentions the importance of time management and how it is in our control to choose how we spend our time. Time management is crucial not only in movie production but also in various aspects of life.

After testing the above approach with several other queries, it has been observed that the technique of Expansion by Multiple queries is more effective for a generic non-fiction book such as mine. However, simple RAG might do the trick.

To conclude, the ‚ÄúAdvanced Retrieval for AI with Chroma‚Äù course is a valuable resource for anyone delving into the nuances of AI retrieval. It offers deep insights into enhancing RAG accuracy and introduces vital techniques such as query expansion and embedding fine-tuning.

Looking forward, exploring other vector databases like Pinecone and applying these concepts in diverse scenarios and various document types are logical next steps. This exploration not only broadens our understanding but also drives innovation in AI retrieval. As we integrate these learnings, sharing experiences and engaging with the AI community becomes essential for collaborative growth and advancement in this exciting field.

### (old)From Specifications to Context Engineering: How the BMAD METHOD Delivers Better AI Development Results


A practical exploration of context engineering through structured AI agent workflows


### Following the Paper¬†Trail


In The Untouchables, everyone was trying to bring down Al Capone with guns and raids. Federal agents, police detectives, and prosecutors all focused on the obvious‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääviolence, bootlegging, and intimidation. But it was Oscar Wallace, the quiet accountant, who found the key: systematic documentation.

While others chased dramatic confrontations, Wallace focused on context‚Ää‚Äî‚Äätax returns, financial records, and methodical investigation. ‚ÄúMr. Capone has neglected to file a tax return for four years,‚Äù he observed. The man who seemed untouchable could be brought down with bookkeeping.

Today‚Äôs AI developers face a similar challenge. We‚Äôre all trying to ‚Äúbring down‚Äù complex development projects with clever prompts and trial-and-error approaches‚Ää‚Äî‚Äälike street cops chasing Capone with guns. But the real breakthrough comes from being more like Oscar Wallace: systematic, methodical, and focused on context engineering.

Like Wallace‚Äôs meticulous financial records, great context engineering transforms impossible challenges into systematic victories.

[IMAGE 1: Split screen comparison‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäLeft: Frustrated developer with messy prompts (street cop), Right: Organized developer with structured workflow (accountant with ledgers). Caption: ‚ÄúStreet cop prompting vs. accountant-level context engineering‚Äù]


### Moving Beyond Street Cop Prompting


The AI development world is shifting from dramatic prompt confrontations to systematic context management. Research shows that most agent failures are context failures, not model failures. While traditional ‚Äústreet cop‚Äù prompting focuses on clever wording and force, context engineering builds methodical systems that provide complete, structured information.

This shift validates what I wrote about in my previous article on specifications becoming the future of programming. The structured approach I advocated is now being proven through context engineering practices. We‚Äôre moving from trial-and-error raids to systematic investigation.

Current challenges developers face mirror Eliot Ness‚Äôs early frustrations: inconsistent results despite good intentions, losing track of important details across complex operations, and difficulty building cases that hold up under scrutiny. The solution isn‚Äôt better raids‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs better record-keeping.

Wallace knew that catching Capone required understanding the complete financial picture, not just individual transactions. Similarly, effective AI development requires understanding the complete project context, not just isolated prompts.


### Hands-On: Building Your Context Paper¬†Trail


Let me walk you through exactly how to set up and use context engineering, using the same systematic approach I used to build a Personal Finance Tracker app‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääfollowing Oscar Wallace‚Äôs methodical documentation strategy.

Setting Up Your Context Investigation System:

Real Implementation Walkthrough:

Starting my investigation, I said: ‚ÄúI want to build a personal finance tracker app that helps users manage their budgets, track expenses, and set financial goals.‚Äù

Then I followed the systematic documentation trail:

Each role switch improved the investigation because each specialist received precisely the documentation they needed. The PM focused on user evidence, the Architect on technical requirements, UX on interaction patterns, and SM on execution planning.

What Made This Investigation Successful:

The evidence flowed seamlessly between specialists. When the Architect started working, they had access to the complete user research from the PM. When UX began designing, they referenced both business requirements and technical constraints. This prevented the common problem of losing crucial evidence as the investigation progressed‚Ää‚Äî‚Äälike Wallace maintaining complete financial records throughout his case.

[IMAGE 2: Screenshot of your CustomGPT showing the agent switching commands and the different types of outputs from PM vs Architect vs UX agents, styled like evidence files]


### The Methodology Behind Systematic Investigation


Research reveals a three-layer investigation architecture that explains why BMAD METHOD works like Wallace‚Äôs approach:

Layer 1: Investigation Framework‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäAgent roles, protocols, and evidence standards. Each BMAD agent has specific documentation responsibilities that prevent evidence contamination. Research shows that clear protocols prevent false information from getting reinforced throughout development cycles.

Layer 2: Evidence Chain‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäCurrent case state, documented findings, and progress tracking. In BMAD, the PRD informs Architecture, Architecture informs Stories, creating a complete evidence trail. Studies demonstrate that this approach maintains case integrity across long investigations without losing critical information.

Layer 3: Specialized Analysis‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäDynamic expertise based on current investigation phase. The Dev agent gets relevant stories plus architecture plus coding standards‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääexactly what they need to build the case. Research confirms that specialized analysis prevents information overload while maintaining focus.

Documentation Management Techniques:

DataCamp research shows that systematic information management can provide up to 54% improvement in complex problem-solving. BMAD implements this through:

The key insight from investigation methodology research is that case failures have specific patterns: evidence contamination (when errors get reinforced), information overload (too much irrelevant data), and chain breaks (forgetting earlier findings). BMAD‚Äôs systematic approach solves all three problems, just like Wallace‚Äôs meticulous bookkeeping.

[IMAGE 3: Diagram showing the three-layer investigation architecture with examples of how evidence flows between BMAD agents, styled like a case board with connected documents]


### The Cost of Sloppy Investigation Work


Enterprise AI research quantifies the problems with unstructured development approaches:

Current Investigation Failures:

My Experience Before Systematic Documentation: I was approaching AI development like a street cop‚Ää‚Äî‚Äätrying to force results through clever prompting rather than building a solid case through systematic investigation. Jumping from idea to code without proper documentation led to inconsistent outputs, missed requirements, and technical debt. Multiple attempts were needed to get coherent results.

The BMAD Investigation Evidence: With systematic context engineering, my success rate jumped dramatically. Each phase produced clear, documented evidence. The Finance Tracker project went from vague concept to detailed implementation plan in one session, with each specialist building meaningfully on previous documentation.

LangChain research confirms that most agent failures stem from documentation issues, not model limitations. When you provide Wallace-quality context‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääsystematic, complete, and properly organized‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääeven basic AI models perform exceptionally well.


### Building Your Case: From Evidence to Execution


Here‚Äôs the systematic methodology that makes BMAD effective:

Phase 1: Initial Evidence Gathering‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäThe PM agent collects comprehensive requirements, user profiles, and success criteria. Research shows that complete documentation upfront prevents downstream confusion and scope drift. This isn‚Äôt just asking ‚Äúwhat do you want to build?‚Äù but systematically documenting business context, user needs, and measurable outcomes.

Phase 2: Technical Analysis‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäThe Architect agent translates business requirements into technical specifications. This implements systematic analysis principles‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääunderstanding not just what needs to be built, but how all the pieces fit together. The key is structured documentation that maintains business-technical alignment.

Phase 3: User Experience Documentation‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäThe UX agent adds interaction requirements while maintaining technical feasibility. Documentation research shows this layered approach prevents cognitive overload while preserving critical information.

Phase 4: Case Breakdown‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäThe SM breaks requirements into specific, actionable tasks with precise context for implementation. This implements the ‚Äúright information, right format, right time‚Äù principle‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääeach development task gets exactly the documentation needed.

Phase 5: Case Validation‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäEach phase validates previous documentation and builds evidence for the next phase. This continuous validation prevents error propagation, a key finding from systematic investigation frameworks.

Documented Outcomes:

[IMAGE 4: Before/after comparison showing messy, unstructured AI outputs vs. clean, organized BMAD methodology outputs with clear documentation, styled like a messy desk vs. organized evidence board]


### Your Investigation Breakthrough Awaits


Research-Validated Results:

Studies show systematic context engineering delivers immediate benefits:

Getting Started‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäYour Investigation Toolkit:

Integration with Current Work: Use BMAD for planning phases of current projects. Apply systematic documentation principles to existing AI tools. Build investigation templates for recurring project types. Train team members on structured AI collaboration.

This validates the structured development approach I outlined in my previous specifications article. Context engineering proves that systematic AI collaboration delivers better results than ad-hoc prompting.


### Following the Money Trail to¬†Success


Al Capone was brought down not by bullets, but by bookkeeping. Oscar Wallace understood that complex challenges require systematic investigation, not dramatic confrontations. ‚ÄúYou can get much farther with a kind word and a gun than you can with a kind word alone,‚Äù Malone said, ‚Äúbut you can get Al Capone with tax returns.‚Äù

Your AI development challenges won‚Äôt be solved by clever prompts any more than Capone was caught by street raids. Success comes from systematic context engineering‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbuilding complete documentation trails that lead to reliable results.

Context engineering with methodologies like BMAD transforms your AI interactions from desperate street cop tactics to methodical investigation work. Your agents get the Wallace-quality documentation they need: systematic requirements, clear role definitions, and complete project evidence.

Be the accountant, not the street cop.

Start building systematic documentation trails for your AI agents, and watch your development outcomes transform from chaotic raids to methodical victories. The evidence‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand the results‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääare out there. You just need to follow the paper trail to find them.

Try the BMAD METHOD on your next AI-assisted project. Focus on building complete documentation rather than clever prompts. The difference between street cop tactics and accountant methodology is the difference between frustration and systematic success.

title: Creating Your Digital Likeness: Synthesia.io and the Future of Personal Avatars
content:
### Creating Your Digital Likeness: Synthesia.io and the Future of Personal¬†Avatars


The Concept of Digital Twins in Popular Culture and AI¬†Avatars

Digital twins are an intriguing goal to have. Although the concept may seem far-fetched at the moment due to several missing pieces, numerous movies have already showcased such technology. These portrayals often blend personal knowledge with a digital likeness, creating a compelling vision of how we might interact with our virtual counterparts.

For instance, in the movie Surrogates, James Cromwell‚Äôs character created a world where people live their lives through robotic surrogates while their actual bodies remain safe at home. These surrogates, essentially digital twins, interact with the world on behalf of their human operators. This concept, while fictional, offers an intriguing vision of how digital twin technology could evolve. The idea of having a personal digital representation that can operate independently in a virtual environment opens up exciting possibilities in various domains, from social interactions to professional tasks.

Aside from the unsettling aspect of humans being completely disconnected from the real world, James Cromwell‚Äôs character presents an intriguing use case in which his surrogates interact with others in less important or routine situations. In fact, Bruce Willis‚Äôs character first interacts with James Cromwell in such a scenario. While the movie Surrogates showcases a futuristic vision, the creation of personal AI avatars ( a baby step towards AI surrogates) is already a reality, progressing significantly in recent years. These avatars can be utilized in diverse ways, from enhancing actors‚Äô brand image off-screen and on-screen to serving as stand-ins for individuals in virtual environments.

AI can generate realistic virtual avatars of actors, which can be used in video games, virtual reality experiences, or even as substitutes for dangerous scenes in movies. Moreover, AI‚Äôs role extends beyond just creating the avatar. It can analyze an actor‚Äôs previous roles, performances, and public persona to create personalized content, aligning with their brand image. This could take the form of social media posts, promotional materials, or even scripts.

Further, advancements in performance capture technology, enhanced by AI, lead to more realistic and nuanced digital characters. AI can also create realistic voice acting for animated or digital characters, adding depth and persona to the character.

On a broader scale, these AI avatars can interact with the world on behalf of their human counterparts, similar to the surrogates in the movie. This opens up a myriad of possibilities in various domains, from social interactions to professional tasks, and could potentially transform the way we interact with the digital world.

In the following sections, we will delve into the process of creating a personal avatar, explore the technology behind it, and discuss what the future holds for this fascinating field.

How to Create a Personal Avatar Using Synthesia.io

Creating a personal avatar with Synthesia.io is a straightforward and efficient process. This guide walks you through the steps to bring your digital likeness to life.

Step 1: Preparation

Before you start, ensure you have a well-lit environment and a quiet space to record your video. The background you choose will be part of your avatar, so select a setting that reflects the professional or personal style you desire.

Step 2: Recording Your Footage

5. Record your consent: After recording your script, you‚Äôll be prompted to record your consent, confirming that Synthesia can use your footage to create the avatar.

Step 3: Submitting and Processing

Step 4: Using Your Avatar

Once your avatar is ready, you can access it directly from your Synthesia account. Here are a few key points to keep in mind:

Here‚Äôs my first AI avatar and a sample video

A sample of my recent loom video for comparison

Benefits and Limitations

Creating a personal avatar with Synthesia is a cost-effective way to produce personalized videos without the need for continuous recording or meetings/events you cannot make it to.

However, be aware of the limitations, such as the inability to update the avatar‚Äôs appearance and the limited video creation time in the starter plan.

Synthesia.io: The Current Technology Powering Digital Web¬†Avatars

Synthesia.io has revolutionized the creation of digital web avatars by leveraging a combination of advanced AI techniques and state-of-the-art technologies. This section delves into the key components and methodologies that make this innovation possible.

1. Pre-trained Models and Transfer Learning

a. Pre-trained networks

Synthesia.io utilizes pre-trained models that have been trained on extensive datasets encompassing diverse faces and voices. These models have already learned a wide array of facial features, expressions, and speech patterns.

b. Transfer learning

Transfer learning allows these pre-trained models to be adapted to new tasks with relatively small amounts of new data. When a user provides a short video, these pre-trained models are fine-tuned to capture the unique features of the user‚Äôs face and voice. This process significantly reduces the training time compared to building models from scratch.

2. Few-Shot Learning and Low-Rank Adaptation

a. Few-Shot learning

Few-shot learning techniques enable models to generalize from a minimal amount of data. By leveraging prior knowledge encoded in the models, Synthesia.io can quickly adapt to new users‚Äô data, ensuring accurate and personalized avatar creation.

b. Low-Rank adaptation (LoRA)

LoRA focuses on modifying only a subset of the model‚Äôs parameters, which reduces computational requirements and accelerates the fine-tuning process. This technique allows the model to efficiently adapt to new data while maintaining high performance.

3. 3D Face and Voice Modeling

a. 3D mesh generation

Synthesia.io creates a detailed 3D model of the user‚Äôs face using convolutional neural networks (CNNs). This involves extracting facial landmarks and generating a 3D mesh that captures the user‚Äôs unique facial structure and expressions.

b. Voice Cloning

The user‚Äôs voice is cloned by extracting voice characteristics and fine-tuning speech synthesis models such as Tacotron 2 and WaveNet. These models are capable of mimicking the user‚Äôs tone, pitch, and cadence, enabling the avatar to speak naturally in the user‚Äôs voice.

4. Real-Time Rendering and Animation

a. Optimized rendering pipelines

Synthesia.io employs GPU-accelerated rendering pipelines to ensure that the avatar animations are generated swiftly and in real-time. This enables the creation of high-quality videos efficiently.

b. Phoneme-Viseme mapping

Accurate lip-syncing is achieved by mapping phonemes (units of sound) to corresponding visemes (visual representations of phonemes). This ensures that the avatar‚Äôs lip movements match the spoken words accurately.

5. Integration with Synthesia‚Äôs Platform

a. Secure cloud storage

The generated avatar, including its 3D model, texture, and voice data, is securely stored in Synthesia.io‚Äôs cloud infrastructure. This ensures scalability and quick access for video generation.

b. Text-to-Video generation

Users can input text scripts into Synthesia.io‚Äôs platform. The system converts these scripts into speech using the cloned voice model and generates corresponding visemes. The avatar is then animated to deliver the script, and the final video is composed with additional elements such as backgrounds and graphics.

Open Source Research powering Features of Synthesia.io

Here‚Äôs a look at the few technologies that are the shaping the future of Synthesia.io.

1. HumanRF: High-Fidelity Neural Radiance Fields for Humans in Motion

HumanRF is a pioneering technique that represents a major leap in capturing and rendering human performances with high fidelity. This technology uses a combination of multi-view capture and 4D dynamic neural radiance fields to produce highly realistic digital avatars.

a. Multi-view Capture and ActorsHQ Dataset

b. 4D Dynamic Neural Radiance Fields

2. Efficient Data Processing and Training Techniques

a. Adaptive Temporal Partitioning

b. Advanced Rendering and Animation

3. Template-Free Approaches for Enhanced Realism

HumanRF adopts a template-free approach, moving away from traditional geometric templates and skeletal models. This allows for:

The advent of personal AI avatars represents a significant step towards the integration of digital and physical worlds. Synthesia.io offers a practical and innovative approach to creating these avatars, making it accessible for a wide range of applications, from enhancing personal brand images to facilitating remote interactions. While the technology is still evolving, the possibilities it opens up are immense, from realistic virtual representations to efficient content creation.

In the broader context, personal AI avatars have the potential to transform our digital interactions and professional communications. As we continue to explore and refine these technologies, the line between the virtual and real worlds will blur, leading to new and exciting possibilities. Whether you‚Äôre looking to enhance your digital presence or streamline your communication efforts, tools like Synthesia.io provide a glimpse into the future of personal AI and digital representation.

By Lakshmi narayana .U on August 4, 2024.

title: Amitabh‚Äôs Oscar acceptance speech
content:
Amitabh‚Äôs Oscar acceptance speech

My fellow artists, my colleagues, my family, and everyone who has made this journey with me‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthank you. It is an immense privilege to stand here, receiving this prestigious award.

Over the past few months, I‚Äôve had the incredible opportunity to be a part of something truly special. A film that has touched hearts and ignited imaginations around the world. We‚Äôve poured our hearts and souls into this project, and I am humbled and deeply grateful for your appreciation.

This award is not just for me, but for every member of the cast and crew, every fan who has supported us, and every child who dreamed of seeing their name on a Hollywood billboard. It is an honor to stand here, as a symbol of Indian cinema, a beacon of hope, and a testament to the power of storytelling.

As I take this stage, I want to take a moment to acknowledge the incredible journey that brought us here. From humble beginnings to this glorious moment, every step was filled with passion, dedication, and unwavering belief in the magic of cinema.

To my fellow actors, thank you for your impeccable performances and unwavering support. Your talent and charisma have ignited the screen, and your contributions have enriched every frame of this film.

To the crew, thank you for your tireless work and unwavering dedication. You are the backbone of any movie set, and your contributions are indispensable.

To my fans, thank you for standing by me through thick and thin. Your unwavering love and support have sustained me during this challenging time.

As I stand here, bathed in the warm glow of this award, I am reminded of the incredible power of cinema. It has the ability to unite us, inspire us, and transport us to different worlds. It is a testament to the human spirit and our shared desire for hope and joy.

I extend my heartfelt gratitude to the Academy and all who have made this night so special. Thank you for recognizing my contribution to Indian cinema and for allowing me to share this gift with the world.

title: In today‚Äôs dynamic business landscape, two distinct approaches have emerged for individuals‚Ä¶
content:
In today‚Äôs dynamic business landscape, two distinct approaches have emerged for individuals, whether as entrepreneurs or employees, to harness the potential of artificial intelligence (AI). The first approach revolves around optimizing existing AI tools and applications, emphasizing their strengths and identifying areas for improvement. The second approach involves creating entirely new AI-driven applications and businesses, paving the way for innovation in various industries.


### Approach 1:


Using Existing AI Tools to Deliver Maximum Results, for individuals as entrepreneurs or employees.

1. Data Analysis and Insights: Utilize AI-powered tools for data analysis, extracting insights, and making data-driven decisions. Examples include Tableau, Power BI, and Google Analytics.

Gaps: Addressing challenges related to data quality, bias in algorithms, and enhancing interpretability of AI-driven insights.

2. Customer Relationship Management (CRM): Leverage AI-enabled CRM platforms for enhanced customer interactions, personalized marketing, and improved customer satisfaction. Examples include Salesforce, HubSpot, and Zoho CRM.

Gaps: Enhancements can be made in sentiment analysis accuracy, natural language understanding capabilities of AI chatbots, and fine-tuning personalized recommendations.

3. Sales and Marketing: Apply AI-driven tools and platforms to optimize sales and marketing strategies, target specific customer segments, and improve campaign effectiveness. Examples include Google Ads, Facebook Ads, and marketing automation tools.

Gaps: Addressing challenges related to ad fraud detection, improving AI algorithms for better conversion prediction, and mitigating biases in automated decision-making.

4. Supply Chain and Logistics: Utilize AI tools for demand forecasting, inventory optimization, and logistics planning to streamline supply chain operations. Examples include IBM Watson Supply Chain and Oracle SCM Cloud.

Gaps: Enhancements can be made in real-time visibility across the supply chain, incorporating external factors like weather or geopolitical events, and optimizing end-to-end supply chain processes.

5. Risk Management and Fraud Detection: Employ AI-powered solutions for risk assessment, fraud detection, and anomaly detection to mitigate risks and safeguard business operations. Examples include SAS Fraud Detection, FICO Falcon Fraud Manager, and IBM Trusteer.

Gaps: Addressing emerging fraud techniques, improving accuracy in real-time fraud detection, and reducing false positives to minimize customer impact.

6. Process Automation: Use AI-powered automation tools, such as RPA platforms, to automate repetitive tasks and workflows, improving efficiency and productivity. Examples include UiPath, Automation Anywhere, and Blue Prism.

Gaps: Integrating AI with RPA to handle unstructured data, expanding cognitive automation capabilities, and ensuring secure automation in sensitive processes.

7. Natural Language Processing (NLP) Applications: Implement NLP tools and solutions for sentiment analysis, chatbot interactions, and text mining. Examples include Google‚Äôs Cloud Natural Language API, IBM Watson NLU, and Hugging Face‚Äôs libraries.

Gaps: Enhancements can be made in understanding complex context, improving multilingual capabilities, and addressing biases in language models.

8. Personalization and Recommendation Systems: Leverage AI-driven recommendation engines for personalized product recommendations, content suggestions, and targeted advertising. Examples include Amazon‚Äôs recommendation engine, Netflix‚Äôs content recommendation, and Spotify‚Äôs music recommendations.

Gaps: Improving serendipity in recommendations, addressing the cold-start problem for new users, and ensuring transparency and user control over personalization algorithms.

9. Personal Productivity Tools: Utilize existing AI-powered tools like Microsoft Office 365, Google Workspace, and Evernote to enhance personal productivity through features like smart suggestions, intelligent search, and automated organization.

Gaps: Continuously improving AI algorithms for better context understanding, refining task management capabilities, and integrating with emerging productivity tools and platforms.

10. Virtual Personal Assistants: Utilize virtual assistant applications such as Apple‚Äôs Siri, Google Assistant, and Amazon‚Äôs Alexa, which leverage AI to provide voice-controlled assistance, perform tasks, and retrieve information.

Gaps: Advancing natural language understanding and conversational capabilities, expanding integration with third-party applications, and ensuring privacy and data security.

11. Smart Calendars and Scheduling: Use AI-powered calendar applications like Microsoft Outlook, Google Calendar, and Calendly to intelligently schedule appointments, optimize meeting times, and automate reminders.

Gaps: Enhancing calendar context awareness, improving scheduling accuracy, and integrating with additional communication platforms and productivity tools.

12. Personalized Health and Fitness Applications: Leverage AI-powered health and fitness apps like Fitbit, Apple Health, and MyFitnessPal to receive personalized health recommendations, track activities, and receive diet suggestions.

Gaps: Advancing AI algorithms for more accurate health data analysis, integrating with medical devices for comprehensive health tracking, and ensuring data privacy and security.

13. Language Learning and Skill Enhancement: Utilize language learning platforms like Duolingo, Rosetta Stone, and Babbel, which leverage AI to provide personalized language lessons, adaptive learning paths, and pronunciation feedback.

Gaps: Improving language proficiency assessment, expanding language coverage, and integrating AI-powered conversation practice for more realistic language learning experiences.¬†14. Generative AI: To leverage Generative AI effectively, individuals can consider tools like OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-3/4 for text generation, NVIDIA‚Äôs StyleGAN for image generation, Jukedeck for music composition, DeepArt for artistic transformations, and RunwayML for a range of generative AI capabilities.¬†¬†Gaps¬†: Addressing ethical usage, bias mitigation, privacy concerns, control and customization options, evaluation mechanisms, data limitations, and performance optimization.

The above covers the key aspects of Approach 1, focusing on the use of existing AI tools and applications to deliver maximum results in various domains. The identified gaps provide areas for improvement and ongoing work, such as addressing data quality and biases, enhancing AI algorithms, improving context awareness, expanding integration capabilities, and ensuring privacy and security.

This article explores two approaches for individuals in entrepreneurship and employment to effectively leverage AI. The first approach utilizes existing AI tools across domains, addressing identified gaps. The second approach involves creating new AI applications, emphasizing sectors such as data analytics, CRM, sales and marketing solutions, supply chain optimization, risk management, and process automation. In both approaches, addressing technology, privacy, and user experience gaps remains crucial for realizing AI‚Äôs potential.

MCP 2.0 represents a significant leap forward in AI-driven productivity. It transforms AI from a conversational assistant into an actionable partner capable of real-time integration across thousands of apps.

title: From The Terminator to Workflows: OpenAI Agent Builder‚Äôs Promise‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand the Skeptics at the Gate
content:
### From The Terminator to Workflows: OpenAI Agent Builder‚Äôs Promise‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand the Skeptics at the¬†Gate



### The 1984¬†Prophecy


In The Terminator (1984), an AI defense network called Skynet becomes self-aware and launches a nuclear holocaust to eradicate humanity, viewing it as a threat to its existence. The film‚Äôs ominous warning‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚ÄúIt can‚Äôt be bargained with. It can‚Äôt be reasoned with.‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcaptured our anxiety about AI systems making autonomous decisions.

Fast forward forty-one years, and OpenAI just launched Agent Builder, a platform that lets anyone create AI agents that act autonomously. Unlike Skynet‚Äôs apocalyptic chaos, these come with guardrails, evaluation tools, and visual canvases. The question isn‚Äôt whether AI agents will change workflows‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthey already are. The question is: can you trust a drag-and-drop platform to build them?

A year ago, I explored building multi-agent workflows using CrewAI‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa code-first approach requiring manual orchestration, custom integrations, and significant development effort. Agent Builder represents a different paradigm: visual-first, with built-in tools and native evaluation.

But does visual simplicity mean production-ready? Let‚Äôs find out.


### The Core¬†Concerns


Before diving into features, let‚Äôs address the elephant in the room


### The Balanced¬†Take


From VentureBeat: ‚ÄúThe response to AgentKit has mainly been positive, with some developers noting‚Ä¶ Several developers view Agent Kit not as a Zapier killer, but rather as a tool that complements the pipeline.‚Äù

The consensus? Agent Builder isn‚Äôt replacing existing tools‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs carving out a new category. As one developer put it: ‚ÄúRamp uses AgentKit for customer-facing chat agents and n8n for backend process automation. Different tools, different contexts.‚Äù

Bottom line: The skepticism is healthy. It forces us to look past the hype and understand what Agent Builder actually does well‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand where it falls short.


### Agent Builder: An¬†Overview


The Core Architecture: AgentKit

Agent Builder is one component of OpenAI‚Äôs AgentKit‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa stack for building production-ready agents:

The Ancient Parable Meets Modern¬†Business

The Panchatantra tale of the Three Fish‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäAnagatavidhata (Forethought), Pratyutpannamati (Quickaction), and Yadbhavishya (Examiner)‚Ää‚Äî‚Äätells of three fish who respond differently to danger. One plans ahead, one acts fast, and one examines reality. This 2,000-year-old parable becomes a framework for strategic business decision-making.

From CrewAI to Agent¬†Builder

Last year, I explored this same three-fish framework using CrewAI, inspired by Andrew Ng‚Äôs talk on agentic workflows at Sequoia Capital. That implementation used:

The approach worked‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit demonstrated iterative problem-solving with multiple agents. But it required writing orchestration code from scratch, managing API calls manually, and building custom evaluation logic.

A year later, Agent Builder changes the equation:

The core insight remains the same‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe Panchatantra framework works for strategic decisions. But the implementation barrier has dropped significantly.

Instead of hours of meetings and market research, the Three-Fish Workflow delivers three structured outputs in about 80 seconds.

### Closing: The Judgement Day¬†Wisdom


Back to The Terminator. After Skynet unleashes nuclear apocalypse on humanity, the survivors learn a harsh lesson: ‚ÄúIt can‚Äôt be bargained with. It can‚Äôt be reasoned with.‚Äù

But with Agent Builder, the game has changed. The winning move is to play‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbut with:


### The Honest Assessment


The skeptics are right about concerns:

But the optimists are also right:

Agent Builder is for you if:

The Three Fish knew: some plan ahead, some act fast, some adapt. The real wisdom? Use the right tool for the job.

Agent Builder isn‚Äôt perfect. It‚Äôs not a Zapier killer. It won‚Äôt replace your entire stack.

But it might be the tool that turns ‚Äúwe should use AI agents‚Äù from a strategy deck talking point into a Monday morning deployment.

From CrewAI‚Äôs code-first approach to Agent Builder‚Äôs visual-first paradigm, the journey continues. Both have their place. Choose based on your needs, not the hype.

Shall we engage? This time, with guardrails.

Ready to build your own Three-Fish Workflow?Start here: platform.openai.com/agent-builder

For the code-curious: Agent Builder exports Python (Pydantic) and TypeScript (Zod) implementations. You can download the generated code, modify it, and run it independently.

Questions or war stories from the trenches?The conversation continues‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbecause unlike Skynet, we learn from playing the game.


### A message from our¬†Founder


Hey, Sunil here. I wanted to take a moment to thank you for reading until the end and for being a part of this community.

Did you know that our team run these publications as a volunteer effort to over 3.5m monthly readers? We don‚Äôt receive any funding, we do this to support the community. ‚ù§Ô∏è

title: How I Write Medium Articles: Finding the 20% That Creates 80% Impact
content:
### How I Write Medium Articles: Finding the 20% That Creates 80%¬†Impact


TL;DR: After two years of writing Medium articles, I‚Äôve discovered that successful content isn‚Äôt about avoiding AI tools‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs about finding your unique 20% contribution that creates 80% of the value. My process involves three inspiration sources (social media trends, deep-dive courses, and news testing), always paired with hands-on exploration and original examples. The key isn‚Äôt the percentage of AI assistance you use, but ensuring your unique insights and contributions form the foundation of everything you publish.

Two years ago, I started writing on Medium with a simple goal: share what I was learning about technology and AI. What I discovered along the way was something more profound‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääin a world where AI can write anything, the real challenge isn‚Äôt creating content, it‚Äôs creating content that matters.

Here‚Äôs the counterintuitive truth I‚Äôve learned: using AI tools doesn‚Äôt make your content less valuable. What makes content less valuable is having nothing unique to contribute in the first place.

After publishing dozens of articles and experimenting with different approaches, I‚Äôve settled into a process that consistently produces work I‚Äôm proud to put my name on. It‚Äôs built on a simple principle: find your 20% that creates 80% of the value.


### My Three Sources of Inspiration (And What Usually Goes¬†Wrong)



### 1. Social Media Signals and Newsletter Nuggets


Most of my article ideas start with something I see scrolling through X or reading one of the many newsletters I subscribe to. But here‚Äôs what I learned the hard way: timing is everything, and most people get it wrong.

I used to jump on trending topics immediately, thinking speed mattered most. The result? Generic articles that said what everyone else was already saying. Now I look for a different sweet spot‚Ää‚Äî‚Äätrends that are gaining momentum but haven‚Äôt been thoroughly explored yet.

For example, when [PLACEHOLDER: specific trend you spotted early and wrote about successfully] started appearing in my feeds, I didn‚Äôt write about the trend itself. Instead, I spent time testing [PLACEHOLDER: what you actually tested/built] and discovered [PLACEHOLDER: your unique insight]. That became the foundation for [PLACEHOLDER: link to successful article].

The key isn‚Äôt to jump on every trending topic. The key is to find the angle that only you can write about because of your specific experience or testing.


### 2. The Deep Dive: Turning Courses into¬†Content


My second major source of inspiration comes from online courses, particularly those on DeepLearning.AI. Here‚Äôs what the course creators won‚Äôt tell you: when a course says it‚Äôs ‚Äúone hour,‚Äù that‚Äôs just the video runtime. For me, it typically takes several days to truly understand what the course is teaching.

I don‚Äôt just watch the videos and move on. I practice the code, break it, fix it, and then write additional code to test my understanding. I take extensive notes in Obsidian, often creating multiple interconnected notes that become my knowledge foundation for that topic.

But here‚Äôs where most people stop‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand where my articles begin. The real value comes not from what the course teaches, but from where the course ends and my exploration begins.

Take my recent article on [PLACEHOLDER: specific article title/link]. The course covered [PLACEHOLDER: what the course taught], but I kept asking ‚ÄúWhat if I tried this approach instead?‚Äù That led me to discover [PLACEHOLDER: your unique finding/implementation], which became the core insight readers couldn‚Äôt find anywhere else.

My biggest failure story here? I once published an article that was essentially a course summary with better formatting. Zero engagement. I learned that if your article could be replaced by the course itself, you haven‚Äôt added enough value.


### 3. News That Demands Testing (Not Just Hot¬†Takes)


The third source of inspiration comes from industry news that I can‚Äôt just read about‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäI need to test it myself. When Microsoft announces a new AI feature, when Apple releases an update, or when OpenAI drops a new model, I don‚Äôt just want to read the press release. I want to get my hands dirty.

This is where I see most tech writers fail. They write hot takes based on announcements without actually testing anything. The result? Content that‚Äôs obsolete the moment someone does the actual work.

My approach: If I can‚Äôt test it, experiment with it, or create something original with it, then I probably shouldn‚Äôt be writing about it.

For instance, when [PLACEHOLDER: recent AI model/tool launch] was announced, instead of writing about its ‚Äúpotential implications,‚Äù I spent [PLACEHOLDER: time spent] testing it with [PLACEHOLDER: specific use case you tested]. What I discovered was [PLACEHOLDER: specific insight from your testing], which became the foundation for [PLACEHOLDER: article link].


### The Hands-On Imperative: My Non-Negotiable Rule


Here‚Äôs my fundamental rule that separates my content from generic AI-generated articles: I never publish an article without creating something original as part of the process.

This might be:

This isn‚Äôt just about having something to show‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs about having something to say. When I‚Äôve actually built something, tested something, or solved a problem myself, I have insights that can‚Äôt be replicated by simply reading other people‚Äôs work or asking an AI to summarize existing content.

My confidence check before hitting publish: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs uniquely mine here? Would this article exist without my direct involvement?‚Äù

If I can‚Äôt answer that question clearly, the article isn‚Äôt ready.


### The AI Partnership Strategy That Actually¬†Works


Let me address the elephant in the room: I use AI tools regularly in my writing process. I use Claude and ChatGPT for refining sections, brainstorming ideas, and even creating related images (which I always acknowledge). I test both local models and AI models in their playgrounds as part of my research process.

But here‚Äôs what most people get wrong about AI assistance: it‚Äôs not about the percentage of AI help you use‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs about where that assistance fits in your creative process.

The Pareto Principle applies perfectly here. Sometimes my personal contribution might be only 20% of the final article‚Ää‚Äî‚Äämaybe I‚Äôve written the core code example and the key insights, while AI has helped with structure, clarity, and polish. But that 20% drives 80% of the article‚Äôs value because it‚Äôs the foundation everything else builds on.

Here‚Äôs a specific example: In my article about [PLACEHOLDER: specific article], I wrote about 300 words of core insights and code. AI helped me expand that into a 1,500-word article with better flow and clarity. Was that ‚ÄúAI-generated content‚Äù? Absolutely not. The AI couldn‚Äôt have written that article without my original testing, insights, and examples.

This is fundamentally different from asking AI to write an article about a topic and then publishing it with minor edits. The difference is in the direction of the creative process: I‚Äôm using AI to amplify and refine my ideas, not to generate them.


### Why AI Detection Misses the Point¬†Entirely


This brings me to something that‚Äôs been bothering me about the current conversation around AI and content creation. There‚Äôs this oversimplified approach where people run articles through AI classifiers and declare them ‚ÄúAI-generated‚Äù based on the results.

This is missing the point entirely.

If I run my entire article through an AI tool for grammar and clarity improvements, that doesn‚Äôt mean AI wrote the article. But because the AI has changed various phrases and sentences, a classifier might flag it as AI-generated.

I‚Äôve seen people get so caught up in avoiding AI assistance that they‚Äôre publishing unclear, poorly structured content just to avoid triggering a classifier. This is backwards thinking. The goal should be to create the most valuable content possible, using whatever tools help you achieve that goal.

The real question isn‚Äôt ‚ÄúWhat percentage of this was touched by AI?‚Äù The real question is ‚ÄúWhere did the core insights, examples, and value come from?‚Äù

If I‚Äôve done original research, created original code, or provided original analysis, then that‚Äôs human contribution regardless of whether I used AI to help with the presentation.


### My Publishing Confidence Checklist


After two years of writing, I‚Äôve developed an internal checklist that determines whether an article is ready to publish:

1. The Uniqueness Test: ‚ÄúWould this article exist without my unique contribution?‚Äù If someone else could have written the same article just by reading existing sources and using AI tools, I haven‚Äôt added enough value.

2. The Value Test: ‚ÄúWhat will readers walk away with that they couldn‚Äôt get elsewhere?‚Äù This might be a new perspective, a practical implementation, or insights from hands-on testing. But there has to be something distinctive.

3. The Ownership Test: ‚ÄúAm I confident explaining and defending every point in this article?‚Äù If I‚Äôve outsourced too much of the thinking to AI, I won‚Äôt be able to engage meaningfully with readers‚Äô questions or criticisms.

When I can answer these questions positively, I know the article is ready. When I can‚Äôt, I know I need to dig deeper, test more, or add more of my own insights.


### Your 20% Matters More Than You¬†Think


Here‚Äôs what I want you to take away from this: in a world where AI can write anything, your unique perspective, experience, and insights are more valuable than ever. Not less valuable‚Ää‚Äî‚Äämore valuable.

The internet doesn‚Äôt need another article that could have been written by anyone. It needs articles that could only have been written by you, informed by your experience, testing, and insights.

Your 20% might be:

Whatever it is, that‚Äôs your competitive advantage. That‚Äôs what makes your content irreplaceable.

So don‚Äôt worry about what percentage of your writing process involves AI assistance. Worry about whether you‚Äôre bringing something unique to the table. Worry about whether you‚Äôre adding value that wouldn‚Äôt exist without your direct involvement.

The world needs your perspective. The question is: what‚Äôs your 20% that could create 80% impact?

What‚Äôs your unique contribution to the conversations you care about? I‚Äôd love to hear about your approach to creating original content in the comments below. And if you found this helpful, consider following me for more insights on AI, writing, and the intersection of technology and creativity.

P.S. If you‚Äôre curious about my specific workflow or want to see examples of the articles I‚Äôve mentioned, feel free to ask in the comments. I‚Äôm always happy to share the behind-the-scenes details.

View original.

content:
This reminded me of regional Indian cinema... you can raise money on the strength of a pitch, but that doesn‚Äôt guarantee the film ever gets made or released. Startups built on demos feel the same: the story sells, but it doesn‚Äôt always last.

What‚Äôs missing though is the other side of working with ChatGPT/Claude etc. Stick with it long enough and you end up learning, even if you‚Äôre non-technical.
