title: From Prompt Engineering to Context Engineering: Building Smarter AI Systems with LlamaIndex
content:
### From Prompt Engineering to Context Engineering: Building Smarter AI Systems with LlamaIndex


How the evolution from crafting prompts to architecting information ecosystems is reshaping AI development (once again)


### üéØ The Great Awakening


‚ÄúJust when you thought you had prompt engineering figured out‚Ä¶‚Äù

Remember in Inception when Dom Cobb thought he was just stealing secrets from dreams, only to discover he could actually architect entire dream worlds with multiple layers of reality? That‚Äôs exactly what happened to the AI community in 2024. While developers everywhere were perfecting their prompt-fu‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcrafting increasingly elaborate instructions like digital Shakespeare‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe real architects were quietly building something that made even the cleverest prompts look like sticky notes.

Enter Context Engineering: the art of architecting entire information ecosystems that make AI systems truly intelligent.

The Reel Revelation:

What‚Äôs Really Happening:

As Andrej Karpathy noted in his recent post, this is about ‚Äúthe delicate art and science of filling the context window with just the right information.‚Äù Industry leaders are recognizing that enterprises must move beyond clever prompts to intelligent context orchestration‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa fundamental shift from ‚Äúasking better questions‚Äù to ‚Äúcreating smarter and scalable environments.‚Äù

This isn‚Äôt just another buzzword evolution: companies implementing context engineering are seeing significant improvements in AI performance, while those stuck in prompt-land are wondering why their systems still struggle with complex, real-world tasks.


### üìä The Great Shift‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäWhy Context Engineering Matters


The Limitations of Prompt Engineering

Traditional prompt engineering focuses on crafting the perfect instruction‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe right words, examples, and structure to guide an LLM‚Äôs behavior. It‚Äôs about optimizing that single text string you send to the model. And for simple tasks, it works brilliantly.

But here‚Äôs where it breaks down: Real-world AI applications aren‚Äôt simple tasks.

When you‚Äôre building a customer support system that needs to remember conversation history, access current product information, check user account status, and coordinate with external tools‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääsuddenly, your carefully crafted prompt is just one small piece of a much larger puzzle.

The context window challenge becomes apparent (even with increasing context windows across all Large Language models): you have limited space (tokens) to work with, and you need to fill it with the right information, not just more information.

Enter Context Engineering

Context engineering shifts the focus from prompt optimization to information ecosystem design. Instead of asking ‚ÄúHow do I phrase this request better?‚Äù we ask ‚ÄúWhat information, tools, and context does the AI need to succeed?‚Äù

The Core Components:

Real-World Impact

Consider KPMG‚Äôs implementation of AI agents across their enterprise. Rather than relying on prompt engineering alone, they built context-rich systems that integrate diverse data sources, maintain conversation history, and coordinate multiple specialized agents. The result? Standardized, scalable AI assistants that actually understand business context.

Or look at Caidera.ai‚Äôs life sciences marketing automation, where context engineering enables 70% faster campaign creation by intelligently orchestrating scientific documents, regulatory requirements, and market data into coherent marketing strategies.


### üèóÔ∏è The Architecture of Intelligence


Why Framework Choice¬†Matters

While context engineering principles can be implemented with any framework, some are better suited to this new paradigm than others. The key is finding tools that support:

Modern Context Engineering Features

Today‚Äôs leading frameworks provide sophisticated context management through:

Advanced Memory Systems:

Dynamic Workflows:

External Integration:

The goal isn‚Äôt to promote any specific tool, but to understand what capabilities enable effective context engineering in practice.


### üí° Context Engineering Techniques in¬†Practice


Core Techniques Breakdown

1. Intelligent Source Selection

Not all information is created equal. The first step in context engineering is analyzing the user‚Äôs query to determine which types of sources will be most valuable:

2. Context Ordering and Compression

Once you have relevant information, you need to rank and potentially compress it to fit within the context window:

3. Context Window Management

The context window is finite, so you need intelligent strategies for fitting information:

4. Multi-Source Data Coordination

Different data sources require different handling strategies:


### üõ†Ô∏è Building Blocks in Action‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäA Research Assistant Case¬†Study


What We‚Äôre¬†Building

Let‚Äôs examine a practical implementation that demonstrates context engineering principles: a multi-source research assistant that intelligently gathers, ranks, and synthesizes information from diverse sources.

The Challenge: Traditional approaches either rely on single sources (like Wikipedia) or dump everything into the context window hoping for the best. Neither approach works well for complex research queries.

The Context Engineering Solution: Build a system that:

Implementation Deep¬†Dive

Smart Document Handling:

Specialized Retrievers:

Performance Visualization:

Measuring Success

Context Engineering Metrics:

Naive vs. Engineered Comparison: The implementation includes a direct comparison function that demonstrates the difference between simply using Wikipedia (naive approach) and the full context engineering pipeline. Typical improvements include:

The Complete Implementation

What the Demo Achieves:

Repository Contents:

The implementation serves as both a learning tool and a foundation for building more sophisticated context engineering systems.

Githhub Link

Techniques to consider while implementing LlamaIndex

My demo showcases a custom context management from scratch for the sake of better understanding, you could use the existing LlamaIndex framework in a better way as indicated below.


### üìà Performance Analysis & Lessons¬†Learned


Measuring Context Engineering Success

Quantitative Metrics:

Qualitative Improvements:

Best Practices Discovered

1. Query Analysis First Understanding user intent before retrieval consistently outperforms generic information gathering. Spend time analyzing what the user is really asking for.

2. Balance Recency and Relevance Fresh information isn‚Äôt always the most important. Develop scoring systems that weight both temporal and topical relevance.

3. Design for Compression Assume you‚Äôll have more relevant information than context space. Build summarization and compression into your pipeline from the beginning.

4. Monitor and Iterate Context engineering benefits from continuous optimization. Build observability into your systems to understand what‚Äôs working.

5. Maintain Source Diversity Single-source systems, even good ones, miss important perspectives. Multi-source approaches provide robustness and completeness.


### üöÄ The Evolving Landscape


Current State of the¬†Field

Context engineering is rapidly evolving, with new techniques and patterns emerging regularly. The field benefits from:

Standardization Efforts:

Technical Advances:

Enterprise Adoption:


### What‚Äôs Next


The field continues to evolve as practitioners discover what works in different contexts. Key areas of development include:


### The Road¬†Ahead


This field will continue evolving as we discover what works in different contexts and scales. The principles are solid, but the implementations will vary widely based on specific needs and constraints.

The transition from prompt engineering to context engineering represents more than just a new technique‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs a new way of thinking about AI system design. Instead of trying to pack everything into perfect instructions, we build intelligent environments that provide AI systems with what they need, when they need it.

Context engineering, as a unified concept, is still in its early days, but the foundational patterns are becoming clear. It will be interesting to see how architects and developers take these concepts and apply them to real-world challenges.

We‚Äôve graduated from the hotel lobby of prompt crafting to architecting the entire dream. Context engineering represents not just better AI systems, but a fundamental shift in how we think about intelligence itself.

This exploration builds on research from the AI community, practical implementations, and ongoing experimentation. The field continues to evolve as more practitioners contribute their insights and discoveries to what promises to be the next major step in AI development.

title: Exploring Model Context Protocol (MCP) with Claude Desktop: Simplifying AI Integration
content:
### Exploring Model Context Protocol (MCP) with Claude Desktop: Simplifying AI Integration


‚ÄúSometimes it is the people who no one imagines anything of who do the things that no one can imagine.‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäThe Imitation Game

This sentiment aligns with the transformative potential of Anthropic‚Äôs Model Context Protocol (MCP), an open-source standard that seamlessly connects AI assistants with diverse data sources. By enabling secure, two-way connections and standardizing integration, MCP empowers AI to transcend traditional limitations and deliver relevant, context-aware responses.

The Model Context Protocol (MCP): AI Integration with Data¬†Sources

Anthropic has introduced the Model Context Protocol (MCP), an open-source standard designed to seamlessly connect AI assistants with various data sources, including content repositories, business tools, and development environments. This initiative aims to enhance AI performance by providing relevant, up-to-date information.

Traditionally, integrating AI systems with diverse datasets required custom implementations for each source, leading to inefficiencies and scalability challenges. MCP addresses this by offering a universal protocol that enables secure, two-way connections between data sources and AI-powered tools. Developers can either expose their data through MCP servers or build AI applications (MCP clients) that connect to these servers, streamlining the integration process.

To facilitate adoption, Anthropic has released several resources:

- MCP Specification and SDKs: Detailed guidelines and software development kits to assist developers in implementing the protocol.- Local MCP Server Support in Claude Desktop Apps: Integration capabilities within Claude‚Äôs desktop applications to connect with MCP servers.- Open-Source Repository of MCP Servers: A collection of pre-built MCP servers for popular enterprise systems like Google Drive, Slack, GitHub, Git, Postgres, and Puppeteer.

Early adopters, including companies like Block and Apollo, have integrated MCP into their systems. Development tool providers such as Zed, Replit, Codeium, and Sourcegraph are utilizing MCP to enhance their platforms, enabling AI agents to retrieve relevant information more effectively and produce nuanced, functional code with fewer attempts.

By standardizing the connection between AI systems and data sources, MCP aims to replace fragmented integrations with a more sustainable architecture, allowing AI systems to maintain context as they interact with various tools and datasets. This advancement is expected to significantly improve the relevance and accuracy of AI-generated responses, marking a substantial step forward in the development of context-aware AI systems.

Steps in Setting Up an MCP¬†Server

In this article, we will cover the steps to set up an MCP server (macOS) and explore a use case associated with it with pre-built MCP servers. To begin building, you need to install pre-built MCP servers via the Claude Desktop app.

Replace the path above with any directory you prefer; in our usecase, it is the Readwise folder in the Obsidian vault.

3. Create the newsletter template from the latest Readwise entries.

Here are the prompts I used to create a basic newsletter template (please ignore the typos). With the capabilities of Claude, you can refine it further and use multiple folders in the filesystem server to enhance its reach and relevance.

Some practical use cases for¬†MCP

This repository contains several reference implementations and community-contributed servers for the Model Context Protocol (MCP). It demonstrates the flexibility and extensibility of MCP by showing how it can securely and efficiently provide Large Language Models (LLMs) with controlled access to various tools and data sources. Each MCP server is built using either the Typescript MCP SDK or the Python MCP SDK.

Here are some practical use cases for the Model Context Protocol (MCP) that one can explore either with the existing servers or custom built ones.

1. AI-Powered Code Assistant

Enhance developer productivity by integrating an AI assistant with code repositories like GitHub. The assistant can analyze commit histories, suggest improvements, and assist with debugging. Utilize an open-source MCP server for seamless communication with AI models.

2. Real-Time Customer Support

Integrate MCP with tools like Slack and Salesforce to provide personalized, contextualized customer support. The AI assistant can access customer history and recent interactions to craft tailored responses, streamlining query resolution.

3. Project Management Assistant

Connect an AI assistant with project management tools like Trello to provide updates on milestones, suggest task prioritization, and analyze productivity trends. Implement an MCP server for real-time project insights.

4. AI-Enhanced Document Search

Enable knowledge retrieval by linking the assistant to platforms like Google Drive. The AI can search, summarize documents, and answer queries based on organizational data, using an MCP server for efficient document access.

5. Personalized Learning and Development

Integrate MCP with learning management systems to deliver personalized recommendations and track progress. Deploy an MCP server to update learning paths dynamically based on user engagement.

These use cases highlight MCP‚Äôs versatility and potential to enhance AI integration across various domains.

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) embodies the spirit of innovation highlighted in The Imitation Game, creating a sustainable architecture for AI integration. By replacing fragmented systems and enabling context-aware interactions, MCP opens new paths for AI applications, empowering them to achieve what was once considered unimaginable.

title: Building Intelligent Agents with Claude Agent SDK: From Concept to Production
content:
### Building Intelligent Agents with Claude Agent SDK: From Concept to Production


‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt You Get the¬†Memo?‚Äù

The AI agent landscape has transformed dramatically over the past year. If you‚Äôre confused by Claude Code, Claude Agent SDK, MCP, and which tool does what, you‚Äôre not alone‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääeven experienced developers are struggling to keep up.

Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs dropped recently:- **November 2024**: MCP (Model Context Protocol)‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe ‚ÄúUSB-C for AI‚Äù- **May 2025**: Claude Code general availability‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääterminal-based AI coding assistant¬†- **September 2025**: Claude Agent SDK + Claude Code VS Code extension

They all sound similar. **They‚Äôre completely different tools.** And mixing them up can waste weeks of development time.

Before we dive into building production agents, let‚Äôs clear up the confusion with a simple comparison:

### The Claude Agent Toolkit: Who‚Äôs It For?

| Tool | Who It‚Äôs For | What You Build | Example | Released ||‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää|‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää|‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî |‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî -|‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää|| **Claude Code** (chat) | Non-techies, business users | Quick automations, prototypes | ‚ÄúAnalyze my sales CSV‚Äù | May 2025 || **Claude Code + VS Code** | Aspiring developers, power users | Interactive development, learning | Data pipeline with guidance | Sep 2025 || **Claude Agent SDK** | Professional developers | Production-grade agents | Greenlighting Agent (this article) | Sep 2025 || **MCP** | All developers | Standardized integrations | Connect AI to any data source | Nov 2024 |

### The Counterintuitive Truth

You might think VS Code + Claude Code is ‚Äúfor developers only,‚Äù but it‚Äôs actually a **game-changer for business users**. Here‚Äôs why:

**For non-technical users**, Claude Code in VS Code offers:- ‚úÖ **No coding required**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäUse natural language to build workflows- ‚úÖ **Fast prototyping**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäExperiment without SDK setup or infrastructure¬†- ‚úÖ **Interactive feedback**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäSee results immediately, iterate quickly- ‚úÖ **Built-in examples**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäTemplates and prompts to get started- ‚úÖ **Lower barrier**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäNo APIs, dependencies, or deployment hassles

**In contrast, the Claude Agent SDK** is for developers who need:- üîß Production-grade error handling- üîß Complex multi-agent orchestration- üîß Custom integrations and workflows¬†- üîß Programmatic control and testing- üîß Deployment at scale

### Which Path Should You Take?

```Non-technical user wanting to automate tasks?‚Üí Start with Claude Code (chat interface)‚Üí Graduate to Claude Code + VS Code for more control

Business user building department workflows?¬†‚Üí Claude Code + VS Code (seriously, try it first)‚Üí Consider Agent SDK only if you hit limitations

Developer building production systems?‚Üí Claude Agent SDK (what this article focuses on)```

**This article focuses on the Agent SDK path**‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbut here‚Äôs the kicker: the prototype we‚Äôll build and share on GitHub can also be explored through Claude Code in VS Code with zero programming knowledge. We‚Äôll show you how at the end.

## Understanding the Claude Agent SDK

Released on September 29, 2025, alongside Claude Sonnet 4.5, the Claude Agent SDK represents a significant milestone in agentic AI development. It‚Äôs the same infrastructure that powers Claude Code‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe tool generating over $500M in annual run-rate revenue‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänow available for developers to build any type of agent.

### What Makes It Different

The SDK provides a comprehensive foundation for building production-ready agents:

**Core Capabilities:**- **Built-in context management**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäHandle long conversations and complex state- **File operations**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäRead, write, and manipulate files programmatically¬†- **Code execution**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäRun bash commands and scripts safely- **Web search**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäIntegrated search capabilities for real-time information- **MCP extensibility**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäConnect to any data source via Model Context Protocol- **Advanced permissions**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäFine-grained control over agent capabilities- **Automatic prompt caching**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäSignificant cost savings on repeated operations

**Available in both TypeScript and Python**, the SDK follows an intuitive agent loop paradigm:

```Gather context ‚Üí Take action ‚Üí Verify work ‚Üí Repeat```

This simple pattern scales from basic automation to complex multi-agent orchestration.

### The Power of Subagents and Hooks

Two features set the Claude Agent SDK apart:

**Subagents** enable specialized task delegation. Instead of one generalist agent, you can create a team of specialists:- A research subagent that excels at information gathering- A coding subagent optimized for implementation¬†- An analysis subagent focused on data processing

These subagents can work in parallel, dramatically speeding up complex workflows.

**Hooks** provide automatic triggers for responsive behaviors:- Pre-execution hooks for validation- Post-execution hooks for cleanup- Error hooks for graceful degradation

Together, these features enable sophisticated agentic workflows that feel less like scripted automation and more like genuine collaboration.

## The Complexity Spectrum: 5 Real-World Use Cases

Not all agents need the same level of sophistication. Understanding where your use case falls on the complexity spectrum helps you build efficiently‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääavoiding both over-engineering simple tasks and under-engineering complex ones.

Here are five real-world use cases in descending order of complexity. Each demonstrates different aspects of the Agent SDK‚Äôs capabilities.

### 5. Customer Support Automation Agent (Least Complex)

**Build Time:** 15‚Äì30 minutes¬†**Complexity:** 1‚Äì2 subagents, simple session management

The entry point to agentic AI. This agent handles customer inquiries by:- Searching knowledge bases for relevant articles- Accessing customer data across CRM systems¬†- Running diagnostic scripts to identify issues- Proposing solutions based on past tickets- Escalating to humans when confidence is low

**Key Learning:** Basic agent loop, simple context management, tool integration

### 4. Content Creation & Research Assistant (Moderate)

**Build Time:** 30‚Äì60 minutes¬†**Complexity:** 2‚Äì3 subagents, moderate context windows

A step up in sophistication. This agent creates polished content by:- Conducting multi-source research with proper citations- Generating drafts adapted to specific style guides¬†- Optimizing content for SEO while maintaining quality- Fact-checking claims against reliable sources- Iterating based on feedback

**Key Learning:** Context synthesis, style adaptation, quality verification

### 3. Financial Portfolio Management Agent (Advanced)

**Build Time:** 1‚Äì2 hours¬†**Complexity:** 2‚Äì3 subagents, complex calculations, regulatory awareness

Enters production-grade territory. This agent manages investments by:- Integrating real-time data from stock, crypto, and real estate APIs- Running Monte Carlo simulations for risk modeling¬†- Generating personalized recommendations based on goals and risk tolerance- Maintaining regulatory compliance (tax implications, reporting requirements)- Providing clear explanations for all recommendations

**Key Learning:** Real-time data integration, numerical accuracy, compliance constraints

### 2. Deep Research & Intelligence Agent (Very Complex)

**Build Time:** 2‚Äì3 hours¬†**Complexity:** 2‚Äì4 subagents, extensive research loops, long sessions

Pushing the boundaries. This agent conducts comprehensive research by:- Synthesizing information across documents, academic papers, APIs, and web sources- Coordinating parallel research tracks via specialized subagents¬†- Verifying sources and tracking conflicting information- Maintaining context across hours of investigation- Producing structured reports with full citations

**Key Learning:** Parallel subagent coordination, source verification, context persistence

### 1. Hollywood Decision-Making: The Greenlighting Agent (Most Complex)

**Build Time:** Few hours for prototype¬†**Complexity:** 4‚Äì5 specialized subagents, high-stakes decisions, hybrid AI-human workflow

The showcase for what‚Äôs possible. This agent evaluates whether to greenlight a film or TV project‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa decision involving hundreds of millions of dollars. It represents peak complexity because:

- **Multiple specialized subagents** working in concert- **High-stakes decisions** requiring careful validation- **Hybrid workflows** that augment rather than replace human judgment¬†- **Measurable outcomes** that can be validated against actual performance- **Scalable complexity** from quick assessment to deep due diligence

This is what we‚Äôll build together.

## Deep Dive: The Greenlighting Agent

When I set out to showcase the Claude Agent SDK‚Äôs capabilities, I faced a challenge: identifying a project that would demonstrate real-world complexity without being purely theoretical. Financial analysis? Too technical. Legal document review? Too specialized. Then it clicked: **Hollywood greenlighting decisions**.

Film and TV greenlight decisions are perfect for demonstrating agentic AI because they‚Äôre:- **Comprehensible**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäEveryone understands movies- **Complex**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäThey involve market analysis, creative assessment, financial modeling, and competitive positioning¬†- **High-stakes**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäStudios bet $50M-$300M on these decisions- **Measurable**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäBox office results validate predictions- **Hybrid by nature**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäAI can inform, but humans must decide

### From Prototype to Production

The code is available at [https://github.com/Laksh-star/greenlighting-agent](https://github.com/Laksh-star/greenlighting-agent). This isn‚Äôt a toy example‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs a functional prototype demonstrating production-ready patterns.

**Running it is simple:**

```bashpython main.py‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääproject ‚ÄúSci-fi thriller about AI rebellion‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbudget 50000000```

**What happens:** The agent completes a comprehensive analysis in 5‚Äì15 minutes, generating:- Market analysis based on genre trends- Script evaluation framework¬†- Financial projections and risk assessment- Competitive positioning analysis- Go/No-Go recommendation with confidence score

But here‚Äôs what‚Äôs important: **the prototype demonstrates scalable complexity**. The same architecture that delivers insights in 5 minutes can support hour-long interactive sessions or multi-day due diligence processes.

### Three Operating Modes

The power isn‚Äôt in a single execution time‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs in the **depth of interaction** the architecture enables:

| Mode | Duration | Use Case | Characteristics ||‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää|‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää|‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää|‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî -|| **Quick Assessment** | 5‚Äì15 min | Initial screening, proof-of-concept | Single-pass analysis, basic checks, Go/No-Go || **Interactive Analysis** | 30‚Äì90 min | Decision workshops, scenario planning | Human-guided exploration, ‚ÄúWhat if?‚Äù scenarios, comparative analysis || **Deep Due Diligence** | Multi-session | Major franchise decisions, board presentations | Multi-day analysis, board-ready materials, extensive modeling |

**Quick Assessment** (what the prototype currently does):- Automated single-pass analysis- Market viability check- Financial feasibility assessment¬†- Clear recommendation with reasoning

**Interactive Analysis** (achievable with extensions):- ‚ÄúWhat if we cast Actor X instead of Y?‚Äù- ‚ÄúCompare three different budget allocations‚Äù- ‚ÄúHow does this perform in international markets?‚Äù- Multiple financial scenarios with sensitivity analysis

**Deep Due Diligence** (production implementation):- Multi-day research sessions- Integration with proprietary studio data- Detailed talent availability and cost analysis¬†- Board-ready investment thesis- Compliance and audit trails

This scalability‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääfrom prototype to production‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääis what makes the Agent SDK powerful.

### Architecture: The Five Specialized Subagents

The greenlighting agent orchestrates five specialized subagents, each focused on a specific domain:

#### 1. Market Intelligence Subagent

**Responsibility:** Understanding audience demand and trends

This subagent analyzes:- Box office performance of similar films in the genre- Genre popularity trends over the past 5‚Äì10 years¬†- Demographic preferences (age groups, regions, streaming vs. theatrical)- Seasonal timing and release window optimization- Audience sentiment from social media and review aggregators

**Data Sources:** TMDB API, Box Office Mojo patterns, historical performance databases

#### 2. Script Analysis Subagent

**Responsibility:** Evaluating creative quality and appeal

This subagent assesses:- Story structure and narrative coherence- Character development and relatability- Dialogue quality and authenticity¬†- Originality vs. familiarity balance- Adaptation potential (if based on existing IP)

**Approach:** Pattern matching against successful films, identifying creative strengths and weaknesses

#### 3. Financial Modeling Subagent

**Responsibility:** Projecting costs and revenues

This subagent calculates:- Production budget breakdown (above-the-line, below-the-line, post-production)¬†- Marketing and distribution costs- Revenue projections (theatrical, streaming, international, ancillary)- Break-even analysis and ROI scenarios- Risk assessment with confidence intervals

**Methods:** Comparable film analysis, regression models, Monte Carlo simulations

#### 4. Competitive Analysis Subagent

**Responsibility:** Understanding market positioning

This subagent evaluates:- Competing releases in the same window- Studio positioning and differentiation¬†- Talent availability and associated costs- Distribution strategy (wide release, limited, streaming)- International market potential

**Focus:** Strategic timing and differentiation from competitors

#### 5. Orchestrator Agent

**Responsibility:** Synthesis and recommendation

The orchestrator:- Receives insights from all four specialized subagents- Identifies contradictions or concerns across analyses¬†- Weights different factors based on project type- Generates executive summary with clear recommendation- Provides confidence scores and key risk factors

### Feature Comparison Matrix

To understand where the Greenlighting Agent sits in complexity:

| Feature | Greenlighting | Financial Portfolio | Research | Support ||‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî -|‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää|‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää-|‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää|‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äî -|| **Subagents** | 4‚Äì5 specialized | 2‚Äì3 | 2‚Äì4 | 1‚Äì2 || **Quick Run** | 5‚Äì15 min | 5‚Äì10 min | 10‚Äì30 min | 2‚Äì5 min || **Interactive** | 30‚Äì90 min | 20‚Äì60 min | 1‚Äì3 hours | 5‚Äì15 min || **API Integrations** | TMDB, Box Office, Financial | Market Data, News APIs | Academic, Web, Internal | CRM, KB || **Decision Stakes** | Very High ($100M+) | High ($10K-$1M) | Medium | Low-Medium || **Output** | Executive Report | Investment Recs | Research Report | Resolution Plan || **Readiness** | Prototype | Buildable | Buildable | Easy |

The greenlighting agent represents the upper bound of what a few hours of development with the Agent SDK can achieve.

## Implementation Journey

Building the greenlighting agent required solving several technical challenges. Here‚Äôs what worked‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand what didn‚Äôt.

### Environment Setup: Why NOT Google Colab

The first instinct was to prototype in Google Colab. **This was a mistake.** Here‚Äôs why Colab doesn‚Äôt work for Agent SDK projects:

‚ùå **Session timeouts**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäColab disconnects after inactivity, killing long-running agents¬†‚ùå **Temporary file system**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäStorage gets wiped when runtime disconnects¬†‚ùå **Poor persistence**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäNo reliable way to save agent state between sessions‚ùå **Security concerns**‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäLess secure for API key management in shared notebooks

### Recommended Approaches

#### 1. Local Python Environment (What We Used)

**Advantages:**- Full control over sessions and file persistence- Best for testing MCP integrations¬†- Secure credential management via `.env` files- Easy debugging with full IDE support

**Setup:**```bash# Clone the repogit clone https://github.com/Laksh-star/greenlighting-agentcd greenlighting-agent

# Install dependenciespip install -r requirements.txt

# Configure API keys in¬†.envANTHROPIC_API_KEY=your_key_hereTMDB_API_KEY=your_tmdb_key```

#### 2. Streamlit/Gradio Web App

**Best for:** Demos and stakeholder presentations

Create a nice UI for the greenlighting agent that non-technical stakeholders can interact with. Deploy to Streamlit Cloud or Hugging Face Spaces for easy sharing.

#### 3. Replit or GitHub Codespaces

**Best for:** Team collaboration

Persistent cloud environment with built-in secret management. Great for remote teams working on the same agent.

### Building Blocks: Core Components

#### 1. MCP Server Integration

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) standardizes how agents connect to external data sources. For the greenlighting agent:

```python# Connect to TMDB via MCPmcp_client = MCPClient()tmdb_server = mcp_client.connect(‚Äútmdb://api.themoviedb.org‚Äù)

# Query for similar filmssimilar_films = tmdb_server.search({¬†‚Äúgenre‚Äù: ‚Äúsci-fi thriller‚Äù,¬†‚Äúrelease_year_min‚Äù: 2019,¬†‚Äúbox_office_min‚Äù: 50000000})```

MCP‚Äôs standardized interface means switching data sources requires minimal code changes.

#### 2. Context Window Management

Long analyses require careful context management. The SDK‚Äôs built-in prompt caching helps significantly:

```python# Cached context persists across callswith agent.cached_context([¬†market_data,¬†historical_performance,¬†genre_trends]):¬†# Subsequent analyses reuse this context¬†# Saving tokens and reducing latency¬†analysis = agent.analyze(project)```

#### 3. Subagent Communication

Subagents coordinate through a simple message-passing interface:

```python# Market subagent completes analysismarket_result = market_subagent.analyze(project)

# Pass to financial subagent for modelingfinancial_result = finance_subagent.model(¬†project,¬†market_assumptions=market_result.assumptions)

# Orchestrator synthesizesrecommendation = orchestrator.synthesize([¬†market_result,¬†script_result,¬†¬†financial_result,¬†competitive_result])```

#### 4. Error Handling & Verification

Every step includes validation:

```pythondef analyze_market(project):¬†try:¬†data = fetch_market_data(project)¬†¬†# Verify data quality¬†if not validate_data_completeness(data):¬†return fallback_analysis(project)¬†¬†analysis = run_analysis(data)¬†¬†# Verify analysis makes sense¬†if not passes_sanity_checks(analysis):¬†log_warning(‚ÄúAnalysis failed sanity check‚Äù)¬†return rerun_with_different_params()¬†¬†return analysis¬†¬†except APIError as e:¬†log_error(f‚ÄùAPI failure: {e}‚Äù)¬†return retry_with_backoff()```

#### 5. Human-in-the-Loop Checkpoints

For high-stakes decisions, the agent pauses for human review:

```python# Generate recommendationrecommendation = generate_recommendation(all_analyses)

# Present to humanif recommendation.confidence < 0.8:¬†human_review = request_human_input(¬†recommendation,¬†uncertainties=recommendation.risk_factors¬†)¬†recommendation = incorporate_human_feedback(¬†recommendation,¬†human_review¬†)```

### Code Architecture Patterns

#### The Agent Loop

At its core, every agent follows this pattern:

```pythondef agent_loop(task):¬†context = []¬†complete = False¬†¬†while not complete:¬†# Gather context¬†new_info = gather_relevant_context(task, context)¬†context.append(new_info)¬†¬†# Decide action¬†action = decide_next_action(task, context)¬†¬†# Execute¬†result = execute_action(action)¬†¬†# Verify¬†if verify_result(result, task):¬†complete = True¬†else:¬†# Add verification failure to context¬†context.append(VerificationFailure(result))¬†¬†return result```

This simple loop handles surprising complexity when each component is well-designed.

#### Subagent Delegation

Parallel execution speeds up analysis:

```pythonimport asyncio

async def orchestrate_analysis(project):¬†# Launch all subagents in parallel¬†results = await asyncio.gather(¬†market_subagent.analyze(project),¬†script_subagent.evaluate(project),¬†finance_subagent.model(project),¬†competitive_subagent.assess(project)¬†)¬†¬†# Synthesize results¬†market, script, finance, competitive = results¬†¬†return synthesize_recommendation(¬†market_analysis=market,¬†script_assessment=script,¬†financial_model=finance,¬†competitive_position=competitive¬†)```

Going from sequential (20 minutes) to parallel (5 minutes) execution was a significant win.

## Lessons Learned & Best Practices

After building the greenlighting agent, several patterns emerged that apply broadly to Agent SDK development.

### What Works

#### Start Simple, Scale Up Incrementally

The first version was a single agent with no subagents. It worked, but slowly and with lower quality outputs. Adding subagents incrementally‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääfirst market analysis, then financial, then competitive‚Ää‚Äî‚Äälet us validate each piece before adding complexity.

**Lesson:** Don‚Äôt architect for scale on day one. Build the simplest thing that could work, then expand based on actual bottlenecks.

#### Design for Observability from Day One

Comprehensive logging made debugging infinitely easier:

```pythonlogger.info(f‚ÄùMarket subagent starting analysis for {project.title}‚Äù)logger.debug(f‚ÄùFetching comparable films in {project.genre}‚Äù)logger.info(f‚ÄùFound {len(comparables)} comparable films‚Äù)logger.debug(f‚ÄùComparable titles: {[c.title for c in comparables]}‚Äù)```

When something went wrong (and it did, often), logs told the story.

**Lesson:** Log everything. Debug level for details, info level for progress, warnings for anomalies.

#### Build Verification Into Every Step

Early versions trusted API responses and subagent outputs. This led to nonsensical recommendations when data was incomplete or analyses made arithmetic errors.

Adding verification after every step caught issues early:

```pythondef verify_financial_model(model):¬†checks = [¬†model.revenue > model.costs, # Basic sanity¬†0 <= model.roi <= 10.0, # Reasonable ROI range¬†len(model.assumptions) > 0, # Has documented assumptions¬†model.break_even_point > 0 # Positive break-even¬†]¬†¬†if not all(checks):¬†raise VerificationError(‚ÄúFinancial model failed sanity checks‚Äù)```

**Lesson:** Never trust, always verify. Every component should validate its outputs.

#### Embrace Hybrid AI-Human Workflows

The original goal was full automation: input a project, get a decision. Reality was messier. Some decisions needed human judgment‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcreative elements, strategic considerations, risk tolerance.

Embracing hybrid workflows made the agent more useful:

```pythonif recommendation.confidence < CONFIDENCE_THRESHOLD:¬†# Present analysis but request human judgment¬†return HumanReviewRequired(¬†analysis=recommendation,¬†specific_questions=[¬†‚ÄúDoes the creative vision align with studio brand?‚Äù,¬†‚ÄúIs the proposed talent package realistic?‚Äù,¬†‚ÄúAre we comfortable with this risk level?‚Äù¬†]¬†)```

**Lesson:** Augment human decision-making, don‚Äôt try to replace it. Make humans better, faster, more informed‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänot obsolete.

### Common Pitfalls

#### Overcomplicating Initial Architecture

The temptation to build ‚Äúenterprise-ready‚Äù code on day one is strong. Resist it.

Early versions had elaborate error handling, retry logic, circuit breakers, and fallback strategies. Most of it was unused. When we stripped it down to essentials, development accelerated.

**Fix:** Ship the minimum viable agent. Add sophistication when pain points emerge.

#### Underestimating Session Management Needs

Agents that run for minutes need different session management than agents that run for hours.

The greenlighting agent‚Äôs quick runs (5‚Äì15 minutes) need minimal state management. But extending it to interactive sessions revealed gaps‚Ää‚Äî‚Äälost context, forgotten assumptions, missing continuity.

**Fix:** Plan for the longest session you‚Äôll need, even if your prototype doesn‚Äôt require it yet.

#### Neglecting Error Handling in Long-Running Tasks

APIs fail. Networks drop. Rate limits hit. In a 30-second execution, retry logic feels optional. In a 30-minute execution, it‚Äôs essential.

**Fix:** Implement exponential backoff, retry logic, and graceful degradation from the start. Your future self will thank you.

#### Missing Human Oversight for High Stakes

Automating a $100M decision sounds impressive. It‚Äôs also terrifying if something goes wrong.

The greenlighting agent always includes human review for final decisions. It informs and accelerates‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbut the human makes the call.

**Fix:** For high-stakes applications, build in mandatory human checkpoints. Make them easy to invoke, hard to skip.

### Production Readiness Checklist

Going from prototype to production requires:

**Infrastructure:**- [ ] Comprehensive error handling and retry logic- [ ] Logging and monitoring (track every decision)- [ ] Security audit (credential management, data access)- [ ] Rate limiting and cost controls- [ ] Performance optimization (caching, parallel execution)

**Process:**- [ ] Human approval workflows for critical decisions- [ ] Audit trails (who approved what, when)- [ ] Rollback capability (undo bad recommendations)- [ ] A/B testing framework (validate improvements)

**Documentation:**- [ ] Architecture documentation- [ ] API documentation for all subagents- [ ] Runbooks for common issues¬†- [ ] User guides for non-technical stakeholders

**Validation:**- [ ] Unit tests for all subagents- [ ] Integration tests for orchestration- [ ] End-to-end tests with real data- [ ] Backtesting against historical decisions

The greenlighting agent prototype checks about 40% of these boxes. Production would require the full checklist.

## Try It Yourself

The complete prototype is available on GitHub: [https://github.com/Laksh-star/greenlighting-agent](https://github.com/Laksh-star/greenlighting-agent)

This isn‚Äôt a toy example. It demonstrates production-ready patterns:- Multi-subagent orchestration- Real API integrations (TMDB for market data)- Structured output generation- Error handling and validation- Extensible architecture

### Running the Prototype

```bash# Clone the repositorygit clone https://github.com/Laksh-star/greenlighting-agentcd greenlighting-agent

# Install dependenciespip install -r requirements.txt

# Add your API keys to¬†.env fileecho ‚ÄúANTHROPIC_API_KEY=your_anthropic_key‚Äù >>¬†.envecho ‚ÄúTMDB_API_KEY=your_tmdb_key‚Äù >>¬†.env

# Run an analysispython main.py‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääproject ‚ÄúSci-fi thriller about AI rebellion‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbudget 50000000```

**What you‚Äôll get:**

A comprehensive analysis including:- Market viability assessment based on genre trends- Script evaluation framework (structure, character, originality)- Financial projections (costs, revenues, ROI scenarios)¬†- Competitive positioning analysis- Clear Go/No-Go recommendation with confidence score

**Time required:** 5‚Äì15 minutes

### Extending the Prototype

The codebase is structured for extensibility. Some ideas:

**Add new subagents:**```python# Add a talent availability subagenttalent_subagent = TalentSubagent()results = await asyncio.gather(¬†market_subagent.analyze(project),¬†script_subagent.evaluate(project),¬†finance_subagent.model(project),¬†competitive_subagent.assess(project),¬†talent_subagent.assess_availability(project) # New!)```

**Integrate additional data sources via MCP:**```python# Connect to Box Office Mojobox_office_server = mcp_client.connect(‚Äúboxoffice://www.boxofficemojo.com")

# Use richer historical datahistorical_performance = box_office_server.query({¬†‚Äúgenre‚Äù: project.genre,¬†‚Äúyears‚Äù: range(2015, 2025)})```

**Build an interactive mode:**```python# Allow scenario explorationwhile user_has_questions:¬†question = input(‚ÄúWhat scenario would you like to explore? ‚Äú)¬†¬†if ‚Äúbudget‚Äù in question:¬†new_budget = extract_budget(question)¬†rerun_financial_model(project, new_budget)¬†elif ‚Äúcast‚Äù in question:¬†new_cast = extract_cast(question)¬†reevaluate_marketability(project, new_cast)```

### Bonus: Running Without Code (For Non-Developers)

If you‚Äôre a business user curious about the greenlighting agent but uncomfortable with code, you can explore it through Claude Code in VS Code:

1. Install the Claude Code VS Code extension2. Open the project folder in VS Code3. Open the Claude Code panel4. Ask: ‚ÄúWalk me through what this agent does and how I can run it‚Äù5. Claude will guide you step-by-step through:‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäUnderstanding the architecture‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäSetting up your API keys¬†‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäRunning your first analysis‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäModifying the project parameters‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäInterpreting the results

This demonstrates the power of both approaches: **developers build sophisticated agents with the SDK, while business users can explore and customize them through Claude Code**.

## The Future of Agentic AI

The greenlighting agent represents where agentic AI is today. Where is it going?

### Current State: Production-Ready Patterns

Several patterns have matured to production readiness:

**Multi-agent orchestration** is proven. Coordinating specialized subagents produces better results than single generalist agents‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand the Agent SDK makes it straightforward.

**MCP for standardized integrations** solves the N√óM integration problem. Instead of custom connectors for every combination of agent and data source, MCP provides a universal interface.

**Hybrid AI-human workflows** work. Agents that augment human decision-making‚Ää‚Äî‚Äärather than replacing it‚Ää‚Äî‚Äädeliver value faster and with less risk.

**Observable, debuggable systems** are table stakes. Comprehensive logging, error handling, and verification aren‚Äôt optional for production agents.

### Real Business Value Today

The greenlighting agent delivers measurable value:

**Speed:** Minutes to insights vs. days of manual analysis¬†**Thoroughness:** Consistent evaluation of all relevant factors**Scalability:** Analyze dozens of projects in the time it takes to manually evaluate one**Measurability:** Recommendations can be validated against actual outcomes

This isn‚Äôt speculative‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs achievable with a few hours of development.

### Where We‚Äôre Going

#### Industry-Specific Agents Becoming Standard

Every industry has complex decision-making processes that could benefit from agentic AI:

- **Legal:** Document analysis, precedent research, contract review- **Medical:** Diagnosis support, treatment planning, literature review¬†- **Financial:** Investment analysis, risk assessment, compliance checking- **Creative:** As demonstrated, greenlighting decisions, content strategy, audience analysis

The patterns are universal; the specialization is domain-specific.

#### Improved Multi-Agent Orchestration

Current orchestration is relatively static‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwe define subagents and their roles upfront. Future systems will:

- **Dynamically form teams** based on task requirements- **Self-organize** to optimize for different objectives¬†- **Learn from outcomes** to improve coordination- **Handle uncertainty** more gracefully when subagents disagree

#### Better Human-AI Collaboration Interfaces

Today‚Äôs interfaces are functional but clunky. Future systems will:

- **Explain reasoning** more transparently- **Request help** more naturally when uncertain- **Learn preferences** from human feedback¬†- **Adapt communication style** to different stakeholders

The goal: collaboration so seamless it feels like working with a talented colleague, not wrestling with a tool.

### Call to Action

The tools are here. The patterns are proven. The barrier isn‚Äôt technical anymore‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs imagination.

**For developers:**- Start with a use case that matches your complexity level- Build a prototype in a few hours, not weeks¬†- Share your work with the community- Contribute patterns and learnings back to the ecosystem

**For business users:**- Try Claude Code + VS Code to explore what‚Äôs possible- Identify high-value decision-making processes in your work- Partner with developers to build custom agents- Start with quick wins before tackling transformational projects

**For everyone:**- The future of work involves humans and AI agents collaborating- The best outcomes come from hybrid workflows that leverage both¬†- Start experimenting now to understand what works for your context- Share what you learn

## Resources

### Documentation- [Claude Agent SDK Documentation](https://docs.claude.com/en/api/agent-sdk/overview)- [Model Context Protocol Specification](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/)- [Claude Code Documentation](https://docs.claude.com/en/docs/claude-code)

### Code & Examples¬†- [Greenlighting Agent (this article)](https://github.com/Laksh-star/greenlighting-agent)- [Agent SDK Official Examples](https://github.com/anthropics/anthropic-sdk-python/tree/main/examples)- [MCP Server Examples](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/servers)

### Community- [Claude Developers Discord](https://discord.gg/anthropic)- [r/ClaudeAI](https://reddit.com/r/ClaudeAI)- [Agent SDK GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/anthropics/anthropic-sdk-python/discussions)

### Further Reading- [Building Effective Agents](https://www.anthropic.com/engineering/building-effective-agents) (Anthropic)- [How Claude Code is Built](https://newsletter.pragmaticengineer.com/p/how-claude-code-is-built) (Pragmatic Engineer)- [Model Context Protocol Deep Dive](https://spec.modelcontextprotocol.io/) (MCP Spec)

## About This Project

This greenlighting agent prototype was built over a few hours to demonstrate the Claude Agent SDK‚Äôs capabilities. The biggest challenge wasn‚Äôt the implementation‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit was identifying a project that showcased real-world complexity while remaining accessible and interesting.

The prototype demonstrates:- Production-ready multi-agent architecture (at prototype scale)- Real API integrations and data synthesis¬†- Practical subagent coordination patterns- Extensible design for future enhancements

**A meta-lesson:** This entire article‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääfrom outline to final draft‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwas created in collaboration with Claude Sonnet 4.5, showcasing the collaborative potential of AI agents in content creation. The future of development isn‚Äôt humans OR AI‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs humans AND AI, working together.

**What will you build?**

The Agent SDK provides the foundation. The patterns are proven. The community is growing. Your move.

title: I Built a Hollywood Multi-Agent System Using AI: A Meta Journey with Claude‚Ä¶
content:
### I Built a Hollywood Multi-Agent System Using AI: A Meta Journey with¬†Claude‚Ä¶


‚Ä¶and Claude Agent¬†SDK

The Irony Wasn‚Äôt Lost on¬†Me

I wanted to showcase the Claude Agent SDK‚Äôs capabilities by building something complex and real-world. After going through a list of five use cases ranked by complexity‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääfrom customer support bots to deep research agents‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääone stood out: a movie/TV greenlighting agent. (which would actually become a multi-agent system).

The irony? I built a multi-agent AI system to help studios decide which movies to make‚Ä¶ by asking an AI to help me build it

This is that story.

The Starting Point: Ranking Use Cases by Complexity

My first conversation with Claude wasn‚Äôt ‚Äúbuild me an agent.‚Äù It was: ‚ÄúCheck out the latest on Claude agent SDK and suggest 5 use cases we can build in descending order of complexity.‚Äù

Claude came back with five options, from most to least complex:1. Deep Research & Intelligence Agent2. Financial Portfolio Management Agent¬†3. Customer Support Automation Agent4. Content Creation & Research Assistant5. Simple task automation agents

Then I asked about a sixth option that wasn‚Äôt on the list: a movie/TV project greenlighting agent.

Claude‚Äôs response surprised me. It didn‚Äôt just say ‚Äúyeah, build it.‚Äù It analyzed where it would fit in the complexity spectrum and concluded this would be #2 in complexity‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääjust below the deep research agent‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbecause it required:

The hook: This was comprehensible (everyone understands movies), complex (true multi-agent orchestration), measurable (we can validate against actual box office), and interesting (people want to read about Hollywood).

The challenge: I‚Äôm not a Hollywood executive. I don‚Äôt have proprietary studio data. And I had maybe a few hours to build this.

The solution: Use Claude to collaboratively design and build it.

The Environment Decision: Why Not Google¬†Colab?

My first instinct was practical: ‚ÄúCan we build this in Google Colab?‚Äù It‚Äôs familiar, easy to share, and requires no local setup.

Claude‚Äôs response was decisive: **‚ÄùNot ideal for this project.‚Äù**

It laid out why:

‚ùå Session Management Issues- Colab timeouts after inactivity- The Agent SDK needs persistent sessions for long-running analysis¬†- Context gets lost when the runtime disconnects

‚ùå File System Limitations- Colab‚Äôs file system is temporary and gets wiped- The agent needs to store market research, analysis results- MCP servers expect persistent local file systems

‚ùå API Key Security- Less secure credential management in notebooks- Notebooks are often shared, risking exposure

‚ùå Poor Agent Loop Fit- Agent SDK is designed for conversational, iterative workflows- Colab‚Äôs cell-based execution doesn‚Äôt match the pattern

Instead, Claude recommended:1. Local Python environment (best control and security)2. Streamlit/Gradio (for stakeholder demos)3. Replit or GitHub Codespaces (for team collaboration)

I went with local setup.

First lesson: Good AI assistance sometimes means being told ‚Äúno, that won‚Äôt work well‚Äù before you waste time finding out the hard way.

Designing the Multi-Agent Architecture

Once we settled on the environment, I asked for an overview: ‚ÄúWill this be multiple agents? Where does it stack up in complexity?‚Äù

Claude didn‚Äôt just answer‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit created a complete breakdown:

The 7 Specialized Subagents:1. Market Research Agent‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcomparable titles, box office trends2. Audience Intelligence Agent‚Ää‚Äî‚Äädemographics, social sentiment3. Financial Modeling Agent‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäROI projections, revenue forecasts4. Competitive Analysis Agent‚Ää‚Äî‚Äämarket saturation, release timing5. Creative Assessment Agent‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääscript elements, cast potential6. Risk Analysis Agent‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääproduction risks, cultural sensitivity7. Master Orchestrator‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääsynthesizes everything into a final recommendation

Then it gave me a feature comparison table showing how this stacked up against other use cases (news aggregator, movie recommender, content repurposing). The greenlighting agent ranked highest in subagent complexity, MCP integration needs, and slash command requirements.

Second lesson: AI assistants excel at structured thinking. The comparison table helped me understand not just what to build, but how ambitious it was relative to alternatives.

Building It: From Architecture to¬†Code

With the architecture clear, Claude started generating the actual project structure. It didn‚Äôt just dump code‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit created a complete, production-ready project layout:

Third lesson: AI doesn‚Äôt just write code snippets. It can scaffold entire projects with proper structure, documentation, and best practices baked in.

The Financial Modeling Challenge

One of the most interesting moments was building the financial modeling agent. I needed it to project revenue for a film based on budget, genre, and market conditions.

Claude created a model using industry multipliers:

But it also added this note in the comments:

Fourth lesson: Good AI assistance is honest about simplifications. It built something that works for a prototype while acknowledging production systems would need more sophistication.

The financial agent generated three scenarios (conservative, moderate, optimistic) with ROI calculations for each. For streaming projects, it used a completely different model based on subscriber acquisition value rather than box office multipliers.

The Integration Work

Claude built the TMDB API integration to fetch comparable films:

It created helper functions for genre ID mapping, error handling for missing data, and rate limiting to avoid hitting API limits.

The Risk Analysis¬†Agent

The last major agent Claude built was for risk assessment. This one was particularly interesting because it had to identify different *types* of risks:

- Production risks (VFX complexity, location challenges)- Market risks (genre saturation, competition)- Creative risks (untested concepts, controversial themes)- Financial risks (budget overruns, revenue uncertainty)

Claude created a structured approach where the agent would analyze each risk category and generate a matrix with mitigation strategies. It even included logic for identifying ‚Äúdealbreakers‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Äärisks so severe they should trigger a NO-GO recommendation regardless of other factors.

The Result: A Working Prototype in¬†Hours

After a few hours of this collaborative building process, I had a complete project:

Interactive Mode

Basic Analysis

What happened: The agent ran all the subagents (some in parallel using async), gathered market data from TMDB, performed financial modeling, assessed risks, and generated a comprehensive recommendation‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääall in 5‚Äì15 minutes.

The output included:- Market analysis with comparable film performance- Financial projections (conservative, moderate, optimistic scenarios)- Risk assessment across multiple categories- Final GO/CONDITIONAL/NO-GO recommendation with confidence score

The kicker: When I first ran it, it actually worked. No major debugging sessions. The architecture Claude designed held up.

The code is on GitHub:

What I Learned About AI-Assisted Development (yet¬†again)

Building this agent collaboratively taught me several lessons:

1. AI Pushes Back on Bad Ideas

When I suggested Google Colab, Claude didn‚Äôt just go along with it. It explained why that wouldn‚Äôt work and suggested better alternatives. This saved me from discovering the hard way that Colab sessions timeout and wipe your work.

2. Structure Before Code

We spent significant time on architecture‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhat agents to build, how they‚Äôd communicate, what data sources we‚Äôd need‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbefore writing substantial code. This front-loading of design made the implementation much smoother.

3. AI Excels at Scaffolding

The complete project structure, README, requirements.txt, proper Python package organization‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäClaude generated all of this following best practices I might have skipped in a prototype.

4. Domain Knowledge Still Matters

I had to guide decisions about what made sense for the film industry. Claude provided technical implementation, but understanding *what* to build and *why* certain metrics mattered came from me.

5. Iteration Is Fast

Want to change how financial modeling works? Update the multipliers? Add a new risk category? The iteration speed is incredible compared to building alone. We explored multiple approaches to problems quickly.

6. The Output Feels Production-Adjacent

This isn‚Äôt a hacky proof-of-concept. It has proper error handling, configuration management, documentation, and extensible architecture. Claude encoded production best practices into a prototype.

The Meta¬†Lesson

Here‚Äôs the most important insight: I built an AI agent using AI assistance, and it worked.

The greenlighting agent demonstrates sophisticated multi-agent orchestration, real API integration, financial modeling, and decision synthesis. It would have taken me days to build alone. With Claude‚Äôs help, it took hours.

But Claude didn‚Äôt ‚Äúwrite the code for me.‚Äù We collaborated:- I provided domain understanding and architectural vision- Claude provided implementation expertise and anticipated problems- I caught logical errors and refined requirements- Claude generated boilerplate and suggested best practices

The result is better than either of us would have produced alone.

What This Means for the¬†Future

If I can build a sophisticated multi-agent system in a few hours with AI assistance, what does that mean for software development?

This experience with Claude Agent SDK mirrors what developers are discovering across the ecosystem‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhether using Cursor for agentic coding, Replit Agent for full-stack builds, or other AI-native development tools. The pattern is consistent: AI assistance is fundamentally changing how we build software.

It doesn‚Äôt mean developers are obsolete. It means:

1. The barrier to building sophisticated systems is dropping dramatically2. Iteration speed is accelerating (we went through many designs quickly)3. Best practices are becoming accessible (Claude encoded years of wisdom)4. The bottleneck shifts from implementation to design (what should we build?)

The developers who thrive will be those who:- Understand problems deeply- Can evaluate and refine AI-generated solutions- Design robust architectures- Know when to trust AI and when to push back

Try It¬†Yourself

The greenlighting agent is open source:

Clone it. Run it. Extend it. And pay attention to how you extend it.

Will you ask Claude for help? Probably.Will you blindly accept its suggestions? Hopefully not.Will you iterate faster than you would alone? Definitely.

That‚Äôs the future of development: humans and AI, collaborating to build things neither could build alone.

The Recursive Irony

This article about using AI to build an AI agent was itself written with AI assistance. Claude and I iterated on the outline, refined the structure, and crafted the narrative together.

The tools are here. The patterns are proven. The only question is: what will you build?

And who‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääor what‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwill you build it with?

References & Resources

Project Repository

Claude Agent SDK

Related Tools Mentioned

Further Reading on AI-Assisted Development

### Exploring the Updated LM Studio and Embedchain: Improved Functionality and Performance


In a previous article, I discussed certain challenges associated with LM Studio and the associated server calls.

I am pleased to report that these issues have been addressed in the latest version of the software.

Here is a simple sample code that operates with a Local LLM. In this instance, I‚Äôm using the version mistral-7b-instruct-v0.1.Q4_K_M.gguf again.

There‚Äôs also another example code that uses both history and context features. This one works well too.

In this article, I share a simple code example that uses Embedchain. Instead of using the open AI API, this code uses the local LLM provided by LM Studio.

A brief explanation about Embedchain.

Embedchain.ai is an open-source data platform for building and deploying machine learning models. It enables users to load, index, retrieve, and sync unstructured data, and create RAG applications with a suite of diverse APIs. Embedchain is designed for a diverse range of users, from AI professionals like Data Scientists and Machine Learning Engineers to those just starting, including college students, independent developers, and hobbyists. It provides a wide range of options to customize the app, including custom configurations for the model and data sources.

Just as I did in the previous article, I‚Äôve written a piece of code here. This code is inspired by an example I found on the Embedchain website and I‚Äôve adapted it using ChatGPT.

Here, I‚Äôve outlined a series of steps from this specific example, following the tips I shared in my previous article. This comes after doing more tests and troubleshooting.

In the coming weeks, I aim to use this method with other embedchain applications and try it with different local LLMs.

### Learning Multi-Agent Systems with DSPy: A Hands-On¬†Guide


The multi-agent AI systems market is projected to reach ~$5.4 billion by 2024, per industry reports. While frameworks like CrewAI and AutoGen make multi-agent coordination accessible, DSPy offers a programming approach that makes agent interactions observable and optimizable. Drawing from concepts explored in the DeepLearning.AI and Databricks DSPy course, let‚Äôs learn how it works by building a simple cinema recommendation system.


### What We‚Äôll Build: A Learning Example¬†üé¨


To understand DSPy‚Äôs multi-agent capabilities, we‚Äôll build a straightforward movie recommendation system with four coordinating agents. This isn‚Äôt groundbreaking AI‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs a clear example that demonstrates key DSPy concepts:

What makes this a good learning example:

The goal isn‚Äôt to revolutionize movie recommendations‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs to understand how DSPy handles multi-agent coordination, observability, and optimization in a concrete, working system.


### DSPy‚Äôs Approach to Multi-Agent Systems¬†üèóÔ∏è


Before diving into code, let‚Äôs understand what makes DSPy (Declarative Self-improving Python) different for multi-agent systems.

Signatures: Typed Agent Contracts

In DSPy, every agent starts with a Signature‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa typed contract defining inputs and outputs:

Agent-to-Agent Communication

DSPy‚Äôs ReAct modules let agents call other agents as tools:

This creates observable agent coordination‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääevery interaction could be traced through MLflow.


### System Architecture: Four Coordinating Agents¬†üèóÔ∏è


Before implementing, let‚Äôs understand the architecture we‚Äôre building:

Key Architecture Features:

ü§ñ True Agent-to-Agent Communication: Orchestrator calls specialists as tools üìä Complete Observability: Every interaction traced through MLflowüéØ Specialized Expertise: Each agent masters a specific domain üîß Real-World Integration: TMDB API + LlamaIndex + production patterns ‚ö° Autonomous Coordination: Agents decide their own strategies

This architecture demonstrates DSPy‚Äôs approach: programming agent coordination rather than configuring workflows, with full observability into every decision point.


### Implementation: Step by Step¬†üíª


Step 1: Environment Setup

Why Databricks Managed MLflow

This tutorial uses Databricks‚Äô managed MLflow service because it provides enterprise-grade observability out of the box. The managed service automatically handles scaling, security, and collaborative experiment tracking‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääessential for multi-agent systems where you need to trace complex agent interactions across team members. Unlike local MLflow setups, the managed service integrates seamlessly with Databricks‚Äô data platform, provides built-in authentication, and eliminates infrastructure management overhead. For learning DSPy‚Äôs multi-agent capabilities, this gives us production-quality observability without setup complexity.

Step 2: TMDB Integration

For real movie data with quality filtering, we use an enhanced TMDB client:

Step 3: Agent¬†Tools

Each agent needs tools that integrate real movie data and DSPy signatures:

Step 4: Specialist Agents

Now we create our four specialist agents:

Step 5: Agent Coordination with Production Wrapper

Here Agents will call other agents as tools. Here‚Äôs our production wrapper:

Step 6: Testing with Interactive Interface

Let‚Äôs test our system with a Gradio interface that shows the agent coordination:


### Step 7: Observing Agent Coordination


The real value is in MLflow observability. When you run the system, MLflow (on Databricks) automatically captures:


### What This Demonstrates About DSPy¬†üîç


Our simple cinema system illustrates several key DSPy concepts:

1. Programming vs Configuration

Unlike frameworks that use YAML or conversational setup, DSPy treats agent coordination as code. This means:

2. Automatic Observability

Every agent interaction is traced without additional setup:

3. Systematic Optimization

While we didn‚Äôt optimize in this tutorial, DSPy can automatically improve:

4. True Agent Coordination

Agents make autonomous decisions about:


### Production Considerations üöÄ


To make this production-ready, you‚Äôd want to add:


### Key Takeaways üåü


This cinema recommendation system demonstrates DSPy‚Äôs approach to multi-agent coordination:

‚úÖ Typed interfaces make agent communication clear and debuggable¬†‚úÖ Programming patterns bring software engineering practices to AI systems¬†‚úÖ Automatic tracing provides complete observability into agent decisions ‚úÖ Modular architecture allows independent development and testing of agents¬†‚úÖ Real integration with external APIs shows practical implementation

The broader lesson: DSPy treats multi-agent systems as software engineering problems, not just coordination challenges. This makes them more maintainable, debuggable, and optimizable than configuration-based approaches.

Whether you‚Äôre building customer service agents, data analysis workflows, or creative content systems, the patterns demonstrated here‚Ää‚Äî‚Äätyped coordination, complete observability, and systematic optimization‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääprovide a foundation for reliable multi-agent architectures.

Multi-agent systems are rapidly becoming standard in AI development. DSPy‚Äôs programming approach ensures they remain maintainable as they grow in complexity.

Want to try this yourself? The complete implementation is available on GitHub. Use it as a starting point to understand DSPy‚Äôs multi-agent capabilities, then adapt the patterns to your own use case. title: How Specifications Can Become the Future of Programming
content:
### How Specifications Can Become the Future of Programming


Why the most valuable programmers of tomorrow will first specify before touching a compiler

In a recent talk, Sean from OpenAI‚Äôs alignment research team made a startling claim: code is only 10‚Äì20% of the value you bring as a developer. The other 80‚Äì90%? Structured communication.

His presentation on ‚Äúthe coming of the new code‚Äù (watch here) challenges how we think about software development. Drawing from OpenAI‚Äôs own Model Specification (released publicly) as a living example, Sean argues that specifications, not code, are becoming the primary artifacts of software development.

The shift is already happening, and the implications go far beyond software engineering.


### The Hidden Truth About ‚ÄúVibe¬†Coding‚Äù


If you‚Äôve used AI to write code, you‚Äôve experienced something strange. You describe what you want in natural language, get working code back, and then‚Ä¶ throw away your prompt. You carefully version control the generated code while discarding the specification that created it.

Sean calls this the fundamental anti-pattern: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like shredding the source and carefully version controlling the binary.‚Äù

In traditional programming, we never keep compiled binaries‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwe regenerate them from source code every time. But with AI-assisted development, we‚Äôre doing the opposite. We‚Äôre treating the generated code as precious and the human intention as disposable.


### Why Your Real Job Isn‚Äôt Writing¬†Code


Most of what developers actually do has nothing to do with syntax or algorithms. The real work happens in conversations:

Notice something? Every step except ‚Äútranslating‚Äù is pure communication. And as AI models get more sophisticated, that translation step becomes increasingly automated.

The bottleneck isn‚Äôt code‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs clarity of intention.


### Specifications in Practice: Movie Management Analyser


Let me show you what this looks like with a real project: an AI system that analyzes movies for management lessons.

Instead of starting with code, you can begin with a comprehensive specification document:

The Complete Specification

From Specification to Working¬†System

Here‚Äôs how you can put this specification-driven approach into practice. Start by creating your specification file:

Now you can use any AI coding tool to implement this specification. While we‚Äôll use Claude Code as our example, this approach works equally well with other AI agents like Bolt, Windsurf, Cursor, or any agentic coding tool:

With Claude¬†Code:

Claude Code can execute bash commands using the¬†! prefix, run custom slash commands from¬†.claude/commands directory, and accept piped input from other CLI tools. You can also use the -p flag for headless mode to get direct output without entering the interactive interface

With Other AI¬†Tools:

The AI tool will read your specification and generate a complete system including:

All generated from your comprehensive specification document.

What You¬†Get

When you implement ‚Äú12 Angry Men‚Äù analysis, the system produces output following your exact specification:

The system automatically handles your edge cases‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääreturning ‚ÄúInsufficient content‚Äù for vague inputs and ‚ÄúNo management lessons identified‚Äù when appropriate, exactly as specified.

Why This Specification Approach¬†Works

This comprehensive specification demonstrates several key advantages of Sean‚Äôs approach:

1. Specifications as Executable Documentation

Your specification includes everything an AI needs to build the system:

2. Version Control for Requirements

Notice the specification includes version tracking and change logs. This treats your requirements as code:

3. Universal Compatibility

Because the specification is written in natural language, it works with any AI coding tool. Whether you use Claude Code, Bolt, Windsurf, or future tools, the specification remains your durable asset.

Expanding with Multiple Specification Files

You can enhance your system by adding complementary specification files:

Add API Specification

Add Performance Requirements

How Multiple Specifications Enhance Implementation

When you provide AI coding tools with multiple specification files, they can:

Generate More Sophisticated Systems

Make Informed Technical Decisions

Ensure Consistent Quality

Multiple specifications create a comprehensive blueprint that ensures:

You can reference all specifications when working with any AI coding tool:

Iterating Through Specification Updates

The power of this approach becomes clear when you need to evolve your system. Instead of hunting through code to understand what needs to change, you update your specifications and regenerate:

Adding New Features

Update your main specification:

Enhancing Performance

Update your performance specification:

Any AI coding tool can then update your system to meet the new specifications while maintaining compliance with existing requirements.

This is exactly what Sean meant by ‚Äúthe coming of the new code‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääspecifications become your primary programming interface, and traditional coding becomes an implementation detail handled by AI tools.


### Getting Started


You don‚Äôt need to wait. Here‚Äôs how to start using specification-driven development:

1. Write Before You¬†Code

For your next AI project, create a specification document with:

2. Make It Executable

Use tools like Claude Code to generate implementations directly from specifications. The specification is your source code; the generated system is your compiled binary.

3. Iterate Through Specifications

Need changes? Update the spec and regenerate. Don‚Äôt patch generated code‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääevolve the specification.

4. Measure Compliance

Build evaluation systems that check outputs against specifications. This becomes your new unit testing.


### When Specifications Aren‚Äôt¬†Enough


While specification-driven development offers significant advantages, it‚Äôs important to recognize scenarios where this approach has limitations:

Performance-Critical Systems: When microsecond response times matter or you‚Äôre optimizing for specific hardware, you may need direct control over memory management, algorithm implementation, and system-level optimizations that are difficult to specify at a high level.

Novel Algorithm Development: If you‚Äôre researching new algorithms or solving previously unsolved computational problems, the specification itself may be unclear or evolving. In these cases, exploratory coding and iterative experimentation remain essential.

Complex Mathematical Computations: Some domains require deep mathematical expertise where the ‚Äúhow‚Äù is as important as the ‚Äúwhat.‚Äù Financial modeling, scientific computing, and cryptographic implementations often need human insight into mathematical nuances.

Rapidly Evolving Requirements: In early-stage startups or research projects where requirements change daily, spending time on comprehensive specifications might slow discovery. Sometimes you need to code first to understand what you‚Äôre actually trying to build.

Legacy System Integration: When working with complex existing codebases, understanding the current implementation details becomes crucial for successful integration, regardless of how well you can specify the desired outcome.

Debugging and Troubleshooting: When AI-generated code fails in unexpected ways, developers still need the skills to read, understand, and modify the implementation directly.

The goal isn‚Äôt to eliminate coding skills entirely, but to recognize that specification writing is becoming an increasingly valuable complement to traditional programming abilities.


### The Competitive Advantage


Organizations that adopt specification-driven development gain:


### The Bottom¬†Line


Sean‚Äôs prediction is becoming reality: ‚ÄúThe person who communicates most effectively is the most valuable programmer.‚Äù

We‚Äôre moving from syntax-focused programming to intention-focused programming. The developers who master structured communication‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwho become specification engineers rather than just code writers‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwill define the next decade of software development.

The new code isn‚Äôt code at all. It‚Äôs the clear, executable expression of human intention.

The tools like Claude Code exist today that can transform specifications into working systems. GitHub version controls markdown as easily as code. AI models evaluate compliance in real-time.

What will you specify into existence?


### Thank you for being a part of the community


Before you go:

### Beyond GPT-4: Exploring Microsoft‚Äôs WizardLM-2


Introducing WizardLM-2: Microsoft‚Äôs latest open source¬†model

The latest iteration, WizardLM-2, comes in three versions: 8x22B, 70B, and 7B, each designed to cater to different scales and requirements. The 8x22B model, being the flagship, boasts 141 billion parameters, making it one of the most potent models available in the open-source community.

Technological Advancements

Developed on a mixture of experts (MoE) architecture, WizardLM-2 leverages a synthetic training system that is fully AI-powered, enhancing its ability to handle complex, multilingual conversations and perform high-level reasoning. This system underpins the model‚Äôs capacity to deliver refined and contextually relevant responses across various domains, including writing, coding, mathematics, and more.

Performance and Applications

In benchmark evaluations, such as the MT-Bench framework, WizardLM-2 demonstrates competitive performance, rivaling even the most advanced proprietary models. Its application in real-world scenarios is vast, ranging from enhancing conversational AI to powering complex decision-making processes in business environments.
