title: The AI Economic Observatory: What Claude 3.7 Sonnet Reveals About Our Working Future
content:
### The AI Economic Observatory: What Claude 3.7 Sonnet Reveals About Our Working¬†Future


Insights from actual AI usage‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbeyond the¬†hype

Like Truman Burbank living in a constructed reality, many of us accept theoretical predictions about AI‚Äôs economic impact without questioning what‚Äôs actually happening.

But what if we could step outside this limited view? Anthropic‚Äôs Economic Index functions as a powerful observatory, allowing us to see beyond assumptions and glimpse the true patterns of AI‚Äôs integration into our economy.

The telescope has been upgraded, and the view is becoming clearer. By analyzing millions of actual conversations between humans and AI, researchers have begun mapping how technology is truly reshaping work‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänot how we theorized it might. The patterns of AI usage are revealing nuances that enhance our understanding of how these tools are being applied across different sectors.

This second research report from the Economic Index covers usage data following the launch of Claude 3.7 Sonnet, Anthropic‚Äôs newest model with capabilities in agentic coding and a new ‚Äúextended thinking‚Äù mode. It builds on their first report by providing comparative data that shows how usage patterns are evolving over time.


### Setting the Stage: The Observatory‚Äôs New¬†Lens


In February 2025, Anthropic introduced Claude 3.7 Sonnet‚Ää‚Äî‚Äätheir newest and most capable model with strengths in agentic coding and a new ‚Äúextended thinking‚Äù mode. Like astronomers receiving a telescope upgrade, researchers gained a sharper lens through which to observe AI‚Äôs impact on the workforce.

The initial Economic Index established baseline observations about how AI was being used across different occupational categories. Now, with new data following Claude 3.7 Sonnet‚Äôs launch, Anthropic has rerun their previous analysis on 1 million anonymized Claude.ai Free and Pro conversations from the 11 days after launch.

This second report provides comparative data that reveals how usage patterns have shifted since the first analysis. The findings show modest but notable changes in the distribution of AI usage across different sectors, alongside interesting patterns in how users are engaging with the new extended thinking mode.

Anthropic‚Äôs methodology remains consistent, using their privacy-preserving analysis tool Clio to map conversations to tasks in the U.S. Department of Labor‚Äôs O*NET database. This consistent approach allows for meaningful comparison between the two data points, revealing both what has changed and what has remained stable in AI usage patterns.


### The Changing Landscape: What the New Observations Show


As we examine the data from the two months since Anthropic‚Äôs original sample, clear shifts in usage patterns emerge across the economy. The research shows an increase in the share of usage for several key occupational categories, including coding, education, and the sciences.

While the increase in coding usage was expected given Claude 3.7 Sonnet‚Äôs improved performance on coding benchmarks, the rise in educational and scientific applications is particularly noteworthy. According to Anthropic‚Äôs report, this could reflect either ‚Äúongoing diffusion of AI throughout the economy, novel applications of coding to those domains, or unexpected capability improvements in the model.‚Äù

Healthcare applications also show increased usage, suggesting that medical professionals are finding new ways to leverage Claude‚Äôs capabilities. This cross-domain growth indicates that AI‚Äôs economic impact isn‚Äôt confined to purely technical fields but is expanding across diverse professional sectors.

What‚Äôs equally interesting is what hasn‚Äôt changed. Despite Claude 3.7 Sonnet‚Äôs advanced capabilities, the fundamental balance between augmentation (57%) and automation (43%) remains stable. However, within these categories, there were some shifts in the types of interactions‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääfor example, learning interactions, where users ask Claude for information or explanations about different topics, rose from approximately 23% to 28%.

The overall distribution of tasks across occupations also shows a similar curve to the first analysis, suggesting that while the intensity of usage in certain areas has changed, the breadth of AI application across different occupational tasks remains consistent.


### The Deep Field: Extended Thinking in¬†Action


Claude 3.7 Sonnet‚Äôs new ‚Äúextended thinking‚Äù mode represents a significant technical advancement in this model release. When activated by the user, this feature enables the model to think for longer when answering more complex questions, potentially improving the quality of responses for particularly challenging tasks.

Anthropic‚Äôs analysis reveals patterns in how this new capability is being utilized across different occupations. The data shows that extended thinking mode is predominantly used in technical and creative problem-solving contexts. Tasks associated with computer and information research scientists lead with almost 10% using extended thinking, followed by software developers at around 8%.

Creative professionals also show substantial adoption of this feature, with tasks associated with multimedia artists at approximately 7% and video game designers at about 6%. This distribution suggests that extended thinking mode is particularly valuable for both highly technical tasks and creative work requiring complex generation and planning.

To enable further research on this new capability, Anthropic has released a dataset that maps each O*NET task to its associated thinking mode fraction. This data is available on their Hugging Face page, providing researchers with the tools to conduct deeper analysis on when and why users choose to activate extended thinking mode.

These early usage patterns provide valuable insights into which types of complex problems benefit most from AI‚Äôs deeper contemplation capabilities. As the feature becomes more widely understood and adopted, it will be interesting to see whether its usage expands to other sectors or remains concentrated in technical and creative domains.


### The Cosmic Dance: Augmentation and Automation


In binary star systems, two celestial bodies orbit a common center, each influencing the other‚Äôs trajectory. The relationship between augmentation and automation resembles this cosmic dance‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwith humans and AI gravitating toward different equilibrium points depending on the task and occupation.

Anthropic‚Äôs data reveals this dance varies significantly across occupations. Community and Social Service tasks, which include education and guidance counseling, show a strong pull toward augmentation, approaching 75% of interactions. Meanwhile, production or computer and mathematical occupations maintain a more balanced orbit, with an almost 50‚Äì50 split between augmentation and automation.

Particular occupations display distinctive patterns in this dance. Copywriters and editors show the highest levels of task iteration‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa collaborative back-and-forth where humans and AI jointly refine content. In contrast, translators and interpreters demonstrate the strongest directive behavior, where humans specify a clear task and AI completes it with minimal intervention.

These patterns challenge simplistic narratives about AI ‚Äúreplacing‚Äù certain professions. Instead, we see a nuanced redistribution of work, with humans maintaining creative direction and quality control while delegating specific execution steps to AI. The cosmic dance continues, but the choreography varies widely across the economic universe.


### Beyond the Known Universe: Bottom-Up Discovery


Traditional economic research typically maps AI usage onto predefined task categories‚Ää‚Äî‚Äälike ancient astronomers fitting observations to existing star charts. But what if our existing maps don‚Äôt capture the full reality?

Anthropic‚Äôs research so far has relied on the ONET dataset of tasks and occupations, which was created and maintained by the U.S. Department of Labor. While ONET covers a very large number of tasks, it may not be the ideal taxonomy to describe the capabilities of general-purpose models like Claude, which can be used for tasks that aren‚Äôt present in the O*NET database.

To address this limitation, Anthropic has released a new bottom-up dataset of user activity patterns on Claude.ai. This dataset was created using the same Clio platform and the same set of anonymized conversations used for their other analyses, enabling direct comparisons between top-down and bottom-up approaches to understanding AI usage.Anthropic‚Äôs bottom-up taxonomy reveals 630 distinct usage clusters‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääentire galaxies of activity that might be missed by conventional approaches.

These newly charted territories include fascinating use cases like ‚ÄúHelp with water management systems and infrastructure projects,‚Äù ‚ÄúCreate physics-based simulations with interactive visualization capabilities,‚Äù and ‚ÄúProvide guidance on battery technologies and charging systems.‚Äù Like astronomical surveys that reveal unexpected objects, this bottom-up approach uncovers specific applications that transcend traditional occupational boundaries.

Some of these applications represent emerging hybrid work patterns that don‚Äôt fit neatly into existing economic frameworks. Just as astronomers updated their celestial maps when new telescopes revealed previously unknown objects, economists may need to revise occupational taxonomies to account for these newly observed work patterns.

By releasing this dataset, Anthropic invites researchers to explore these uncharted territories and develop new theories about how AI is reshaping work from the ground up. These 630 clusters serve as a more detailed map of the AI economy‚Äôs actual topography‚Ää‚Äî‚Äärevealing mountains, valleys, and rivers that weren‚Äôt visible from our previous vantage point.


### The Observatory‚Äôs Technology: How the Data Is¬†Captured


Behind every great observatory lies sophisticated instrumentation that captures signals while filtering out noise. Anthropic‚Äôs Clio platform functions as the Economic Index‚Äôs primary instrument‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcollecting, processing, and analyzing millions of conversations while maintaining strict privacy protections.

Clio operates through multiple layers, each serving a specific function in the observational process. First, it extracts ‚Äúfacets‚Äù from conversations‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääspecific attributes like topic, language patterns, or interaction length. Then, it uses semantic clustering to group similar conversations, creating meaningful patterns from the vast data landscape. Each cluster receives a descriptive label that captures its essence without exposing private details.

To ensure privacy, Clio employs multiple safeguards: it summarizes conversations without including personal information, enforces minimum cluster sizes, instructs the model to exclude private information during cluster creation, and performs final auditing to remove any sensitive content. This multi-layered approach allows researchers to observe broad economic patterns without compromising individual privacy.

The system‚Äôs accuracy has been extensively validated, achieving 94% in reconstructing ground-truth categories‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääfar above random classification. This validation ensures that the patterns we observe through Clio‚Äôs lens accurately reflect the underlying reality of AI-human interactions across the economy.


### The Backyard Astronomer: DIY AI Usage¬†Analysis


Professional observatories provide our most detailed view of the cosmos, but backyard astronomers can still make meaningful observations with more modest equipment. Similarly, while Anthropic‚Äôs comprehensive Economic Index offers the broadest perspective on AI‚Äôs economic impact, individuals can gain valuable insights by analyzing their own AI interactions with Claude.

The updated analysis code I‚Äôve compiled aligns with Anthropic‚Äôs methodology, allowing you to classify your personal AI usage according to the same framework used in the Economic Index. This toolkit processes conversation exports from Claude.ai to generate insights about your interaction patterns.

Key components of the analysis framework include:

The interaction analysis follows Anthropic‚Äôs five-category model:

The code also detects extended thinking mode usage:

Visualization components generate six charts that mirror Anthropic‚Äôs approach:

The analysis also creates a task-occupation dataset similar to what Anthropic has released:

While this personal analysis can‚Äôt match the scale of Anthropic‚Äôs research covering millions of conversations, it provides good insights into your own AI usage patterns and how they compare to broader economic trends. The code includes error handling and can even generate synthetic data for demonstration purposes if you don‚Äôt have enough conversations to analyze.

Github Link


### Charting the Future Trajectory


As astronomers track celestial objects to predict their future positions, we can use current AI usage patterns to forecast potential economic trajectories. The relative stability in augmentation versus automation ratios suggests that human-AI collaboration may remain the dominant paradigm even as capabilities advance. However, the shift toward more technical and scientific applications following Claude 3.7 Sonnet‚Äôs release hints at accelerating adoption in knowledge-intensive fields.

What orbital path will extended thinking follow? Currently concentrated in technical and creative domains, will this deeper contemplation mode expand to other sectors as users discover its benefits for complex problems in healthcare, education, or business strategy? The early pioneers in research, software development, and creative fields are establishing usage patterns that may spread to adjacent occupations.

The bottom-up usage clusters represent potential growth areas‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääsome may remain niche applications, while others could expand into significant economic activities. Like watching distant galaxies for signs of expansion or contraction, economists should monitor these clusters to identify emerging economic patterns before they become obvious.


### The View Continues to¬†Improve


Just as telescopes grow more powerful with each generation, our ability to observe AI‚Äôs economic impact will continue to improve. Anthropic‚Äôs commitment to releasing regular Economic Index updates promises an increasingly detailed time-series view of how these technologies reshape work patterns across the economy.

This empirical approach marks a fundamental shift in how we understand technological change‚Ää‚Äî‚Äämoving from theoretical or hyped up predictions to evidence-based observation. The early data challenges many assumptions: AI isn‚Äôt simply automating tasks‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs enabling new forms of collaboration; it isn‚Äôt uniformly impacting all occupations‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit shows distinctive patterns across domains; and it isn‚Äôt following a simple linear adoption curve‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs creating complex diffusion patterns as capabilities evolve.

As the Economic Index continues to collect data points, each new observation adds resolution to our understanding, allowing us to distinguish between temporary fluctuations and lasting structural changes. In this ongoing observatory of economic change, we‚Äôre just beginning to appreciate the true shape and trajectory of AI‚Äôs impact on our working future.

This screenshot isn‚Äôt from Anthropic‚Äôs official Economic Index‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääjust a friendly reminder from Claude that even advanced models need to set boundaries. üòÖ Turns out, extended thinking has its rate limits too.

References and Resources

By Lakshmi narayana .U on April 3, 2025.

title: Molmo: Advancing Open Multimodal AI Models
content:
### Molmo: Advancing Open Multimodal AI¬†Models


Introduction

The Allen Institute for AI (Ai2) recently introduced Molmo, a family of open-source multimodal AI models. Molmo demonstrates competitive performance against proprietary models like OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-4o and Anthropic‚Äôs Claude 3.5 Sonnet across multiple benchmarks. With its ability to handle both text and visual inputs, Molmo represents a step forward in making advanced multimodal AI models more accessible.

Key Features of¬†Molmo

Molmo‚Äôs most notable feature is its capacity for multimodal interaction, allowing it to process both images and text. What sets it apart is that it achieves high performance while using significantly less training data compared to its proprietary counterparts. Ai2‚Äôs approach focuses on a novel training pipeline that uses speech-based annotations to generate rich descriptions of images, replacing the traditional reliance on large-scale datasets‚Äã.

Molmo‚Äôs real-time analysis capabilities are also impressive. For instance, users can snap a photo, and Molmo can quickly identify objects, count elements, and even provide specific insights, like determining dietary options from a menu. This opens up new possibilities for applications requiring quick visual feedback.

Technical Architecture

Molmo‚Äôs architecture consists of a simple combination of a vision encoder and a language model, connected through a multi-layer perceptron (MLP) that projects visual tokens into the language model‚Äôs input space. The vision encoder used in Molmo is OpenAI‚Äôs ViT-L/14 336px CLIP model, which processes multi-scale, multi-crop images into vision tokens. These tokens are pooled for dimensionality reduction before being passed to the language model‚Äã.

The language model component of Molmo is a decoder-only Transformer, and the models in the Molmo family vary based on different underlying models and parameter sizes. Molmo‚Äôs flagship model, Molmo-72B, is based on Qwen2‚Äì72B, an open-source model from Alibaba Cloud. Other models in the family include the Molmo-7B-D, Molmo-7B-O, and MolmoE-1B‚Äã.

Training Process

Molmo‚Äôs training process is divided into two stages:

Unlike many contemporary models, Molmo does not use reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF). Instead, its performance relies on careful tuning of all model parameters during both the pre-training and fine-tuning stages‚Äã

Benchmark Performance

Molmo has shown strong performance across multiple benchmarks. The Molmo-72B model, for example, scored 96.3 on DocVQA and 85.5 on TextVQA, outperforming several proprietary models, including GPT-4o and Claude 3.5 Sonnet‚Äã. Additionally, it achieved top results in visual grounding tasks like RealWorldQA, making it particularly suitable for applications in robotics and complex multimodal reasoning.

Molmo‚Äôs pointing capability is a noteworthy innovation. This allows the model to identify objects in images by pointing to them, which enhances its ability to provide visual explanations and handle tasks like object counting‚Äã.

Molmo‚Äôs visual grounding abilities allow it to identify and interact with objects within images, making it suitable for tasks that require spatial understanding, such as robotics‚Äã.

Demo Review

Molmo is available for a demo at https://molmo.allenai.org/

One can also access the model via Hugging Face (needs a¬†GPU)

Simple code available here

In both cases above, it did a good job.

Further, one can even try to generate code through image analysis, which yields decent results.

Ai2‚Äôs Molmo offers an open-source alternative to proprietary multimodal models, delivering strong performance across various benchmarks. With its focus on efficiency and innovative data collection methods, Molmo provides developers and researchers with a powerful tool that can be customized for a variety of applications. Ai2‚Äôs commitment to open access ensures that future updates, including more datasets and model weights, will continue to expand the possibilities for the AI community.

title: From Prompt to Picture: How ChatGPT-4o‚Äôs New Image Generation Works
content:
### From Prompt to Picture: How ChatGPT-4o‚Äôs New Image Generation Works


A look at ChatGPT-4o‚Äôs image generation‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääprompt in, picture¬†out.

Imagine asking your AI assistant to create not just any image, but one that perfectly captures your vision (sometimes even extrapolated from your intent, which is picked up from your prompt), complete with accurate text, proper styling, and precise details. And you can bring your own images to the party as well. That‚Äôs exactly what OpenAI delivered with 4o Image Generation.

This isn‚Äôt just another incremental update to image AI. It‚Äôs a complete reimagining of how machines create visuals, now woven directly into the fabric of GPT-4o itself. Available to all ChatGPT users (with Enterprise and Edu access coming soon), this technology represents a fundamental shift in AI-generated imagery, within the popular chatbot interface.

The magic lies in its seamless integration. Unlike previous image generators that functioned as separate tools, 4o Image Generation taps directly into GPT-4o‚Äôs vast knowledge, drawing on its understanding of language, concepts, and context to create images that aren‚Äôt just pretty pictures‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthey‚Äôre visual solutions to specific needs. And this model will spoil you to a fault.

Technical Foundation

4o Image Generation breaks the mold of its previous AI image tools through its innovative architecture. Where DALL-E relied on diffusion models, 4o builds images through an autoregressive approach‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääpredicting one element after another‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääall while tightly integrated with ChatGPT‚Äôs language capabilities.

This design creates a true ‚Äúomnimodel‚Äù that doesn‚Äôt just understand different types of information separately but sees the connections between them. By training on the joint distribution of online images and text, the system learned not just what things look like, but how visual elements relate to each other and to language concepts.

Yes, images take a bit longer to generate (up to a minute versus seconds with older models, akin to images loading during the good old modem-internet days), but the output makes the wait worthwhile. The system processes your request with a deeper understanding of what you‚Äôre asking for, resulting in visuals that finally match what you actually had in mind.

Core Capabilities

Text Rendering Excellence

Finally, an (open)AI that can spell! One of 4o‚Äôs most impressive feats is rendering text correctly within images. Where previous models gave you gibberish that looked like text from a distance, 4o creates crisp, readable text for signs, menus, diagrams, and documents.

Photorealistic Image Creation

The leap in photorealism is striking. 4o creates images with natural lighting, proper reflections, consistent shadows, and accurate textures. Landscapes, portraits, products, and complex scenes all benefit from this enhanced realism that previously required human touch-ups to achieve.

Multi-turn Generation and Refinement

Want to tweak that image? Just ask. 4o remembers what it created and maintains consistency through conversation. Start with a basic concept, then refine colors, adjust composition, or add new elements without starting over. It‚Äôs like working with a designer who remembers every detail of your project.

Instruction Following

4o handles complex requests that would overwhelm other AI systems. While previous models struggled with more than 5‚Äì8 elements, 4o can juggle up to 10‚Äì20 distinct objects in a single image while maintaining their relationships and attributes.

In-context Learning

Upload a reference image, and 4o studies it. The system can analyze your examples and incorporate elements from them into new creations. Show it your logo, product, or style reference, and it‚Äôll create new visuals that maintain those distinctive elements.

World Knowledge Integration

4o doesn‚Äôt just create pretty pictures‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit understands concepts. Ask for a visualization of photosynthesis, economic principles, or historical events, and it applies its knowledge to create informative, accurate representations without you needing to explain every detail.

Practical Applications

The capabilities of 4o Image Generation open up numerous practical applications across various domains, as evidenced by real-world usage examples:

Educational Content

Educators and learners can create custom diagrams, infographics, and explanatory visuals tailored to specific learning objectives. The ability to generate accurate visual representations of complex concepts makes it an invaluable tool for teaching abstract ideas.

Few examples I tried:

Storytelling and Literary Visualization

The system excels at bringing stories and literary works to life through visual representation:

Few examples I tried:

Creative Expression

Artists, writers, and content creators can use 4o Image Generation to visualize stories, concepts, and creative ideas. The system can generate comics, storyboards, character designs, and artistic interpretations based on textual descriptions.

Professional Use Cases

Marketers, designers, and business professionals can quickly generate product mockups, advertisements, presentation visuals, and branding materials. The ability to accurately render text makes it particularly useful for creating professional-looking content that includes logos, slogans, and informational text.

Personal Projects

Individuals can create personalized memes, custom imagery for social media, visual jokes, and other creative content. The conversational interface makes it accessible even to those without design experience.

Few examples I tried:

UI/UX Design

Designers can rapidly prototype user interfaces, app screens, and website layouts with accurate text rendering and visual consistency. The ability to iterate through conversation allows for quick refinement of design concepts.

Features Comparison

4o Image Generation vs. DALL-E 3

4o doesn‚Äôt just improve on DALL-E 3‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit leapfrogs it:

Safety Measures and Limitations

Provenance Tracking

In an era of deepfakes, provenance matters. Every 4o-generated image contains C2PA metadata‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa digital signature that identifies it as AI-created. OpenAI also maintains internal tools to verify whether a suspicious image originated from their system.

Safety Guardrails

OpenAI balances creative freedom with responsible use through several safeguards:

Current Limitations

While impressive, 4o isn‚Äôt perfect:

User Experience

Seamless Integration

No need to switch tools or hop between apps‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää4o‚Äôs image capabilities are built right into the ChatGPT interface. Just describe what you want, upload reference images if needed, and watch your vision take shape through natural conversation.

Conversational Refinement

Think of it as working with a designer who actually listens. Don‚Äôt like something? Just say so. Want to try a different color? Just ask. The system remembers what you‚Äôre working on and maintains consistency throughout your creative conversation.

The Wait Factor

Let‚Äôs address the elephant in the room: 4o takes longer to generate images‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääup to a minute compared to DALL-E‚Äôs seconds. But when you see the results, you‚Äôll understand why. It‚Äôs like the difference between a quick sketch and a carefully composed painting. The quality upgrade is dramatic, and OpenAI promises generation speed will improve over time.

Prompting Tips

Get better results with these quick tips:

4o Image Generation isn‚Äôt just a better DALL-E‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs a fundamental rethinking of how AI creates visuals. By embedding image generation directly into the language model‚Äôs architecture, OpenAI has created a system that understands what you want, not just what you say.

The combination of accurate text rendering, photorealism, and conversational refinement transforms image generation from a novelty into a practical tool for communication, education, creativity, and professional work. While it has limitations‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand raises important questions about the future of visual creation‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää4o represents a significant step in making AI-powered imagery both more beautiful and more useful, for anyone interested in creative expression in a simple conversation.

As users experiment with the system and developers begin building on the upcoming API, we‚Äôll likely discover applications far beyond what was initially imagined. The line between describing and visualizing continues to blur, opening new possibilities for how we express ideas and share information in an increasingly visual digital world.

title: Beyond Assistants: Developing Autonomous Workflows with OpenAI‚Äôs Agents SDK
content:
### Beyond Assistants: Developing Autonomous Workflows with OpenAI‚Äôs Agents¬†SDK


From Dialogue to Delivery: The AI¬†Agency

From Assistants to Autonomous Agents

The AI landscape is undergoing a transformation, shifting from reactive AI assistants that simply respond to queries to proactive autonomous agents capable of completing complex tasks independently. This evolution represents a fundamental change in how we interact with AI systems.

Autonomous agents stand apart from traditional assistants through their capacity for independent decision-making and ability to take actions without constant human supervision. Unlike assistants that wait for instructions, autonomous agents can initiate processes, determine next steps, and complete multi-stage workflows based on high-level objectives. This proactive approach enables them to manage complex processes with minimal human intervention.

The business impact of this shift is significant. This transition from question-answering to task execution promises substantial efficiency gains across industries, reducing the time knowledge workers spend on routine tasks while improving consistency and availability.

Multi-agent systems further enhance these capabilities by enabling specialized autonomous workflows. Rather than relying on a single general-purpose AI, organizations can deploy multiple specialized agents that excel in specific domains‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhether that‚Äôs customer support, research, sales prospecting, or financial analysis. These agents can collaborate, handing off tasks between them as needed to complete complex business processes end-to-end.

OpenAI‚Äôs New Agent Ecosystem: Tools for¬†Autonomy

Recently, OpenAI announced a comprehensive suite of tools designed specifically to enable the development of autonomous agents. This includes new APIs, built-in tools, and orchestration frameworks that make it significantly easier to build, deploy, and scale agentic applications.

The Responses API

The Responses API combines ‚Äúthe simplicity of Chat Completions with the tool-use capabilities of the Assistants API,‚Äù providing a unified framework for agent development. Its item-based design offers several advantages over previous approaches:

Importantly, the Responses API is designed to be a superset of the Chat Completions API, making migration straightforward for developers. OpenAI has committed to maintaining the Chat Completions API for applications that don‚Äôt require built-in tools, while recommending the Responses API for new integrations.

Built-in Tools for Autonomous Capabilities

The Responses API launches with three powerful built-in tools that extend the capabilities of autonomous agents:

Web Search Tool: This allows models to access up-to-date information from the internet, providing factual, cited responses from the web. Powered by fine-tuned versions of GPT-4o and GPT-4o-mini, these models achieve impressive accuracy on factual question benchmarks (90% and 88% respectively on SimpleQA). In the demonstration at OpenAI‚Äôs launch event, the web search tool helped a personal stylist agent locate Patagonia stores in Tokyo based on a user‚Äôs preferences and location.

File Search Tool: This improved tool helps agents retrieve relevant information from large document collections. New capabilities include metadata filtering (to narrow searches based on attributes) and a direct search endpoint (for querying vector stores without model mediation). Companies like Navan have leveraged this tool to build AI-powered travel agents that quickly access and personalize information from their knowledge base.

Computer Use Tool: (Just like in Claude etc)This tool allows agents to control computers directly through a browser interface or operating system. It captures mouse and keyboard actions generated by the model and executes them within the specified environment. This enables automation of browser-based workflows and legacy systems that lack API access. Quite a few Companies have already used this tool to automate complex operational workflows that previously required human intervention.

Chat Completions API Vs Responses API

While the OpenAI committed to maintaining the Chat Completions API, they‚Äôve positioned the Responses API as the future for agentic applications. Similarly, they plan to achieve feature parity between the Assistants API and the Responses API, with a goal to sunset the Assistants API by mid-2026, providing developers with a clear migration path.

The Agents SDK: Architecture for Workflow Orchestration

Beyond providing the building blocks for individual agents, OpenAI has introduced the Agents SDK, an open-source framework that simplifies the orchestration of multi-agent workflows. This SDK evolved from Swarm, an experimental SDK released last year that was widely adopted by the developer community.

Core Components for Autonomous Workflow Development

The Agents SDK provides several key components that make it easier to build complex agent systems:

Agent Configuration: The SDK allows developers to easily configure agents with specific instructions and tool access. As shown in the sample implementation, each agent can be defined with a clear purpose and specialized capabilities.

Function Tools: One of the interesting features is the automatic conversion of Python functions to tools that models can use. By examining type signatures, the SDK generates the JSON schema required for function calling:

Handoff Protocol: The SDK formalizes the concept of ‚Äúhandoffs‚Äù between agents, allowing one agent to transfer control to another while maintaining conversation context. This enables specialized agents to handle different parts of a workflow:

Guardrails: The SDK includes configurable safety checks for input and output validation, helping ensure that agents operate within defined boundaries.

Tracing System: A comprehensive tracing dashboard visualizes agent execution paths, making it easier to debug and optimize complex workflows. The tracing UI provides detailed insights into agent decisions, function calls, and handoffs.

Development Advantages

The Agents SDK offers significant advantages over manual orchestration approaches. It reduces boilerplate code, provides consistent patterns for common requirements, and handles many edge cases automatically. The separation of concerns allows teams to develop and test different agents independently, making complex systems more maintainable.

The SDK works with both the Responses API and Chat Completions API, and can even support models from other providers that offer a Chat Completions-style API endpoint. Currently available for Python, with Node.js support coming soon, it provides a portable framework for autonomous workflow development.

Implementing Autonomous Business Workflows: A Practical Example

To demonstrate how these tools enable practical autonomous workflows, let‚Äôs examine a small business advisor system implemented using the Agents SDK. This example shows how to create a multi-agent system that helps small business owners with various aspects of starting and running their business. (Link to full code at Github below)

Designing the Autonomous Business Process Workflow

The system is designed to provide detailed business advice through specialized agents:

Each agent handles a specific domain, allowing for deep expertise in its area while maintaining a unified user experience through seamless handoffs.

Development Environment Setup

Setting up the development environment involves installing the necessary packages and configuring API access:

Autonomous Function Implementation

The system implements several specialized functions that agents can use to complete specific tasks:

Business FAQ Lookup: This function retrieves information about common business questions:

Business Plan Generator: This function creates customized business plans based on user input:

Marketing Strategy Advisor: This function provides tailored marketing recommendations:

Funding Calculator: This function analyzes financial needs and recommends funding options:

Creating Specialized Workflow Agents

With these functions defined, the system creates specialized agents for different aspects of business advising:

Workflow Orchestration

The triage agent serves as the entry point, determining which specialized agent should handle each request:

The system manages workflow state through a BusinessAdvisorContext class, which preserves information across agent handoffs:

Handoff hooks provide opportunities for pre-processing and post-processing at transition points:

User Interaction and Testing

The system uses Gradio to provide a user-friendly interface:

The tracing dashboard provides visibility into the execution path, showing agent decisions, function calls, and the overall flow of the conversation.

Github Link

Conclusion and Next¬†Steps

The OpenAI Agents SDK represents an important step from one of the key players in AI, towards advancement in AI development, enabling truly autonomous workflows that can transform how organizations operate across industries. While we‚Äôve explored a simple implementation in this article, the potential applications are vast and diverse:

Customer Service Automation: Organizations can develop multi-agent systems that handle inquiries, process transactions, and manage customer relationships with minimal human intervention, improving response times and consistency.

Sales Process Optimization: Autonomous agents can qualify leads, personalize outreach, demonstrate products, and manage follow-up activities, creating more efficient sales pipelines while freeing sales professionals to focus on relationship building.

Operations Workflow Streamlining: For internal processes, agents can automate routine tasks, monitor systems, generate reports, and coordinate activities across departments, reducing operational overhead.

Research and Analysis: Agents can gather information from multiple sources, analyze data, and generate insights, accelerating research processes that previously required significant manual effort.

When implementing autonomous workflows, several key considerations apply regardless of the specific use case:

Security and Governance: Establish clear boundaries and oversight mechanisms, especially for agents with access to sensitive systems or customer data.

Context Management: Design systems that maintain appropriate context across interactions and agent handoffs to ensure coherent user experiences.

Performance Monitoring: Implement comprehensive monitoring to track agent performance, identify optimization opportunities, and detect potential issues before they impact users.

Human-AI Collaboration: Design workflows that leverage the strengths of both autonomous agents and human experts, with clear escalation paths for complex or sensitive situations.

The Agents SDK, being open-source, will likely evolve rapidly as the developer community contributes enhancements and best practices. Organizations that start exploring these capabilities now will be well-positioned to leverage increasingly sophisticated autonomous workflows in the future.

In a forthcoming article, I‚Äôll attempt to provide more detailed implementation of the OpenAI Agents SDK, exploring additional capabilities and demonstrating how to build more complex multi-agent systems for enterprise applications.

As we continue to explore the potential of autonomous agents, it‚Äôs clear that we‚Äôre moving beyond mere AI assistants toward truly intelligent systems that can independently accomplish meaningful work‚Ää‚Äî‚Äätransforming productivity and enabling new possibilities across business functions.

title: The Dawn of a New Era in Filmmaking: The Transformative Potential of AI Collaborations
content:
The Dawn of a New Era in Filmmaking: The Transformative Potential of AI Collaborations

In the ever-evolving landscape of cinema, the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) is poised to redefine the boundaries of creativity and production. The burgeoning creator economy and advancements in AI technologies have opened up intriguing possibilities for filmmakers and studios alike. This convergence is not just a testament to the growing intersection of AI and entertainment but also a harbinger of potential advancements in how films are made and experienced by audiences worldwide.


### A Visionary Collaboration


In the early 2000s, I set up my own company and introduced a concept called CAPM (Computer-Aided Process Management) for the entertainment industry. The objective was to bring efficiency to the filmmaking process without compromising the creative aspects. We aimed to track outputs like completed scenes without interfering with the writers‚Äô and directors‚Äô artistic workflows. Although the system didn‚Äôt take off due to the industry‚Äôs focus on the final product over process optimization, it laid the groundwork for understanding how technology could support creativity.

Fast forward to today, the idea of integrating advanced technologies into filmmaking has gained significant traction. Studios are exploring AI‚Äôs potential to enhance storytelling and production efficiency, offering a glimpse into the future of filmmaking. Companies specializing in generative AI, like RunwayML, have developed cutting-edge models that assist in creating visual effects, storyboarding, and even generating synthetic media. These tools enable filmmakers to visualize concepts rapidly, iterate on ideas, and streamline the production process.


### The Potential of AI in Filmmaking


The integration of AI into the filmmaking process offers numerous possibilities:

For instance, AI-driven tools can help filmmakers visualize scenes more quickly and create intricate special effects like explosions, all while maintaining artistic control. The financial benefits are also significant, with expectations of saving substantial resources through AI-driven efficiencies.


### Revisiting CAPM in the Age of¬†AI


Reflecting on my earlier efforts with CAPM, it‚Äôs fascinating to see how AI is now being embraced to enhance the creative process‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa concept I once envisioned but couldn‚Äôt fully realize due to the limitations of the time. The challenges I faced, such as the industry‚Äôs reluctance to adopt new process management systems, are now being overcome as the benefits of AI become more apparent.

The experiences with CAPM taught me the importance of aligning technological solutions with the unique demands of creative industries. Effective collaboration between technologists and creatives is essential to ensure that tools augment rather than hinder the artistic process. The subtle methods of controlling the creative process, like recording story discussions and making detailed notes, are now being enhanced with AI, offering unobtrusive yet powerful ways to support creativity.


### Addressing Challenges and Ethical Considerations


While the potential benefits of AI in filmmaking are immense, the integration of AI also raises important ethical considerations:


### The Future of AI-Driven Cinema


The potential for AI to revolutionize cinema is immense. As technology advances, we may see:


### Conclusion: A New Chapter in Cinematic Innovation


We stand at the dawn of a new era in filmmaking, where technology and creativity converge to push the boundaries of what‚Äôs possible. The lessons from my early experiences with CAPM underscore the importance of integrating technology thoughtfully within creative industries. As AI becomes an increasingly integral part of the filmmaking process, it holds the promise of enhancing storytelling, optimizing production, and offering audiences unprecedented experiences.

The future of cinema will likely be defined by how well we balance technological innovation with the timeless art of storytelling. Embracing AI not as a replacement but as an extension of human creativity will pave the way for groundbreaking works that resonate with audiences worldwide. Studios, filmmakers, and technologists must collaborate closely to navigate the challenges and harness the opportunities that AI presents.

In this new chapter of cinematic innovation, the partnership between creative vision and technological advancement serves as a beacon of what is possible when we dare to explore uncharted territories. As filmmakers and audiences alike embark on this exciting journey, the potential for AI-driven cinema to transform the industry is limitless, offering a glimpse into a future where the art of storytelling knows no bounds.

title: The Browser That Thinks: Perplexity.ai Comet‚Äôs Agentic Twist to Replace Your Digital Detective Work
content:
### The Browser That Thinks: Perplexity.ai Comet‚Äôs Agentic Twist to Replace Your Digital Detective Work


‚ÄúI see dead tabs‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääif browsers had their own Sixth Sense moment, Comet would be the kid who finally learned to communicate with the digital spirits haunting our workflows.

I still remember the excitement when news broke about Halley‚Äôs Comet approaching in 1986. As a teenager, I convinced my friend to visit a nearby observatory (the Ibrahimpatnam one) and ironically had to view it with his binoculars, instead of the telescope inside. Craning our necks toward the night sky, we finally spotted that legendary celestial visitor‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa fuzzy blur that appears once every 76 years. Standing there, I ruefully wondered if I‚Äôd ever see it again (spoiler alert: probably not, unless I make it to 2061).

Fast forward to 2025, and I found myself with that same sense of cosmic timing when Perplexity announced their Comet browser. With its exclusive $200/month price tag and invite-only access, I thought it might take just as long to get my hands on this digital comet. But sometimes the universe aligns in unexpected ways‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthanks to a generous offer from Perplexity.ai business fellowship team, I received the invite, and I got access without the 76-year wait.

Like Dom Cobb navigating dreams within dreams in Inception, Perplexity AI has built something that operates on multiple layers of web reality simultaneously. And unlike that disappointing fuzzy blur I glimpsed through binoculars decades ago, this digital Comet actually delivers on its promise.


### TL;DR: Comet Features & Try-It-Yourself Use¬†Cases


Beginner Level¬†üü¢

Intermediate Level¬†üü°

Advanced Level¬†üî¥

What‚Äôs Coming Next (Per CEO Aravind Srinivas)


### The Strategic Stakes: Why Browser Wars Matter¬†Now


Before we dive into Comet‚Äôs features and my exploration, here‚Äôs the crucial context: browsers have been the cornerstone of the internet revolution, while LLMs (chatbots/APIs/MCP et al) represent the foundation of the AI revolution. A combination of both would be a killer move for any incumbent AI company.

This insight reveals why Perplexity felt compelled to create their own browser rather than just building extensions or plugins.

For Srinivas, the browser represents something more fundamental: ‚ÄúThe browser is the most agentic software that we use every day. It has your login state. It has all the pages you‚Äôre on. It‚Äôs the most powerful surface area where AI can actually take actions for you.‚Äù In other words, if you want to build true AI agents that can act on your behalf, you need to control the browser infrastructure.

Comet has all that strategic positioning going for it, and we‚Äôll have to wait and see how the landscape changes with the rumored entry of OpenAI‚Äôs native browser. One can definitely understand the urgency behind Perplexity‚Äôs push‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääif you control the browser, you control the majority of user experience today (emphasis on ‚Äúas of today‚Äù).

Like everyone, I use browsers for everything: email, research, web applications, AI chatbots, programming via Colab. Almost my entire online experience is embedded in a browser, making it the perfect place for AI integration.


### My Digital Detective Dilemma: The Manual Analysis Nightmare


This ubiquity made me curious to analyze my browsing patterns and make sense of them‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääespecially from time management and research perspectives. I wanted answers to questions like: How much time do I spend on email? Did I research that topic thoroughly? Did I save important findings to Readwise for future use?

The Safari History Archaeology Project

I tried exporting my Safari browsing history¬†, time-tracking tool¬†, etc. and writing Python code to analyze it. The manual export process was a nightmare of JSONs/SQLite databases, timestamp conversions, and incomplete data. What I hoped would be dynamic insights turned into a one-time analysis that told me little about my actual research patterns or time allocation.

The LinkedIn Likes Laboratory

Additionally, I have a habit of liking content on LinkedIn and X as a way to bookmark items for future exploration. I attempted to analyze these engagement patterns with Python code to identify trending topics worth deeper investigation. Instead, I got lost in API mazes, authentication headaches, and rate limiting frustrations.

The goal was simple: understand my information consumption patterns to optimize my research workflow. The reality was complex: manual approaches that yielded minimal actionable intelligence.


### How Comet Solves My Digital Detective Problems


Now with Comet, both of the above challenges can be handled easily through natural language queries.

The Browsing History¬†Oracle

Instead of manual SQLite exports and Python scripts, I can ask: ‚ÄúWhat topics have I been researching most this month?‚Äù or ‚ÄúShow me my time allocation across different types of websites.‚Äù Comet‚Äôs AI automatically recognizes patterns in browsing behavior with local data processing that respects privacy.

The Social Media Insight¬†Engine

My LinkedIn and X analysis struggles vanish with Comet‚Äôs ability to analyze social media engagement patterns across platforms. No more API wrestling‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääjust automated trend identification, content gap analysis, and proactive suggestions for topics worth exploring deeper.


### The CXO Briefing: My Use Case Discovery


Here‚Äôs my favorite discovery‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa semi-automated morning briefing system I set up:

My Briefing Prompt: ‚ÄúBased on tabs opened, do the following: 1) Gather the latest business highlights 2) Check if they are reflecting on [website_url] and identify missing worthy items that can be covered 3) Get the current live count of [youtube_channel_name] and [youtube_channel_name] along with timestamps in IST 4) Combine 2 and 3 into a morning brief and email [email_id]‚Äù

This represents the shift from information gathering/processing/delivering to a single step, automated intelligence synthesis. One AI agent replaces multiple tools and manual processes, delivering personalized executive summaries with actionable insights directly to my inbox (for now) and to my team later.


### The Technical Reality Check: What Works and What¬†Doesn‚Äôt


The Impressive Wins

Built on Chromium with full Chrome extension compatibility, Comet delivers faster performance especially with multiple tabs. The ‚Äúagentic advantage‚Äù enables what researchers call ‚Äúvibe browsing‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääusers step back while agents interact on their behalf. Real-world task completion includes successful restaurant booking while multitasking, effective summarization across languages, and seamless Chrome migration.

Privacy Clarifications

Comet‚Äôs ability to analyze browsing history and social media engagement is powerful, but it raises valid privacy concerns. Perplexity states that Comet processes data locally to minimize cloud-based risks, ensuring that sensitive information like your Gmail or LinkedIn activity stays on your device. (And there is an existing privacy guidance regarding the threads that get created in perplexity.ai)

However, the browser‚Äôs access to such data requires trust in Perplexity‚Äôs security practices. Unlike some competitors, Perplexity has faced scrutiny for its data retention policies in the past, particularly around how long user queries are stored. While Comet‚Äôs beta includes encryption and user-controlled data settings, it‚Äôs not perfect‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääusers can‚Äôt yet fully opt out of anonymized data collection for AI training. For privacy-conscious users, this trade-off between functionality and control is worth weighing. I recommend checking Comet‚Äôs privacy dashboard to customize data permissions and sticking to local processing for sensitive tasks like email analysis.

The Growing¬†Pains

Hallucination issues persist with complex tasks, resource consumption can be heavy, and the $200/month subscription creates a significant barrier to entry. The browser is still in beta, so some prompts crash when the AI encounters unexpected hurdles.


### The Browser Wars and What‚Äôs¬†Next


The browser wars are heating up, with OpenAI‚Äôs rumored AI-native browser and Google‚Äôs Chrome (holding ~70% mobile market share in 2025) facing emerging pressure from Comet‚Äôs AI-driven features. Industry reports suggest AI browsers could capture 10% of the market by 2027, driven by demand for automated workflows.

Comet‚Äôs early lead lies in its agentic capabilities, like task automation and cross-site synthesis, but scaling these features to compete with Chrome‚Äôs ecosystem will require seamless integration with tools like Google Workspace. For now, Comet‚Äôs beta shows what‚Äôs possible when browsers evolve from portals to proactive partners, hinting at a future where knowledge synthesis trumps simple search.

Like Morpheus offering Neo the red or blue pill, we‚Äôre at a defining moment: browsers can remain passive windows to information or evolve into intelligent co-pilots that act on our behalf.

My attempts to manually track Safari history and LinkedIn engagement weren‚Äôt failures‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthey were relics of an outdated workflow model.

Comet represents the future of AI-first browsing‚Ää‚Äî‚Äämerging automation, summarization, and real-time decision support in a single surface.

üöÄ TL;DR‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäKey Takeaways as of August 3, 2025:


### And One Last¬†Thing‚Ä¶


In a subsequent article, I‚Äôll dig into the technical architecture of AI browsers, especially Chromium-based implementations, and explore creating a personal knowledge assistant that scans all my email (where I send important articles for further processing), Readwise, Obsidian vault, LinkedIn, and X activity for research patterns and future idea generation.

I‚Äôll also compare Comet‚Äôs agentic approach against competitors like Arc‚Äôs AI features, Brave‚Äôs privacy-first integration, and The Browser Company‚Äôs Dia browser, plus how its workflow automation stacks up against tools like Zapier actions and Rewind.ai‚Äôs personal data analysis.

By Lakshmi narayana .U on August 3, 2025.

Creating a compelling article in one session is entirely feasible when you come prepared and make the best use of ChatGPT Plus. Here‚Äôs a step-by-step guide to ensure you make the most out of your writing experience.

1. Preparation: Laying the Groundwork

2. Configuration: Setting Up ChatGPT¬†Plus

3. Research and Content Enhancement

4. Building Your Article‚Äôs Structure

5. Adding Creative¬†Elements

6. Refining Your¬†Content

7. Maintaining Authenticity and High Standards

8. Ensuring Relevance and Factuality

9. Adding Finishing Touches

10. Engaging Your Audience and Promoting Your¬†Article

With these steps and the right preparation, you can efficiently leverage ChatGPT Plus to create an article that not only meets but exceeds expectations‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääall in one session! Happy writing!

title: Exploring Jockey: A conversational Video agent using Twelve Labs API and LangGraph
content:
### Exploring Jockey: A conversational Video agent using Twelve Labs API and LangGraph


Agents are everywhere. In simple terms, an agent is a software entity that can perceive its environment and act upon it to achieve specific goals. In the realm of artificial intelligence, agents can range from simple reflex agents that act based on immediate perceptions to more complex learning agents that adapt and evolve over time. Imagine you‚Äôre playing a video game, and there‚Äôs a non-player character that seems to know exactly where to go and what to do to win‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthis character is acting as an agent.

Agents can be designed to handle a wide variety of tasks, from automating mundane processes to solving complex problems that require decision-making and learning. For instance, with the help of tools like Agent Studio and LMStudio, even beginners can start creating local agents that mimic human-like decision-making processes. These agents can be proactive, continuously learning from their environment and adjusting their actions to achieve their objectives more effectively.

In more advanced applications, as seen with the frameworks like Autogen, Langchain, Llamaindex and phidata frameworks, agents can leverage large language models (LLMs) to resolve complex queries by breaking them down into a series of manageable steps. These agents use a set of predefined tools, or experts, to perform specific tasks, such as web searches or mathematical calculations, when necessary. This allows agents to operate in a dynamic and iterative manner, making them powerful allies in navigating and making sense of complex information landscapes. Whether in video games, business applications, or research, agents are becoming an integral part of how we interact with technology. Implementing agents for videos is a different ball game altogether.

In this article, let‚Äôs explore Jockey, a conversational agent for videos built on Twelve Labs technology. This is the first in a planned series exploring Jockey‚Äôs capabilities, with future articles diving deeper into advanced features and real-world applications. You might want to check out my previous article on Twelve Labs, which is provided below.

Introducing Jockey

Jockey is a conversational video agent designed for complex video workflows. It combines the Twelve Labs Video Understanding Platform, Large Language Models (LLMs), and LangGraph to perform accurate video operations based on natural language instructions. The Twelve Labs Video Understanding Platform offers an API suite for integrating state-of-the-art video foundation models (VFMs) that understand contextual information from videos. LLMs logically plan execution steps, interact with users, and pass video-related tasks to the Twelve Labs Video Understanding Platform, interpreting natural language instructions and translating them into actionable tasks. LangGraph orchestrates the interaction between the Twelve Labs API suite and LLMs, enabling the creation of stateful, multi-step applications, allowing for complex video processing workflows.

Jockey‚Äôs architecture is designed to efficiently handle complex video-related tasks through a multi-agent system. The system comprises three main components: the Supervisor, the Planner, and the Workers. The Supervisor is responsible for routing tasks between different nodes and managing the overall workflow. The Planner creates detailed, step-by-step plans for complex user requests. The Workers section consists of the Instructor, which generates precise task instructions, and the Actual Workers, which are specialized agents that execute the instructions using their available tools, including Video Search, Video Text Generation, and Video Editing. This architecture allows Jockey to handle a wide range of video-related tasks with flexibility and precision.

Jockey‚Äôs modular design facilitates customization and extension. Developers can modify prompts, extend the state to handle more complex scenarios, or add new workers to address specific use cases. Developers can also directly modify Jockey‚Äôs components. This includes modifying prompts, extending or modifying the state, and adding or modifying workers.

Jockey can perform tasks such as clip selection, video editing, and content analysis, all driven by natural language instructions. It is capable of compiling and editing video clips, summarizing videos, generating chapters and highlights, searching for clips or videos using natural language queries, creating custom video compilations based on specific criteria, and answering questions about video content. Jockey supports both terminal-based deployment for quick testing and development, and API server deployment for integration into larger applications.

Key Highlights:

- Intelligent Task Allocation: Jockey seamlessly balances workloads between large language models for logical planning and user interaction, and video foundation models for deep video understanding.

- Direct Video Engagement: Unlike traditional systems that rely on pre-generated captions, Jockey processes video content directly, offering unparalleled accuracy and nuanced operations.

- Adaptable Architecture: Built on the dependable LangGraph framework, Jockey‚Äôs modular design allows for easy customization and extension to meet diverse needs.

- Versatile Deployment: Whether you‚Äôre looking for quick testing in a terminal or integrating into larger applications, Jockey offers flexible deployment options.

- Comprehensive Video Manipulation: From clip selection and video editing to detailed content analysis, Jockey handles it all through natural language commands.

To use Jockey, here are the prerequisites:

Jockey is an open-source project, and the source code and documentation can be found on its GitHub repository.

Installing and Deploying Jockey in the Terminal: A Step-by-Step Guide

To install Jockey on your system (MacOS), follow these steps:

2. Set Up a Python Virtual Environment:

Activate the virtual environment:

4. Set Up Environment Variables:

Open the¬†.env file and configure the necessary variables:

An example of¬†.env file

5. Run Jockey

i. Activate your virtual environment:

iii. Jockey will initialize‚Ä¶wait for the prompt with ‚ÄòChat‚Äô indicating it‚Äôs ready for input. You can start interacting with it using natural language commands, as shown in the example below:

The terminal version of Jockey offers detailed output for debugging:

Apart from the terminal deployment option, Jockey also provides LangGraph API Server deployment. However, I encountered difficulties in getting it to work due to package conflicts.

In summary, Jockey provides a strong foundation for exploring conversational video agents using the robust Twelve Labs platform, and developers can utilize its customization options. However, the current version conflicts need to be resolved to facilitate broader adoption. With an active Discord channel, there is hope for a resolution soon, and I look forward to posting a deep dive related to customization and its advanced features.

title: The New Kid on the Open-Source Block: DeerFlow, a Deep Research Assistant
content:
### The New Kid on the Open-Source Block: DeerFlow, a Deep Research Assistant


Exploring How DeerFlow‚Äôs Multi-Agent Framework Enhances Open-Source AI¬†Research

Over the past year, open-source AI platforms have been rapidly closing the gap with proprietary systems like OpenAI‚Äôs ChatGPT and Anthropic‚Äôs Claude, delivering powerful features such as autonomous AI agents and deep research capabilities that rival closed-source models. Projects like DeepSeek‚Äôs R1 and OpenManus, a community-built alternative to the invite-only Manus AI agent launched in March 2024, showcase the strength of collaborative development. OpenManus, created by the MetaGPT community in mere hours, matches proprietary agents in tasks like travel planning, stock analysis, and coding, leveraging models like GPT-4o. These advancements, powered by frameworks like Hugging Face‚Äôs Transformers, highlight the growing accessibility and innovation in open-source AI, setting the stage for impactful tools like DeerFlow, which provides the power of agentic workflows and research automation.


### DeerFlow: A community-driven framework for deep¬†research


DeerFlow, an open-source multi-agent framework developed by ByteDance and just released, exemplifies how open-source AI is making strides across all domains of AI. Built on LangChain and LangGraph, DeerFlow coordinates specialized AI agents to tackle complex research tasks with unprecedented efficiency, transparency, and scalability. DeerFlow employs a modular, multi-agent architecture where each agent focuses on specific functions such as task planning, knowledge retrieval, code execution, or report synthesis. This directed graph-based approach, orchestrated by LangGraph, ensures robust task coordination and data flow, making DeerFlow ideal for academic, corporate, and R&D environments.

Key Features of¬†DeerFlow

Installing DeerFlow

To get started with DeerFlow, follow these installation instructions to set up the framework on your local or cloud environment. Ensure you have the necessary dependencies and configurations for a smooth deployment.

Prerequisites

Installation Steps

2. Set Up a Virtual Environment (optional but recommended):

3. Install Python Dependencies:

The requirements.txt includes dependencies like LangChain, LangGraph, and other libraries for web search and code execution.

4. Install Node.js Dependencies (for web UI):

5. Configure Environment Variables: Create a¬†.env file in the root directory and add your API keys and settings:

Refer to the DeerFlow documentation for additional configuration options, such as model selection or proxy settings.

6. Run the Application:

For the core Python framework:

For the web UI:

The web UI will be accessible at http://localhost:3000.

7. Verify Installation: Test DeerFlow with a sample pipeline, such as the included example_research.py, which demonstrates a basic research task like comparing landmarks.

Troubleshooting

Here is a Github link to Google Colab Notebook


### Real-World Applications


DeerFlow‚Äôs versatility makes it a powerful tool across various domains just as the proprietary tools claim. In academia, researchers can use it to conduct systematic literature reviews, synthesize data, and generate structured reports.

How DeerFlow Compares to Proprietary Platforms

Unlike proprietary systems, DeerFlow‚Äôs open-source nature allows users to inspect and modify its architecture, ensuring transparency and reducing dependency on black-box solutions. Additionally, its community-driven approach propels rapid innovation, as seen in the quick development of tools like OpenManus.

This table highlights DeerFlow‚Äôs strengths in transparency, customization, and cost, making it a compelling alternative for users seeking flexibility and control. While OpenAI and Claude offer polished user experiences and robust infrastructure, their closed ecosystems limit adaptability compared to DeerFlow‚Äôs open-source model.


### The Broader Impact of Open-Source AI


The rise of tools like DeerFlow underscores the transformative potential of open-source AI. By democratizing access to advanced technologies, these platforms empower smaller organizations, independent researchers, and developers in resource-constrained regions to compete with industry giants. The collaborative ethos of open-source communities accelerates innovation, as developers worldwide contribute to frameworks like LangChain and Hugging Face, which DeerFlow builds upon. Moreover, open-source AI promotes ethical development by allowing scrutiny of algorithms, reducing the risk of biases inherent in proprietary systems. As Gartner predicts, by 2028, 33% of enterprise software will incorporate agentic AI, with open-source frameworks like DeerFlow showing potential to take charge.

Challenges and Future Directions

Despite its strengths, DeerFlow faces challenges common to open-source projects. Integrating disparate tools and ensuring compatibility across environments can be complex, requiring technical expertise. Additionally, while its human-in-the-loop design mitigates errors, agents may occasionally misinterpret data or hallucinate sources, necessitating robust validation mechanisms. Future developments could focus on enhancing DeerFlow‚Äôs reinforcement learning capabilities, enabling agents to adapt dynamically to unpredictable tasks, as seen in OpenAI‚Äôs Deep Research tool. Expanding support for additional LLMs and integrating advanced visualization tools could further broaden its appeal.

DeerFlow offers a modular, transparent, and powerful framework that could rival proprietary platforms. Its multi-agent architecture, human-in-the-loop design, and robust tool integration make it a go-to solution for deep research and automation, from academic studies to enterprise workflows. With straightforward installation and a supportive community, DeerFlow is accessible to a wide range of users, from developers to researchers. As open-source platforms like DeerFlow continue to innovate, they are not only catching up with but also redefining the standards set by proprietary giants.


### Thank you for being a part of the community
